samples.title: Garbage collection (disambiguation)
samples.original_text:
Garbage collection, or waste collection, is part of municipal waste management.

Garbage collection may also refer to:

 Garbage collection (computer science), in automatic memory management
 Garbage collection (SSD), in flash memory

easy_general.text: Garbage collection is when trucks pick up trash from homes and businesses. This is part of how cities manage waste. Sometimes people also talk about garbage collection in other ways, like in computers or flash drives.

adult_non_technical.text: When you think of garbage collection, you might think of the truck that picks up your trash every week. This process is an important part of municipal waste management, which is the way cities and towns take care of their trash. But garbage collection can also mean something else.

adult_technical.text:
Waste collection, also known as garbage collection, is a crucial component of municipal waste management. It involves the systematic removal of waste from households, businesses, and public areas, ensuring its transportation for proper recycling and disposal. However, the term "garbage collection" can also refer to two distinct processes in the fields of computer science and solid-state drives (SSDs).

In computer science, garbage collection is a technique used for automatic memory management. This process involves periodically identifying and freeing up memory that is no longer in use by a program, thereby preventing potential memory leaks and improving system performance. Garbage collection is widely used in modern programming languages like Java, C#, and Python, as it simplifies memory management and reduces the risk of memory-related errors.

In the context of SSDs, garbage collection is a mechanism used to maintain the performance and longevity of flash memory. Flash memory, the underlying technology in SSDs, has a limited number of write cycles before it begins to degrade. Garbage collection in SSDs involves reorganizing data across the drive to balance the wear and tear on individual memory cells, ensuring optimal performance and lifespan.

samples.title: Route flapping
samples.original_text:
In computer networking and telecommunications, route flapping occurs when a router alternately advertises a destination network via one route then another, or as unavailable and then available again, in quick sequence. 

Route flapping is caused by pathological conditions (hardware errors, software errors, configuration errors, intermittent errors in communications links, unreliable connections, etc.) within the network which cause certain reachability information to be repeatedly advertised and withdrawn. For example, link flap occurs when an interface on a router has a hardware failure that causes the router to announce it alternately as "up" and "down".

In networks with link-state routing protocols, route flapping will force frequent recalculation of the topology by all participating routers. In networks with distance-vector routing protocols, route flapping can trigger routing updates with every state change. In both cases, it prevents the network from converging.

Route flapping can be contained to a smaller area of the network if route aggregation is used. As an aggregate route will not be withdrawn as long as at least one of the aggregated subnets is still valid, a flapping route that is part of an aggregate will not disturb the routers that receive the aggregate.

See also
 BGP route damping
 Supernet

References

Flapping

easy_general.text:
In computer networking, route flapping is when a router keeps switching between two different ways to get to a destination network. This can happen due to various issues like hardware errors, software problems, or unreliable connections. For example, if a router's connection stops working and then starts working again, it can cause route flapping.

Route flapping can cause problems in the network because it forces other routers to constantly update their information. To fix this, network administrators can use a technique called route aggregation, which helps contain the flapping to a smaller area of the network.

adult_non_technical.text: In computer networks, route flapping is when a router keeps switching between different ways to reach a destination network. This can happen due to various issues like hardware problems, software errors, or unreliable connections. When this happens, the router keeps advertising and withdrawing information, which can cause frequent network updates. To prevent this, network administrators can use techniques like route aggregation, which helps contain the problem to a smaller area.

adult_technical.text:
In computer networking and telecommunications, route flapping refers to a situation where a router alternates between advertising a destination network via different routes or as unavailable and available again in rapid succession. This phenomenon is caused by various network issues such as hardware failures, software errors, configuration mistakes, intermittent errors in communication links, or unreliable connections. For instance, link flap occurs when an interface on a router experiences a hardware failure, causing the router to alternately announce it as "up" and "down."

Route flapping can have significant impacts on network performance. In networks using link-state routing protocols, route flapping forces frequent recalculation of the topology by all participating routers, leading to increased overhead and potential network instability. Similarly, in networks with distance-vector routing protocols, route flapping can trigger routing updates with every state change, further exacerbating the issue.

To contain route flapping to a smaller area of the network, route aggregation can be employed. As an aggregate route will not be withdrawn as long as at least one of the aggregated subnets is still valid, a flapping route that is part of an aggregate will not disturb the routers that receive the aggregate.

See also
 BGP route damping
 Supernet

References

Flapping

samples.title: Stata Mater
samples.original_text:
In ancient Roman religion, Stata Mater ("Mother who stops or stabilizes") was a compital goddess who protected against fires. She had an image (simulacrum) in the Forum, and her cultus, as Festus notes, spread from there throughout the neighborhoods (vici) of the city.

The original statue was set up by an Aurelius Cotta who had supervised the installation of new pavement in the Forum at the end of the 80s BC. The goddess's purpose was to safeguard the stonework from fire damage. Only the Lares Augusti outnumber her as recipients of surviving dedications from compital shrines.

In the neighborhoods

The cult of Stata Mater was centered on compital shrines of the vici, and numerous inscriptions to her were made by the heads of neighborhood associations (vicomagistri). Her popularity attests to the everpresent threat and danger of fire in metropolitan Rome. She is sometimes given the additional title Augusta, perhaps in reference to the reorganization of the regions of Rome under Augustus in 7 BC. One of the outcomes of this redistricting was to create local boards or neighborhood watches (vigiles) tasked with fire control, as a response to recent arson in the Forum. The dedications mark the success of local fire brigades in putting out fires. One pairs Stata Mater Augusta with Volcanus Quietus Augustus, "the 'Quieted' Vulcan Augustus." Stata Mater is perhaps to be identified with the Fortuna Augusta Stata named in an inscription. Her cultivation is an example of localized Imperial cult under Augustus.

A Vicus Statae Matris ("Stata Mater's Neighborhood") was located on the Caelian Hill, and a Vicus Statae Siccianae in the Transtiberim.

W.H. Roscher places Stata mater among the indigitamenta, the list of deities maintained by Roman priests to assure that the correct divinity was invoked for rituals.

See also
 Vulcanalia
 Vesta
 Cacus
 Great Fire of Rome

References

External links
 A pedestal for Stata Mater from Roman Spain

Fire goddesses
Roman goddesses

easy_general.text:
In ancient Rome, there was a goddess named Stata Mater, which means "Mother who stops or stabilizes." She was a special goddess who protected against fires. People had a statue of her in the Forum, which was a big public space in the center of the city. From there, her worship spread to the different neighborhoods (vici) of Rome.

The first statue of Stata Mater in the Forum was put up by a Roman official named Aurelius Cotta. He was in charge of installing new pavement in the Forum around the end of the 80 BC. The goddess's job was to protect the new pavement from any fires.

In the neighborhoods, Stata Mater was very important. People honored her by making dedications at special places called compital shrines in the vici. The leaders of the neighborhood groups, called vicomagistri, often made these dedications. The popularity of Stata Mater shows that fire was a big threat to people in Rome.

Stata Mater was sometimes given the title "Augusta," which might be related to the Roman Emperor Augustus. Augustus was a powerful leader who ruled Rome from around 30 BC to the early 14 AD. He reorganized the different regions of Rome in 7 BC, and one of the changes was the creation of neighborhood watches (vigiles) to help control fires. The dedications to Stata Mater show the success of these neighborhood watches in putting out fires.

There were two neighborhoods named after Stata Mater: Vicus Statae Matris on Caelian Hill and Vicus Statae Siccianae in the Transtiberim.

W.H. Roscher believed that Stata Mater was part of a list of deities called the indigitamenta. This list was used to make sure people invoked the right gods during rituals.

Other important Roman gods include the Vulcanalia, Vesta, Cacus, and the Great Fire of Rome. The fire goddesses and Roman goddesses are also related to Stata Mater.

Her image was located in the Forum, and her cultus spread throughout the neighborhoods (vici) of the city. The original statue was installed by Aurelius Cotta, who had supervised the installation of new pavement in the Forum at the end of the 80s BC. In the neighborhoods, the cult of Stata Mater was centered on compital shrines, and numerous inscriptions were made to her by the heads of neighborhood associations (vicomagistri). Her popularity reflects the ever-present threat and danger of fire in metropolitan Rome. She is sometimes given the additional title Augusta, possibly in reference to the reorganization of the regions of Rome under Augustus in 7 BC. This redistricting created local boards or neighborhood watches (vigiles) tasked with fire control, as a response to recent arson in the Forum. The dedications mark the success of local fire brigades in putting out fires. Stata Mater Augusta is often paired with Volcanus Quietus Augustus, "the 'Quieted' Vulcan Augustus." Stata Mater may be identified with the Fortuna Augusta Stata named in an inscription. Her cultivation is an example of localized Imperial cult under Augustus.

A Vicus Statae Matris ("Stata Mater's Neighborhood") was located on the Caelian Hill, and a Vicus Statae Siccianae in the Transtiberim.

W.H. Roscher places Stata Mater among the indigitamenta, the list of deities maintained by Roman priests to ensure the correct divinity was invoked for rituals.

samples.title: Westport Township, Pope County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Westport Township is a township in Pope County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 279 at the 2000 census.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 35.4 square miles (91.8 km), of which 34.5 square miles (89.5 km) is land and 0.9 square mile (2.3 km) (2.48%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 279 people, 83 households, and 68 families residing in the township.  The population density was 8.1 people per square mile (3.1/km).  There were 90 housing units at an average density of 2.6/sq mi (1.0/km).  The racial makeup of the township was 99.28% White, and 0.72% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 1.08% of the population.

There were 83 households, out of which 47.0% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 78.3% were married couples living together, 2.4% had a female householder with no husband present, and 16.9% were non-families. 13.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and 6.0% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 3.36 and the average family size was 3.72.

In the township the population was spread out, with 35.8% under the age of 18, 9.3% from 18 to 24, 26.2% from 25 to 44, 21.1% from 45 to 64, and 7.5% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 31 years. For every 100 females, there were 111.4 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 113.1 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $42,188, and the median income for a family was $44,250. Males had a median income of $31,667 versus $17,750 for females. The per capita income for the township was $14,185.  About 13.6% of families and 13.2% of the population were below the poverty line, including 12.6% of those under the age of eighteen and 23.1% of those 65 or over.

References

Townships in Minnesota

samples.title: 105 BC
samples.original_text:
Year 105 BC was a year of the pre-Julian Roman calendar. At the time it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Rufus and Maximus (or, less frequently, year 649 Ab urbe condita) and the Sixth Year of Yuanfeng. The denomination 105 BC for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events 
 By place 
 Roman Republic 
 January 1 – Gnaeus Mallius Maximus and Publius Rutilius Rufus become Roman consuls. 
 October 6 – The Battle of Arausio, where the Cimbri destroy two Roman armies on the Rhône, is the most severe defeat of Roman forces since the Battle of Cannae.
 Gaius Marius, together with the consul Publius Rutilius Rufus, initiates sweeping reforms of the Roman army.
 Lucius Cornelius Sulla secures the capture of Jugurtha. His success is made possible by the treachery of Bocchus I, king of Mauretania, and this ends the Jugurthine War (which has begun in 112 BC).
 At Rome, the first official gladiator match is demonstrated by gladiators from Capua, as part of a training program for the military.

Births 
 Decimus Laberius, Roman nobleman and Latin writer (d. 43 BC)
 Tiberius Claudius Nero, Roman politician and general 
 Marcus Atius Balbus, Roman praetor and governor (d. 51 BC)

Deaths 
 Marcus Aurelius Scaurus, Roman politician and general, executed as a prisoner of war in the advent of the Battle of Arausio

References

easy_general.text:
In the year 105 BC, many important things happened in the Roman Republic. On January 1, Gnaeus Mallius Maximus and Publius Rutilius Rufus became the Roman consuls, which were the leaders of the Roman army. On October 6, there was a battle called the Battle of Arausio, where a group of people called the Cimbri defeated two Roman armies. This was the worst defeat for the Romans since a battle called the Battle of Cannae.

Gaius Marius and Publius Rutilius Rufus worked together to make big changes to the Roman army. Lucius Cornelius Sulla, a Roman general, captured a man named Jugurtha. He did this with the help of Bocchus I, the king of Mauretania, who betrayed Jugurtha. This marked the end of a long war for the Romans called the Jugurthine War, which started in 112 BC.

In Rome, the first official gladiator match took place. Gladiators were people who fought in battles for entertainment. This match was meant to help the military train their soldiers.

Some important people were born this year, like Decimus Laberius, who was a Roman nobleman and writer, and Tiberius Claudius Nero, who was a Roman politician and general. Marcus Atius Balbus, a Roman praetor and governor, was also born this year.

Marcus Aurelius Scaurus, a Roman politician and general, died as a prisoner of war after the Battle of Arausio.

adult_non_technical.text:
In the year 105 BC, which was a long time ago, some important things happened in Rome. Back then, this year was known as the "Year of the Consulship of Rufus and Maximus" or "year 649 Ab urbe condita," which means "year 649 since the city of Rome was founded." We now call it 105 BC because that's how people started to count years using the Anno Domini calendar, which is the common way we count years.

Here are some things that happened in the Roman Republic:

On January 1, Gnaeus Mallius Maximus and Publius Rutilius Rufus became the leaders, or consuls, of Rome.

On October 6, there was a battle called the Battle of Arausio. A group of people called the Cimbri defeated two Roman armies near the Rhône River. This was one of the worst losses for the Romans since a battle called the Battle of Cannae.

Gaius Marius and Publius Rutilius Rufus made changes to the Roman army.

Lucius Cornelius Sulla captured a man named Jugurtha. This helped to end a war called the Jugurthine War, which had started in 112 BC.

In Rome, the first official gladiator match took place. Gladiators from a city called Capua fought each other as part of a training program for the military.

Some important people were born in 105 BC:

- Decimus Laberius, a Roman nobleman and writer
- Tiberius Claudius Nero, a Roman politician and general
- Marcus Atius Balbus, a Roman praetor and governor

Some important people died in 105 BC:

- Marcus Aurelius Scaurus, a Roman politician and general, who was executed after the Battle of Arausio

adult_technical.text:
The year 105 BC was a pivotal year in the pre-Julian Roman calendar, known as the Year of the Consulship of Rufus and Maximus or year 649 Ab urbe condita. This year predates the Anno Domini (AD) era, which became the standard method for denoting years in Europe starting from the early medieval period.

In the Roman Republic, on January 1, the year was marked by the appointment of two consuls: Gnaeus Mallius Maximus and Publius Rutilianus Rufus. On October 6, the Battle of Arausio took place, where the Cimbri tribe decisively defeated two Roman armies on the Rhône River. This was the most severe defeat for Roman forces since the Battle of Cannae in 216 BC.

Gaius Marius, in collaboration with the consul Publius Rutilianus Rufus, initiated significant reforms to the Roman army, which would have a lasting impact on the military structure. Additionally, Lucius Cornelius Sulla secured the capture of Jugurtha, a Berber king, with the treachery of Bocchus I, the king of Mauretania. This event concluded the Jugurthine War, which had begun in 112 BC.

In Rome, the first official gladiator match was held, featuring gladiators from Capua. This event was part of a training program for the military.

Some notable births during this year include Decimus Laberius, a Roman nobleman and Latin writer, Tiberius Claudius Nero, a Roman politician and general, and Marcus Atius Balbus, a Roman praetor and governor.

Unfortunately, the year saw the death of Marcus Aurelius Scaurus, a Roman politician and general, who was executed as a prisoner of war in the aftermath of the Battle of Arausio.

During this year, several important events took place. One of the notable events was the birth of Solon, a famous lawmaker from Athens. Solon was known for his fair and just laws that helped shape the city of Athens into a strong and prosperous society.

samples.title: Numitor
samples.original_text:
In Roman mythology, King Numitor () of Alba Longa, was the maternal grandfather of Rome's founder and first king, Romulus, and his twin brother Remus.  He was the son of Procas, descendant of Aeneas the Trojan, and father of the twins' mother, Rhea Silvia, and Lausus.

In 794 BC Procas died and was meant to be succeeded by Numitor. Instead he was overthrown and removed from the kingdom by his brother, Amulius, who had no respect for his father's will or his brother's seniority. Amulius also murdered Numitor's sons, in an effort to remove power from his brother for himself.

Rhea Silvia was made a Vestal Virgin by Amulius rendering her unable to have children on pain of death; however, according to myth she was forcibly impregnated by the god Mars. Romulus and Remus overthrew Amulius and reinstated Numitor as king in 752 B.C .

Family tree

See also
Aeneid
The Golden Bough (mythology)

Notes

References

Kings of Alba Longa

Characters in Book VI of the Aeneid

easy_general.text:
In Roman mythology, King Numitor was the grandfather of Romulus and Remus, the founders of Rome. He was the son of Procas, who was descended from Aeneas, a Trojan hero. Numitor had two children: Rhea Silvia, the mother of Romulus and Remus, and Lausus.

In 794 BC, Procas died, and Numitor was supposed to take over as king. However, his brother, Amulius, took over the kingdom and kicked Numitor out. Amulius killed Numitor's sons to ensure he kept power.

Rhea Silvia was forced to become a Vestal Virgin, which meant she couldn't have children. But according to the myth, the god Mars made her pregnant. Romulus and Remus were born and eventually defeated Amulius, restoring Numitor to the throne in 752 BC.

Family tree

adult_non_technical.text:
In Roman mythology, King Numitor of Alba Longa was the maternal grandfather of Rome's founder, Romulus, and his twin brother, Remus. He was the son of Procas, who was descended from Aeneas, a Trojan hero. Numitor had two children: Rhea Silvia, the mother of Romulus and Remus, and Lausus.

In 794 BC, Procas died, and Numitor was supposed to take over as king. However, his brother, Amulius, took control and forced Numitor out of the kingdom. Amulius also killed Numitor's sons to keep the power for himself.

Rhea Silvia was then made a Vestal Virgin, which meant she couldn't have children or she would be killed. But according to the myth, the god Mars made her pregnant with Romulus and Remus. These twins grew up and defeated Amulius, restoring Numitor to the throne in 752 BC.

Numitor's family tree can be found in the Aeneid and The Golden Bough (mythology).

adult_technical.text:
In Roman mythology, King Numitor of Alba Longa was the maternal grandfather of Rome's founder and first king, Romulus, and his twin brother, Remus. He was the son of Procas, a descendant of Aeneas the Trojan, and the father of the twins' mother, Rhea Silvia, and Lausus.

In 794 BC, Procas passed away, and Numitor was expected to succeed him. However, he was overthrown and removed from the kingdom by his brother, Amulius, who disregarded their father's will and Numitor's seniority. Amulius also murdered Numitor's sons, aiming to seize power for himself.

Rhea Silvia was then made a Vestal Virgin by Amulius, which meant she was forbidden to have children under penalty of death. However, according to myth, she was forcibly impregnated by the god Mars, leading her to give birth to Romulus and Remus, who overthrown Amulius and reinstated Numitor as king in 752 BC.

samples.title: Ford Escort
samples.original_text:
Ford Escort may refer to one of several vehicles manufactured by Ford Motor Company:
 Ford Escort (North America), a compact car manufactured for the North American market from 1980 to 2003
 Ford Escort (Europe), a vehicle manufactured by Ford Europe from 1968 to 2002
 Ford Escort RS Cosworth, sports and rally version of the fifth generation European Escort
 Ford Escort (China), a Ford Focus-based compact car for the Chinese market since 2015
 Ford Escort (Squire-based estate), a variant of the Ford Squire built and marketed in the United Kingdom from 1955 to 1961

easy_general.text:
The Ford Escort is a car made by Ford Motor Company. There are different versions of the Ford Escort, and they are made for different parts of the world.

1. The North American Ford Escort is a small car that was made from 1980 to 2003. It was popular in the United States and Canada.
2. The European Ford Escort is a car that was made from 1968 to 2002. It was popular in Europe.
3. The Ford Escort RS Cosworth is a special version of the European Ford Escort. It was made for sports and rally racing.
4. The Chinese Ford Escort is a small car that is based on the Ford Focus. It was made for China since 2015.
5. The Ford Escort (Squire-based estate) is a version of the Ford Squire. It was made in the United Kingdom from 1955 to 1961.

adult_non_technical.text: The Ford Escort is a car model made by Ford Motor Company. There are several different versions of the Ford Escort, and each one was made for a different part of the world. One version was a compact car for North America, which was made from 1980 to 2003. Another type of Escort was made in Europe from 1968 to 2002. There was also a sports and rally version of the Escort called the RS Cosworth, which was made for the European market. Additionally, there is a version of the Escort made in China since 2015, which is based on the Ford Focus. Lastly, there was a version of the Escort that was based on the Ford Squire, which was made in the United Kingdom from 1955 to 1961.

adult_technical.text:

samples.title: Watarrka National Park
samples.original_text:
Watarrka National Park is a protected area  in the Northern Territory of Australia located about 1,316 kilometres (817 miles) south of the territory capital of Darwin and  southwest of Alice Springs.

It contains the much visited Kings Canyon at the western end of the George Gill Range and Kathleen Springs —  to the southeast of Kings Canyon.

Watarrka National Park was established in 1989 and gets its name from the Aboriginal name of the land.

In 1986, the national park was described by the Department of Environment as follows:One of the most spectacular canyons in Central Australia. Kings Canyon contains some 60 rare or relict plant species and a total of 572 different plant species and 80 species of birds. It is a 'living plant museum' and is notable for its stands of cycads & permanent rock pools. There are some well-preserved Aboriginal paintings and engravings in the area...

The national park is categorised as an IUCN Category II protected area. On 25 March 1986, it was listed on the now-defunct Register of the National Estate.

See also 
 Protected areas of the Northern Territory

References

External links
Official webpage
Webpage on the Protected Planet website

National parks of the Northern Territory
Protected areas established in 1989
1989 establishments in Australia
Northern Territory places listed on the defunct Register of the National Estate

easy_general.text:
Watarrka National Park is a special place in the Northern Territory of Australia. It's about 1,316 kilometers (817 miles) south of the capital, Darwin, and southwest of Alice Springs. The park is home to two famous places: Kings Canyon and Kathleen Springs. Kings Canyon is at the western end of the George Gill Range, and Kathleen Springs is to the southeast of Kings Canyon.

Watarrka National Park was created in 1989 and gets its name from the Aboriginal people who lived there. In 1986, the Department of Environment described the park as one of the most beautiful canyons in Central Australia. Kings Canyon has 60 rare or special plant species, 572 different plant species, and 80 types of birds. It's like a living plant museum with special plants called cycads and permanent rock pools. There are also some old Aboriginal paintings and carvings in the area.

The park is classified as an IUCN Category II protected area, which means it's a place where plants and animals are protected. On 25 March 1986, it was listed on a list called the Register of the National Estate, which is no longer used.

You can find more information about other protected areas in the Northern Territory on the official webpage or on the Protected Planet website.

adult_non_technical.text:
Watarrka National Park is a protected area in the Northern Territory of Australia. It's about 817 miles south of the capital city of Darwin and southwest of Alice Springs. The park is home to two famous places: Kings Canyon and Kathleen Springs.

Kings Canyon is a beautiful canyon at the western end of the George Gill Range. It's known for its rare plants and birds, with over 60 rare or ancient plant species and 80 species of birds. The canyon is called a "living plant museum" because of its unique plants, like cycads and permanent rock pools. There are also well-preserved Aboriginal paintings and engravings in the area.

Watarrka National Park was created in 1989 and is named after the Aboriginal name for the land. It's classified as an IUCN Category II protected area, which means it's a place where plants and animals are protected and preserved. The park was also listed on the Register of the National Estate in 1986, which was a list of very important natural and cultural sites in Australia.

For more information, check out the official webpage or the Protected Planet website.

adult_technical.text:
Watarrka National Park is a protected area situated in the Northern Territory of Australia, approximately 1,316 kilometers (817 miles) south of the territory capital of Darwin and southwest of Alice Springs. The park encompasses the Kings Canyon, located at the western end of the George Gill Range, and Kathleen Springs, situated to the southeast of Kings Canyon.

Established in 1989, Watarrka National Park derived its name from the Aboriginal name of the land. In 1986, the Department of Environment described the park as one of the most spectacular canyons in Central Australia. Kings Canyon is home to approximately 60 rare or relict plant species, a total of 572 different plant species, and 80 species of birds. The park is also known for its living plant museum, with notable stands of cycads and permanent rock pools. Additionally, the area features well-preserved Aboriginal paintings and engravings.

Watarrka National Park is classified as an IUCN Category II protected area. On March 25, 1986, it was listed on the now-defunct Register of the National Estate.

samples.title: Perieres

In Greek mythology, Perieres () may refer to these two distinct individuals.
Perieres, king of Messenia and son of Aeolus.
 Perieres, Theban charioteer of Menoeceus (father of Creon). He was the one who wounded Clymenus, king of Minyans and father of Erginus. This resulted to the heavy tribute imposed by the Minyans to the Thebans.

Notes

Because of this, the Minyans made the Thebans give them a lot of stuff as punishment.

In Greek mythology, the name Perieres can be attributed to two separate figures:

1. Perieres, the king of Messenia and the son of Aeolus.

samples.title: Nässjö Municipality
samples.original_text:
Nässjö Municipality (Nässjö kommun) is a municipality in Jönköping County, southern Sweden where the town Nässjö is situated.

The present municipality was created in 1971 when the City of Nässjö (instituted in 1914) was amalgamated with five surrounding municipalities.

Localities
There are 11 urban areas (also called a Tätort or locality) in Nässjö Municipality.

In the table the localities are listed according to the size of the population as of December 31, 2005. The municipal seat is in bold characters.

Sister cities 
Nässjö has had two sister cities since the 1940s: Brønderslev in Denmark and Eidsberg in Norway.

References

Statistics Sweden

External links

easy_general.text: Nässjö Municipality is a place in southern Sweden where the town of Nässjö is located. It was formed in 1971 by combining the town of Nässjö with five other towns. There are 11 towns and villages in Nässjö Municipality. The table shows the towns and villages and their populations. The main town is in bold. Nässjö has two sister cities in Denmark and Norway.

adult_non_technical.text:
Nässjö Municipality is a place in southern Sweden where the town of Nässjö is located. It was formed in 1971 by combining the town of Nässjö, which was established in 1914, with five other nearby towns.

There are 11 areas in Nässjö Municipality with a lot of people. These areas are called localities or Tätorter. The table shows the localities with the town of Nässjö being the biggest one.

Nässjö has two sister cities: Brønderslev in Denmark and Eidsberg in Norway. These sister cities have been around since the 1940s.

You can learn more about Nässjö's history on their official website, but some parts are in Swedish. You can also find more information from Statistics Sweden.

adult_technical.text:
Nässjö Municipality, officially named Nässjö kommun, is a local government in Jönköping County, located in southern Sweden. The town of Nässjö serves as the municipal seat. The current administrative unit was established in 1971 through the amalgamation of the City of Nässjö, which was founded in 1914, with five neighboring municipalities.

Within the municipality, there are 11 urban areas, also referred to as Tätort or localities. These localities are listed below by population size as of December 31, 2005, with the municipal seat indicated in bold.

samples.title: List of counties of Prince Edward Island
samples.original_text:
The Canadian province of Prince Edward Island has three counties that have historically been used as administrative divisions for the provincial government, and prior to Confederation (in 1873), the colonial government.

The current system of land division in Prince Edward Island, including its three counties, dates to a series of surveys undertaken in 1764-65 by Captain Samuel Holland of the British Army's Corps of Royal Engineers.  Holland's survey saw the island divided into the three counties, each of which had a "royalty" (or shire town) as a county seat.  The rest of the county outside the royalty was sub-divided into parishes for the Church of England, measuring approximately ; the parishes were further sub-divided into townships measuring approximately .

The counties are no longer used as administrative boundaries for the provincial government; however, they continue to be used as census divisions by Statistics Canada for statistical purposes in administering the Canadian census.

See also

Administrative divisions of Canada

References

 
Counties
Prince Edward Island

easy_general.text: Prince Edward Island, a province in Canada, has three counties that were once used to organize the government. Before 1873, these counties were used by the colonial government. The counties were created by a British Army officer in 1764-65. Today, the counties are still used by Statistics Canada for the Canadian census.

adult_non_technical.text:
Prince Edward Island, a province in Canada, has three counties that were once used as administrative divisions for the provincial government and the colonial government before the country's Confederation in 1873.

The current system of land division in Prince Edward Island comes from a series of surveys done in 1764-65 by Captain Samuel Holland, dividing the island into the three counties. Each county had a "royalty" (or shire town), which was the county seat. The rest of the county was then divided into parishes for the Church of England, each measuring about . These parishes were further divided into townships, each measuring about .

Today, the counties are no longer used as administrative boundaries for the provincial government. However, they are still used as census divisions by Statistics Canada for statistical purposes in the Canadian census.

See also: Administrative divisions of Canada

References: 
Counties of Prince Edward Island

adult_technical.text: The Canadian province of Prince Edward Island has three counties that have historically served as administrative divisions for both the provincial and colonial governments. The current land division system dates back to surveys conducted by Captain Samuel Holland of the British Army's Corps of Royal Engineers in 1764-65. Holland's survey divided the island into three counties, each with a "royalty" or shire town as the county seat. The remaining areas of each county were further divided into parishes for the Church of England, measuring approximately , and then divided into townships measuring approximately . Although the counties are no longer used as administrative boundaries for the provincial government, they are still utilized by Statistics Canada as census divisions for statistical purposes in the Canadian census.

adult_non_technical.text:
The USS Triton is a name that has been used for several different ships in the United States Navy. Here's a breakdown of the different versions:

1. The first USS Triton was a tugboat that was in service from 1889 to 1930. A tugboat is a small, powerful boat that helps move larger ships around the water.
2. The second USS Triton was another tugboat that served for a short time during 1918.
3. The third USS Triton was a submarine that was commissioned in 1940 and was sunk in 1943. A submarine is a ship that can travel underwater.
4. The fourth USS Triton was a submarine that was in service from 1959 to 1969. It was later known as SSN-586, which is a type of nuclear submarine.

For more information, you can check out the United States Navy ship names.

adult_technical.text:
The designation "USS Triton" has been applied to several vessels in the United States Navy, each with its own unique characteristics and service history. Here is a detailed overview of each instance:

1. **USS Triton (AT-11)**: This vessel was a tugboat that was in commission from 1889 to 1930. Tugboats were responsible for towing and maneuvering ships, assisting in port operations and maintaining order within the fleet. The Triton of this period played a crucial role in the Navy's logistics and maintenance.

2. **USS Triton (AT-18)**: The second vessel to bear the name "USS Triton" was a tugboat that saw action during World War I. It was commissioned in 1918 and saw a brief service in 1918, just before the end of the war. This vessel remained in service until the end of the war and was decommissioned in 1919.

3. **USS Triton (SSN-586)**: The third "USS Triton" was a submarine that was commissioned in 1940 and served in World War II. It was sunk in 1943 during a patrol in the Pacific. Submarines were vital in the war effort, engaging in underwater warfare and intercepting enemy shipping.

4. **USS Triton (SSN-586)**: The fourth "USS Triton" was a nuclear-powered submarine that was commissioned in 1959 and decommissioned in 1969. This vessel was part of the Navy's nuclear-powered submarine fleet, designed for strategic missions and intelligence gathering.

For further information on the naming conventions and history of United States Navy ships, please refer to the United States Navy ship names article.

samples.title: Murray River National Park
samples.original_text:
Murray River National Park is a protected area  in South Australia located between  and  north east of the Adelaide city centre.  The national park was proclaimed in 1991 "to conserve a significant proportion of South Australia’s floodplain environments which are not represented widely in other reserve systems."  The national park consists of three sections adjoining the Murray River and extending from near Loxton in the south west to near Renmark in the north-east.  The first which is known as the ‘Katarapko’ section is located on the north side of the river between Loxton in the south and Berri in the north.  The second section which is known as the ‘Lyrup Flats’ section is located on the north side of the river midway between Berri and Loxton.  The third section is known as the ‘Bulyong’ section is located on the west side of the river upstream from Renmark.     The national park is classified as an IUCN Category VI protected area.

See also

samples.title: Tuireann
samples.original_text:
In Irish mythology, Tuireann (Old Irish: Tuirenn or Tuirill Biccreo) was the father by Danu (or Brigid) of Creidhne, Luchtaine, and Goibniu.

His other sons, by his daughter Danand, included Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba, who killed Lugh's father Cian. As an erec (a recompense fine), they were sent on a quest recounted as Oidheadh Chlainne Tuireann (The Tragedy of the Sons of Tuireann), one of the Three sorrowful tales of Erin. After Lugh had taken his elaborate revenge, Tuireann died of grief over their graves.

He is stated in various portions of Lebor Gabála Érenn to be the same person as Delbáeth mac Ogma, who is also credited as the father of Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba.

References

Tuatha Dé Danann

easy_general.text:
In Irish mythology, Tuireann was a father who had many children. With his wife Danu (or Brigid), he had Creidhne, Luchtaine, and Goibniu. With his daughter Danand, he had Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba. These sons killed Lugh's father, Cian. As a result, they were sent on a quest to make up for their mistake. This story is called "The Tragedy of the Sons of Tuireann" and is one of the Three Sorrowful Tales of Erin. After Lugh took his revenge, Tuireann died of sadness over his sons' graves.

In a book called Lebor Gabála Érenn, Tuireann is said to be the same person as Delbáeth mac Ogma, who is also the father of Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba.

References

easy_general.text: Mathematical optimization is about finding the best solution to a problem. It's like trying to find the highest or lowest point on a graph. samples.title: 186 BC
samples.original_text:
Year 186 BC was a year of the pre-Julian Roman calendar. At the time it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Albinus and Philippus (or, less frequently, year 568 Ab urbe condita). The denomination 186 BC for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events 
 By place 

 Roman Republic 
 The rapid spread of the Bacchanalia cult throughout the Roman Republic, which, it is claimed, indulges in all kinds of crimes and political conspiracies at its nocturnal meetings, leads to the Roman Senate issuing a decree, the Senatus consultum de Bacchanalibus, by which the Bacchanalia are prohibited throughout all Italy except in certain special cases which must be approved specifically by the Senate.

 Asia Minor 
 Eumenes II of Pergamum defeats Prusias I of Bithynia.

 China 
 The first burial at the famous archaeological site of Mawangdui is made during the Western Han Dynasty of China.

Births 
 Ptolemy VI Philometor, king of Egypt, who will reign from 180 BC (d. 145 BC)

Deaths 
 Li Cang, Marquis of Dai, buried in one of the Mawangdui

References

easy_general.text: In 186 BC, the Roman Senate banned a cult called the Bacchanalia, which was said to involve crimes and political conspiracies. In Asia Minor, a king named Eumenes II defeated another king named Prusias I. In China, the first burial at an archaeological site called Mawangdui took place.

adult_non_technical.text:
In the year 186 BC, which was part of the pre-Julian Roman calendar, the year was referred to as the Year of the Consulship of Albinus and Philippus, or less commonly as year 568 Ab urbe condita. The term "186 BC" has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the standard in Europe for naming years.

Here's a summary of some significant events that occurred in different parts of the world:

186 BC:

1. Roman Republic: In 186 BC, a religious cult called the Bacchanalia had quickly spread throughout the Roman Republic. This cult was believed to be involved in various crimes and political conspiracies during their secret meetings. In response, the Roman Senate issued a decree, known as the Senatus consultum de Bacchanalibus, which prohibited the Bacchanalia everywhere in Italy, except in certain special cases that had to be approved by the Senate.

2. Asia Minor: In the region of Asia Minor, a ruler named Eumenes II of Pergamum defeated another ruler named Prusias I of Bithynia.

3. China: The first burial occurred at the famous archaeological site of Mawangdui during the Western Han Dynasty of China.

4. Births: Ptolemy VI Philometor, who would later become the king of Egypt from 180 BC to 145 BC, was born in 186 BC.

5. Deaths: Li Cang, the Marquis of Dai, died and was buried in one of the Mawangdui tombs.

References:

adult_technical.text:
In 186 BC, the pre-Julian Roman calendar marked the year as the Year of the Consulship of Albinus and Philippus, or 568 Ab urbe condita. The designation 186 BC emerged during the early medieval period when the Anno Domini calendar era became the dominant method in Europe for naming years.

By place:

Roman Republic:
In the Roman Republic, the rapid spread of the Bacchanalia cult, known for its nocturnal meetings and alleged involvement in crimes and political conspiracies, led to the Roman Senate issuing a decree, the Senatus consultum de Bacchanalibus. This decree prohibited the Bacchanalia throughout Italy, except in specific cases approved by the Senate.

Asia Minor:
Eumenes II of Pergamum achieved victory over Prusias I of Bithynia, marking a significant shift in the balance of power in the region.

China:
The first burial at the renowned archaeological site of Mawangdui occurred during the Western Han Dynasty of China.

Births:
Ptolemy VI Philometor, who would later rule Egypt from 180 BC to 145 BC, was born in 186 BC.

Deaths:
Li Cang, the Marquis of Dai, passed away and was buried in one of the Mawangdui tombs.

samples.title: Dodoni
samples.original_text:
Dodoni () is a village and a municipality in the Ioannina regional unit, Epirus, Greece. The seat of the municipality is the village Agia Kyriaki (community Theriakisi).

The modern village of Dodoni is located near the ancient city of same name and site of the ancient oracle of Dodona. Oedipus the King was shot here in 1967.

Municipality
The present municipality Dodoni was formed at the 2011 local government reform by the merger of the following 4 former municipalities, that became municipal units:
Agios Dimitrios
Dodoni
Lakka Souliou
Selloi

The municipality Dodoni has an area of 657.499 km2, the municipal unit Dodoni has an area of 101.016 km2, and the community Dodoni has an area of 8.748 km2.

Gallery

References

Populated places in Ioannina (regional unit)
Municipalities of Epirus (region)
Cities in ancient Greece

easy_general.text: Dodoni is a village and a place where people make decisions in Greece. It's close to an old city and a place where people used to ask for advice. There's also a movie made there.

adult_non_technical.text:
Dodoni is a village and a town in the region of Epirus, Greece. The main part of the town is a village called Agia Kyriaki, which is part of a larger area called Theriakisi.

The modern village of Dodoni is close to an ancient city with the same name and a place where people used to get advice from a god called an oracle. A famous movie called "Oedipus the King" was filmed here in 1967.

In 2011, Dodoni was formed by combining four villages: Agios Dimitrios, Dodoni, Lakka, and Selloi. The new town covers an area of about 657 square kilometers. The main part of Dodoni is a smaller area of about 101 square kilometers, and the surrounding area is about 8 square kilometers.

adult_technical.text:
Dodoni is a village and municipality located in the Ioannina regional unit of Epirus, Greece. The seat of the municipality is the village of Agia Kyriaki, which is part of the community of Theriakisi. The modern village of Dodoni is situated near the ancient city of Dodoni and the site of the ancient oracle of Dodona. Notably, the film "Oedipus the King" was shot in this area in 1967.

The current municipality of Dodoni was established following the 2011 local government reform, through the merger of four former municipalities, which became municipal units. These units are Agios Dimitrios, Dodoni, Lakka Souliou, and Selloi. The total area of the municipality Dodoni is 657.499 square kilometers, while the municipal unit Dodoni covers an area of 101.016 square kilometers. The community of Dodoni has an area of 8.748 square kilometers.

samples.title: Florence, Illinois
samples.original_text:
Florence is a village in Pike County, Illinois, United States. The population was 71 at the 2000 census.

Geography
Florence is located at  (39.628248, −90.610328).

According to the 2010 census, Florence has a total area of , all land.

Demographics

As of the census of 2000, there were 71 people, 30 households, and 21 families residing in the village. The population density was 350.4 people per square mile (137.1/km). There were 45 housing units at an average density of 222.1 per square mile (86.9/km). The racial makeup of the village was 100.00% White.

There were 30 households, out of which 16.7% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 50.0% were married couples living together, 16.7% had a female householder with no husband present, and 30.0% were non-families. 23.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and 13.3% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.37 and the average family size was 2.67.

In the village, the population was spread out, with 22.5% under the age of 18, 5.6% from 18 to 24, 22.5% from 25 to 44, 26.8% from 45 to 64, and 22.5% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 44 years. For every 100 females, there were 115.2 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 89.7 males.

The median income for a household in the village was $20,000, and the median income for a family was $22,679. Males had a median income of $19,000 versus $20,625 for females. The per capita income for the village was $9,878. There were 8.0% of families and 15.1% of the population living below the poverty line, including no under eighteens and 5.0% of those over 64.

easy_general.text:
"Daigo is a word that can refer to different things:

Buddhism
Daigo (Zen) is a Buddhist term that means great enlightenment or great realization.
Daigo (Shōbōgenzō) is a book in Eihei Dōgen's Shōbōgenzō, which is about Great Realization.
Daigo Temple is a temple where Emperor Daigo got his name.

People
Emperor Daigo was a ruler of Japan from 897 to 930.
The Daigo family is a part of the Ichijō family, which was a noble family in Japan.
Daigo (musician) is a Japanese singer-songwriter, actor, talent, and voice actor born in 1978.
Daigo Umehara, also known as "Daigo," is a Japanese competitive fighting game player.

Places
Daigo, Fushimi, Kyoto is a district in the city of Kyoto.
Daigo Station (Kyoto) is a train station in Kyoto.
Daigo Station (Akita) is another train station in Akita.
Daigo, Ibaraki is a town in Ibaraki Prefecture.

Other uses
Daigo (dairy product) is a type of ghee, which is a type of butter that was possibly made in ancient Japan.
Daigo is also a character from a TV show called Gosei Sentai Dairanger.

See also
Daigou is a word that means the unauthorized import of foreign goods into China."

adult_non_technical.text:
"Daigo is a term that can refer to different things, depending on the context. Here are some possible meanings:

Buddhism
In Zen Buddhism, Daigo means great enlightenment or great realization. It's also the name of a book in Eihei Dōgen's Shōbōgenzō, which is a collection of teachings on Zen. Daigo Temple, from which Emperor Daigo took his name, is a Buddhist temple in Japan.

People
Emperor Daigo was a ruler of Japan from 897 to 930. The Daigo family, a branch of the Ichijō family, was a group of Japanese nobles. Daigo, a Japanese singer-songwriter, actor, talent, and voice actor, was born in 1978. Daigo is also the name of a Japanese competitive fighting game player, Daigo Umehara, who is simply known as Daigo.

Places
Daigo is a district in the ward of Fushimi-ku, Kyoto, Japan. There is also a train station called Daigo Station in Kyoto and another one in Akita. Daigo, Ibaraki, is a town in Ibaraki Prefecture.

Other uses
Daigo can also refer to a dairy product called ghee, which is believed to have been made in ancient Japan. It's also the name of a character from the TV show Gosei Sentai Dairanger.

See also
Daigou is the unauthorized import of foreign goods into China."

samples.title: Pane carasau
samples.original_text:
Pane carasau (, ; "toasted bread" in Sardinian language, from the past participle of the Sardinian verb  "to toast", referring to the crust) is a traditional flatbread from Sardinia. It is called  in Italian, meaning "sheet music", in reference to its large and paper-thin shape, which is said to be so thin before cooking that a sheet of music can be read through it.

The bread is thin and crisp, usually in the form of a dish half a meter wide. It is made by taking baked flat bread (made of durum wheat flour, salt, yeast, and water), then separating it into two sheets which are baked again. The recipe is very ancient and was conceived for shepherds, who used to stay far from home for months at a time: pane carasau can last up to one year if it is kept dry. The bread can be eaten either dry or wet (with water, wine, or sauces). A similar, yeast-free bread, with added seasoning, is known as  "dripped bread".

Remains of the bread were found in archeological excavations of nuraghes (traditional Sardinian stone buildings) and it was therefore already eaten on the island prior to 1000 BC.

References

External links
 A video showing the production of Pane carasau
 History of Pane Carasau

Italian breads
Flatbreads
Cuisine of Sardinia
Ancient dishes

easy_general.text:
Pane carasau is a traditional flatbread from Sardinia. It's called "sheet music" in Italian because it's so thin that you can read a sheet of music through it. The bread is thin and crispy, usually shaped like a dish half a meter wide. It's made by taking baked flat bread, made from durum wheat flour, salt, yeast, and water, and separating it into two sheets that are baked again. This recipe has been around for ages, and it was made for shepherds who stayed away from home for months. Pane carasau can last up to a year if it's kept dry. You can eat it dry or with water, wine, or sauces. A similar bread, without yeast and with added seasoning, is called "dripped bread."

Remains of pane carasau were found in ancient Sardinian stone buildings called nuraghes, which means it was eaten on the island before 1000 BC.

adult_non_technical.text:
Pane carasau is a traditional flatbread from Sardinia, an island of Italy. It's called "toasted bread" in the Sardinian language because it has a crispy crust. In Italian, it's called "sheet music" because it's so thin that you can read a sheet of music through it before cooking.

To make pane carasau, you start with a baked flatbread made from durum wheat, salt, yeast, and water. Then, you separate it into two thin sheets and bake them again. This recipe is very old and was made for shepherds who stayed away from home for months. Pane carasau can last up to a year if kept dry. You can eat it dry or with water, wine, or sauces.

A similar bread without yeast is called "dripped bread." Remains of this bread were found in ancient Sardinian stone buildings called nuraghes, which means it was already eaten on the island before 1000 BC.

adult_technical.text: Pane carasau, a traditional flatbread from Sardinia, is characterized by its thin, crisp, and paper-thin shape. Known as "sheet music" in Italian, this bread is typically prepared in the form of a dish about half a meter wide. The bread is made by taking a baked flatbread, made from durum wheat flour, salt, yeast, and water, and separating it into two sheets that are then baked again. This ancient recipe was designed for shepherds who were often away from home for extended periods, as pane carasau can last up to one year if kept dry. The bread can be consumed either dry or wet, with water, wine, or sauces. A similar, yeast-free bread with added seasoning is known as "dripped bread." Remains of pane carasau have been found in archaeological excavations of nuraghes, traditional Sardinian stone buildings, indicating that it was already consumed on the island before 1000 BC.

samples.original_text:
Year 346 (CCCXLVI) was a common year starting on Wednesday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar. In the Roman Empire, it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Constantius and Claudius (or, less frequently, year 1099 Ab urbe condita). The denomination 346 for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events 
 By place 
 Asia 
 In Korea, the Buyeo Kingdom is absorbed by Goguryeo.
 Geunchogo becomes king of the Korean kingdom of Baekje.

 By topic 
 Religion 
 Emperor Constans I uses his influence to secure the return of Athanasius. He is restored as Patriarch of Alexandria, and documents are compiled relating to his expulsion, under the title Apology Against the Arians.
 Macedonius I, Patriarch of Constantinople, is deposed again by Paul I.
 Julius Firmicus Maternus writes De erroribus profanarum religionum.
 The Visigoths are converted to Arianism by Wulfila.

Births 
 Zhang Tianxi, Chinese ruler of Former Liang (d. 406)

Deaths 
 He Chong (or Cidao), Chinese politician (b. 292)
 Maximin of Trier, German bishop (approximate date)
 Zhang Jun (or Gongting), Chinese prince (b. 307)

References

easy_general.text:
In the year 346, which was a common year in the Julian calendar, the Roman Empire knew it as the Year of the Consulship of Constantius and Claudius, or year 1099 Ab urbe condita. The number 346 has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became popular in Europe.

In Asia, specifically Korea, the Buyeo Kingdom was taken over by Goguryeo. Geunchogo became the king of Baekje, another Korean kingdom.

In the world of religion, Emperor Constans I helped Athanasius return to his position as Patriarch of Alexandria. Athanasius wrote a book about his time away, called Apology Against the Arians. Macedonius I, who was the Patriarch of Constantinople, was taken out of his position again by Paul I. A famous writer named Julius Firmicus Maternus wrote a book called De erroribus profanarum religionum. The Visigoths, a group of people, were converted to a religion called Arianism by a man named Wulfila.

In this year, Zhang Tianxi, a Chinese ruler of Former Liang, was born. He lived until 406. He Chong, a Chinese politician, died. He was born in 292. Maximin of Trier, a German bishop, also died around this time, and Zhang Jun, a Chinese prince, born in 307, passed away.

The number 346 has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the standard in Europe for naming years.

In Asia, particularly in Korea, the Buyeo Kingdom was absorbed by Goguryeo, and Geunchogo became the king of Baekje.

In the realm of religion, Emperor Constans I secured the return of Athanasius, who was then restored as the Patriarch of Alexandria. Documents were compiled to explain his expulsion, known as "Apology Against the Arians." Macedonius I, the Patriarch of Constantinople, was deposed again by Paul I. Julius Firmicus Maternus wrote a book called "De erroribus profanarum religionum," which discussed the errors of other religions. The Visigoths were converted to Arianism by Wulfila.

During this year, Zhang Tianxi, a Chinese ruler of Former Liang, was born. He lived until 406. He Chong, a Chinese politician, died, and Maximin of Trier, a German bishop, passed away. Zhang Jun, a Chinese prince, was born.

samples.title: Tetonia, Idaho
samples.original_text:
Tetonia is a city in Teton County, Idaho, United States, about  northeast of Idaho Falls, Idaho (center to center) and about  northwest of Denver, Colorado. The population was 269 at the 2010 census.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the city has a total area of , all land.
Tetonia is located at 43°48′50″N 111°9′35″W, in Teton County Idaho.

History
Tetonia was established as an agricultural town in the late 19th century, taking its name from the nearby Teton Range. Many of the businesses previously operating in Haden relocated to Tetonia following the arrival of the Union Pacific railroad.

Demographics

2010 census
As of the census of 2010, there were 269 people, 95 households, and 62 families residing in the city. The population density was . There were 122 housing units at an average density of . The racial makeup of the city was 92.2% White, 0.7% Native American, 6.3% from other races, and 0.7% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 10.8% of the population.

There were 95 households, of which 46.3% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 49.5% were married couples living together, 11.6% had a female householder with no husband present, 4.2% had a male householder with no wife present, and 34.7% were non-families. 28.4% of all households were made up of individuals, and 10.5% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.83 and the average family size was 3.61.

The median age in the city was 35.1 years. 36.1% of residents were under the age of 18; 5.1% were between the ages of 18 and 24; 26.7% were from 25 to 44; 24.5% were from 45 to 64; and 7.4% were 65 years of age or older. The gender makeup of the city was 48.7% male and 51.3% female.

Tetonia was founded as an agricultural town in the late 19th century. It got its name from the nearby Teton Range, which is a group of mountains. Many businesses that were previously located in Haden, a town that is no longer there, moved to Tetonia after the arrival of the Union Pacific railroad.

2010 census

samples.original_text:
Hubley Township is a township in Schuylkill County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 854 at the 2010 census, a drop of less than 1% from the previous census in 2000.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , all of it land.

Demographics

At the 2000 census there were 889 people, 345 households, and 260 families living in the township.  The population density was 68.0 people per square mile (26.2/km).  There were 369 housing units at an average density of 28.2/sq mi (10.9/km).  The racial makeup of the township was 99.21% White, 0.22% African American, 0.11% Asian, 0.22% Pacific Islander, 0.11% from other races, and 0.11% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 1.12%.

Of the 345 households 29.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 66.7% were married couples living together, 5.8% had a female householder with no husband present, and 24.6% were non-families. 21.2% of households were one person and 11.9% were one person aged 65 or older.  The average household size was 2.58 and the average family size was 2.98.

The age distribution was 21.7% under the age of 18, 6.7% from 18 to 24, 28.3% from 25 to 44, 23.3% from 45 to 64, and 19.9% 65 or older.  The median age was 41 years. For every 100 females, there were 107.7 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 102.3 males.

The median household income was $41,250 and the median family income  was $46,538. Males had a median income of $32,734 versus $24,375 for females. The per capita income for the township was $17,377.  About 4.2% of families and 5.7% of the population were below the poverty line, including 4.6% of those under age 18 and 7.9% of those age 65 or over.

samples.title: Kebechet
samples.original_text:
In Egyptian mythology, Kebechet (spelt in hieroglyphs as Qeb-Hwt, and also transliterated as Khebhut, Kebehut, Qébéhout, Kabehchet and Kebehwet) is a goddess, a deification of embalming liquid. Her name means cooling water.

Myths
Kebechet is a daughter of Anubis and his wife Anput. In the Pyramid Texts, Kebechet is referred to as a serpent who "refreshes and purifies" the pharaoh.

Kebechet was thought to give water to the spirits of the dead while they waited for the mummification process to be complete. She was probably related to mummification where she would fortify the body against corruption, so it would stay fresh for reanimation by the deceased's ka.

References

Egyptian death goddesses

Kebechet was believed to give water to the spirits of the dead while they waited for the mummification process to be complete. She was probably related to mummification because she helped protect the body from corruption, so it would stay fresh for reanimation by the deceased's ka.

Kebechet was also thought to give water to the spirits of the dead while they waited for the mummification process to be complete. She may have been involved in the mummification process, helping protect the body against corruption, so it would stay fresh for reanimation by the deceased's ka, which was a part of the soul that was believed to return to the body after death.

samples.title: Oostburg
samples.original_text:
Oostburg (Zeelandic Flemish: Wòstburg) is a town in the south-western Netherlands. It is the largest town in the municipality of Sluis, in the province of Zeeland. As of 1 January 2015, its population is 4731, down from 5008 in January 2005. It received city rights in 1237. Before 1 January 2003, Oostburg was also the name of a municipality. It merged with Sluis-Aardenburg to form the new municipality of Sluis. The municipality covered an area of 224.93 km², of which 1.05 km² was water. As well as the town of Oostburg, the former municipality also included the following towns, villages and townships:
Breskens
Cadzand
Groede
Hoofdplaat
IJzendijke
Nieuwvliet
Schoondijke
Waterlandkerkje
Zuidzande

Oostburg is typically a tourist town very close to the beaches at Cadzand. Every Wednesday is market day all year round but in the summer the town is busy and has many fun events.

The unicorn
Oostburg's symbol is the unicorn, from which the townsfolk are said to derive strength and courage. In reality, the unicorn's presence is represented by a sculpture produced by the sculptress Liesbeth Messer-Heijbroek who for many years, with her husband, lived in the area: she evidently took inspiration from the name of a former inn. The sculpture has been repositioned at least once since it first appeared in 1952 during the postwar reconstruction: at one stage it adorned a small car park. Currently it shares with a modern fountain a spot in "Eenhoornplantsoen" (Unicorn Place) beyond the northern end of the old market square in the town centre.

WW2 Monument
During the Second World War approximately 140 Oostburg townsfolk died and most of all the buildings, shops and churches were destroyed. This monument is a tribute to them and the rebuilding of the town. Around the lower part of the monument are the names of those who perished.

Before 2003, Oostburg was also a separate area called a municipality. It joined with another area called Sluis-Aardenburg to form a new area called Sluis, which covered 224.93 square kilometers. The sculpture has been moved at least once since it was first put up in 1952. At one point, it was in a small car park, but now it's shared with a modern fountain in the Unicorn Place in the town center.

samples.title: Leaf River Township, Wadena County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Leaf River Township is a township in Wadena County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 515 at the 2000 census.

Leaf River Township was named after the Leaf River.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , all of it land.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 515 people, 174 households, and 135 families residing in the township.  The population density was 14.6 people per square mile (5.7/km2).  There were 196 housing units at an average density of 5.6/sq mi (2.2/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 94.37% White, 2.14% African American, 1.75% Native American, 0.58% Asian, 0.19% Pacific Islander, and 0.97% from two or more races.

There were 174 households, out of which 31.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 75.9% were married couples living together, 0.6% had a female householder with no husband present, and 22.4% were non-families. 21.8% of all households were made up of individuals, and 10.3% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.68 and the average family size was 3.16.

In the township the population was spread out, with 26.2% under the age of 18, 3.9% from 18 to 24, 23.9% from 25 to 44, 33.6% from 45 to 64, and 12.4% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 43 years. For every 100 females, there were 138.4 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 130.3 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $37,292, and the median income for a family was $46,750. Males had a median income of $32,411 versus $20,795 for females. The per capita income for the township was $14,681.  About 6.5% of families and 19.3% of the population were below the poverty line, including 11.1% of those under age 18 and 28.0% of those age 65 or over.

samples.title: Haddocks' Eyes
samples.original_text:
"Haddocks' Eyes" is a term for the name of a song sung by The White Knight from Lewis Carroll's  1871 novel Through the Looking-Glass, chapter VIII.

"Haddocks' Eyes" is an example used to elaborate on the symbolic status of the concept of "name": a name as identification marker may be assigned to anything, including another name, thus introducing different levels of symbolization. It has been discussed in several works on logic and philosophy.

Naming

The White Knight explains to Alice a confusing nomenclature for the song.

To summarize:

The song's name is called Haddocks' Eyes
The song's name is The Aged Aged Man
The song is called Ways and Means
The song is A-sitting on a Gate

The complicated terminology distinguishing between 'the song, what the song is called, the name of the song, and what the name of the song is called' both uses and mentions the use–mention distinction.

The song

The White Knight sings the song to a tune he claims as his own invention, but which Alice recognises as "I give thee all, I can no more". By the time Alice heard it, she was already tired of poetry.

The song parodies the plot, but not the style or metre, of "Resolution and Independence" by William Wordsworth.

Upon the Lonely Moor

Like "Jabberwocky," another poem published in Through the Looking Glass, "Haddocks’ Eyes" appears to have been revised over the course of many years. In 1856, Carroll published the following poem anonymously under the name Upon the Lonely Moor. It bears an obvious resemblance to "Haddocks' Eyes."

See also

Nonsense verse

References

British poems
1871 poems
Alice's Adventures in Wonderland
Nonsense poetry
Parodies of literature

adult_non_technical.text:
"Haddocks' Eyes" is the name of a song sung by the White Knight in Lewis Carroll's 1871 novel, Through the Looking-Glass. This song is used to explain a concept in logic and philosophy called the "use–mention distinction." This concept means that a name can be used to identify something, but it can also be used to identify another name, leading to different levels of meaning.

The White Knight gives Alice a confusing explanation of the song's name:

The song's name is called Haddocks' Eyes.
The song's name is The Aged Aged Man.
The song is called Ways and Means.
The song is A-sitting on a Gate.

This explanation shows the difference between "the song," "what the song is called," "the name of the song," and "what the name of the song is called." 

The White Knight then sings the song to a tune he claims is his own, but Alice recognizes as "I give thee all, I can no more." Alice is tired of poetry by this time, so the song doesn't appeal to her.

The song parodies the plot of "Resolution and Independence" by William Wordsworth, but not the style or meter.

samples.title: Eunomia (disambiguation)
samples.original_text:
Eunomia is one of the Horae, goddesses of Greek mythology. Eunomia may also refer to:

 Eunomia (moth), a moth genus
 The Eunomia family of asteroids (named after the goddess)
15 Eunomia, the largest asteroid in that family
 Eunomia (plant), a genus of plants in the family Brassicaceae
 A fictional computer in SoltyRei; see List of SoltyRei characters#Eunomia

See also 
 Callicore eunomia, a nymphalid butterfly species 
 Boloria eunomia (formerly Proclossiana eunomia eunomia), scientific names for the bog fritillary butterfly

easy_general.text:

- A type of moth called Eunomia
- A group of asteroids called the Eunomia family
- The biggest asteroid in that group, called 15 Eunomia
- A type of plant called Eunomia
- A fictional computer in a story called SoltyRei

There are also some butterflies named Eunomia, like the Callicore eunomia and the Boloria eunomia.

adult_non_technical.text: Eunomia is a goddess from Greek mythology who represents order and harmony. Her name is also used for a moth, an asteroid family, a plant, and a fictional computer in a video game.

adult_technical.text: Eunomia, a goddess of Greek mythology, is one of the Horae, goddesses of order and law. The name Eunomia is also associated with several other entities, including a moth genus, a family of asteroids named after the goddess, the largest asteroid in that family, a genus of plants in the mustard family (Brassicaceae), and a fictional computer in the SoltyRei series. Additionally, Eunomia is linked to a nymphalid butterfly species and the scientific names for the bog fritillary butterfly.

The year 661 BC was a year of the pre-Julian Roman calendar. In the Roman Empire, it was known as year 93 Ab urbe condita . The denomination 661 BC for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events
 Queen Macha of Ireland begins to rule alone, after the death of her husband Cimbaeth.

samples.title: Holland Township, Kandiyohi County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Holland Township is a township in Kandiyohi County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 369 at the 2000 census.

Holland Township was organized in 1888. A large share of the early settlers being natives of Holland caused the name to be selected.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , of which  of  land and 0.03% is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 369 people, 120 households, and 102 families residing in the township.  The population density was 10.4 people per square mile (4.0/km2).  There were 122 housing units at an average density of 3.5/sq mi (1.3/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 98.37% White, 0.27% African American, 1.08% from other races, and 0.27% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 1.08% of the population.

There were 120 households, out of which 47.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 84.2% were married couples living together, and 15.0% were non-families. 11.7% of all households were made up of individuals, and 1.7% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 3.08 and the average family size was 3.40.

In the township the population was spread out, with 33.9% under the age of 18, 3.8% from 18 to 24, 30.4% from 25 to 44, 22.8% from 45 to 64, and 9.2% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 34 years. For every 100 females, there were 105.0 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 114.0 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $45,313, and the median income for a family was $46,875. Males had a median income of $30,750 versus $19,107 for females. The per capita income for the township was $16,243.  About 7.1% of families and 7.0% of the population were below the poverty line, including 7.6% of those under age 18 and none of those age 65 or over.

References

Townships in Kandiyohi County, Minnesota
Townships in Minnesota

samples.title: SI derived unit
samples.original_text:
SI derived units are units of measurement derived from the
seven base units specified by the International System of Units (SI). They are either dimensionless or can be expressed as a product of one or more of the base units, possibly scaled by an appropriate power of exponentiation. 

The SI has special names for 22 of these derived units (for example, hertz, the SI unit of measurement of frequency), but the rest merely reflect their derivation: for example, the square metre (m2), the SI derived unit of area; and the kilogram per cubic metre (kg/m3 or kg⋅m−3), the SI derived unit of density. 

The names of SI derived units, when written in full, are always in lowercase. However, the symbols for units named after persons are written with an uppercase initial letter. For example, the symbol for hertz is "Hz", but the symbol for metre is "m".

Derived units with special names
The International System of Units assigns special names to 22 derived units, which includes two dimensionless derived units, the radian (rad) and the steradian (sr).

Examples of derived quantities and units

Other units used with SI
Some other units such as the hour, litre, tonne, bar, and electronvolt are not SI units, but are widely used in conjunction with SI units.

Supplementary units
Until 1995, the SI classified the radian and the steradian as supplementary units, but this designation was abandoned and the units were grouped as derived units.

See also
 International System of Quantities (ISQ)
 International Vocabulary of Metrology
 Metric prefix
 Metric system

References

Bibliography

External links

Derived
