samples.title: 266 BC
samples.original_text:
Year 266 BC was a year of the pre-Julian Roman calendar. At the time it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Pera and Pictor (or, less frequently, year 488 Ab urbe condita). The denomination 266 BC for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events 
 By place 

 Roman Republic 
 January 23 – Marcus Atilius Regulus and Lucius Julius Libo celebrate triumphs over the Salentini.
 Calabria and Messapia are annexed by the Roman Republic.

 Asia Minor 
 Ariobarzanes becomes the second king of Pontus, succeeding his father Mithridates I Ctistes.

 India 
 The Mauryan emperor Ashoka converts to Buddhism.

Births 
 Berenice II, queen and co-regent of Egypt (or 267 BC)

Deaths 
 Huiwen of Zhao, Chinese king of Zhao (b. 310 BC)
 Mithridates I Ctistes, founder of the kingdom of Pontus

References

easy_general.text: In the year 266 BC, many things happened around the world. In Rome, two leaders celebrated their victory over a group of people called the Salentini. Rome also took over two places called Calabria and Messapia. In Asia Minor, a new king named Ariobarzanes took over the kingdom of Pontus. In India, a king named Ashoka became a Buddhist. Some important people were born and died that year, too.

adult_non_technical.text:
In the year 266 BC, which was a long time ago, some important things happened in Rome. Back then, this year was known as the Year of the Consulship of Pera and Pictor, or year 488 Ab urbe condita. In the Roman Republic, two important leaders, Marcus Atilius Regulus and Lucius Julius Libo, celebrated a big victory over a group of people called the Salentini. Rome also took control of two areas called Calabria and Messapia.

In Asia Minor, a new king named Ariobarzanes took over the kingdom of Pontus after his father, Mithridates I Ctistes, passed away. In India, a powerful emperor named Ashoka decided to follow a religion called Buddhism.

During this year, a new queen named Berenice II was born in Egypt. Two important people passed away: Huiwen of Zhao, a king in China, and Mithridates I Ctistes, the founder of the kingdom of Pontus.

adult_technical.text:
The year 266 BC was a significant year in the pre-Julian Roman calendar, known at the time as the Year of the Consulship of Pera and Pictor, or, less commonly, as the year 488 Ab urbe condita. The designation 266 BC has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

In the Roman Republic, notable events occurred on January 23 when Marcus Atilius Regulus and Lucius Julius Libo celebrated triumphs over the Salentini. Additionally, Calabria and Messapia were annexed by the Roman Republic, marking the expansion of Roman territory.

In Asia Minor, Ariobarzanes became the second king of Pontus, succeeding his father Mithridates I Ctistes. This marked a significant shift in the political landscape of the region.

Meanwhile, the Mauryan emperor Ashoka converted to Buddhism, signaling a significant change in the religious landscape of India.

A notable birth occurred in the form of Berenice II, queen and co-regent of Egypt, who was born in 266 BC or 267 BC.

Notable deaths in the year 266 BC include Huiwen of Zhao, Chinese king of Zhao, who was born in 310 BC, and Mithridates I Ctistes, founder of the kingdom of Pontus.

References

samples.title: Kilo Ali
samples.original_text:
Andrell D. Rogers (born May 1, 1973), better known as Kilo Ali, formerly Kilo, is an American rapper from Atlanta, Georgia. Kilo Ali recorded mainly bass music (described more closely to Miami bass style music), but also hip-hop tracks with a less distinctive Southern flavor. His most well known singles include "Show Me Love", "Baby Baby", and "Love In Ya Mouth".

As Kilo Ali, he released Organized Bass in 1997 on Interscope, with featured artists including George Clinton, Cee-Lo of Goodie Mob, Big Boi of OutKast, and JT Money. In 2011, Ali was released from prison after serving six years of a 15-year sentence for arson. In June 2021, Ali sued rapper NLE Choppa for copyright infringement for unauthorized use of his 1997 song, "Love In Ya Mouth".

as Kilo Ali

In 1997, he released an album called "Organized Bass" on Interscope Records. This album featured other famous artists like George Clinton, Cee-Lo of Goodie Mob, Big Boi of OutKast, and JT Money.

In 2011, Ali was released from prison after serving six years of a 15-year sentence for arson. In 2021, he sued another rapper, NLE Choppa, for using one of his 1997 songs, "Love In Ya Mouth," without permission.

Ali has also released several singles, including "Show Me Love," "Baby Baby," and "Love In Ya Mouth."

samples.title: Slow fire
samples.original_text:
A slow fire is a term used in library and information science to describe paper embrittlement resulting from acid decay. The term is taken from the title of Terry Sanders's 1987 film Slow Fires: On the preservation of the human record.

Solutions to this problem include the use of acid-free paper stocks, reformatting brittle books by microfilming, photocopying or digitization, and a variety of deacidification techniques.

See also
Acid-free paper
Double Fold
Wood-pulp paper
Preservation: Library and Archival Science

External links
 International Journal of Library Science 
Extinguishing slow fires: cooperative preservation efforts
 Slow fires: on the preservation of the human record
 Slow fires at IMDB

Preservation (library and archival science)

easy_general.text: Have you ever noticed how old books can become brittle and fragile? This happens because the acid in the paper breaks down over time, causing it to become weak and fragile. We call this a "slow fire." To prevent this from happening, we use acid-free paper, reformat books by microfilming, photocopying, or digitizing them, and use special techniques to remove the acid.

adult_non_technical.text: Have you ever noticed how old books can become brittle and fragile over time? This happens because of something called "acid decay," which causes the paper to become weak and break easily. To prevent this, libraries and archives use special acid-free paper, reformat old books using microfilm, photocopies, or digital copies, and use different techniques to remove the acid from the paper. This helps preserve our valuable history for future generations to enjoy.

adult_technical.text:
A slow fire is a term used in library and information science to describe the gradual degradation of paper due to acid decay. The term is derived from the title of Terry Sanders's 1987 film, "Slow Fires: On the Preservation of the Human Record."

To address this issue, various solutions are employed, including acid-free paper stocks, reformatting brittle books through microfilming, photocopying, or digitization, and employing various deacidification techniques.

See also:
Acid-free paper
Double Fold

samples.title: Speed, North Carolina
samples.original_text:
Speed is a town in Edgecombe County, North Carolina, United States. It is part of the Rocky Mount, North Carolina Metropolitan Statistical Area. The population was 80 at the 2010 census.  The town of Speed was founded by Andrew Jackson Parker Sr. It was named after the town doctor Eugene Travis Speed Sr.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the town has a total area of , all  land.

Demographics

As of the census of 2000, there were 70 people, 28 households, and 15 families residing in the town. The population density was 247.3 people per square mile (96.5/km). There were 60 housing units at an average density of 212.0 per square mile (82.7/km). The racial makeup of the town was 51.43% White, 45.71% African American, 2.86% from other races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 2.86% of the population.

There were 28 households, out of which 21.4% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 53.6% were married couples living together, and 42.9% were non-families. 42.9% of all households were made up of individuals, and 25.0% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.50 and the average family size was 3.50.

In the town, the population was spread out, with 20.0% under the age of 18, 2.9% from 18 to 24, 25.7% from 25 to 44, 30.0% from 45 to 64, and 21.4% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 47 years. For every 100 females, there were 100.0 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 107.4 males.

The median income for a household in the town was $25,938, and the median income for a family was $46,875. Males had a median income of $33,333 versus $36,250 for females. The per capita income for the town was $17,079. There were 22.2% of families and 26.9% of the population living below the poverty line, including no under eighteens and 46.2% of those over 64.

At the 2000 census, there were 885 people, 364 households and 266 families residing in the township. The population density was 41.5 per square mile (16.0/km). There were 694 housing units at an average density of 32.6/sq mi (12.6/km). The racial makeup of the township was 88.70% White, 0.90% African American, 7.57% Native American, 0.34% Asian, and 2.49% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 1.36% of the population.

There were 364 households, of which 25.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 58.8% were married couples living together, 9.1% had a female householder with no husband present, and 26.9% were non-families. 21.2% of all households were made up of individuals, and 9.6% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.43 and the average family size was 2.76.

24.6% of the population were under the age of 18, 5.4% from 18 to 24, 22.9% from 25 to 44, 28.5% from 45 to 64, and 18.5% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 44 years. For every 100 females, there were 98.0 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 102.1 males.

The median household income was $36,058 and the median family income was $42,500. Males had a median income of $35,909 compared with $19,583 for females. The per capita income was $19,742. About 7.5% of families and 10.6% of the population were below the poverty line, including 22.0% of those under age 18 and 1.9% of those age 65 or over.

samples.title: Francis Hyacinth, Duke of Savoy
samples.original_text:
Francis Hyacinth (; 14 September 1632 – 4 October 1638) was the Duke of Savoy from 1637 to 1638 under regency of his mother  Christine Marie.

Biography

Born at the Castle of Valentino in Turin he was the eldest surviving son of Victor Amadeus I, Duke of Savoy and his wife Christine Marie of France. As the heir to the Savoyard throne, he was styled as the Prince of Piedmont. His parents had another son who had died in 1628 prior to the birth of Francis Hyacinth.

At his father's death in October 1637, he succeeded and his mother took power having been claimed regent. While Duke of Savoy he also held the subsidiary titles of Marquess of Saluzzo, count of Aosta, Moriana and Nice, and claimant King of Jerusalem. The infant was nicknamed the Flower of Paradise (French: Fleur de Paradis). Having succeeded his father at such a young age, Francis Hyacinth did not rule de facto being only 5 years old. Having caught a fever, he died at the Castle of Valentino, and was succeeded by his brother Charles Emmanuel II. The infant was buried at the Sacra di San Michele in Turin.

Ancestry

easy_general.text:
Francis Hyacinth was the Duke of Savoy from 1637 to 1638. He was the eldest son of Victor Amadeus I, Duke of Savoy, and his wife, Christine Marie of France. He was born at the Castle of Valentino in Turin on September 14, 1632. Since he was the heir to the Savoyard throne, he was called the Prince of Piedmont. His parents had another son who died in 1628 before Francis Hyacinth was born.

When his father died in October 1637, Francis Hyacinth became the Duke of Savoy. His mother, Christine Marie, took control of the country as the regent. Francis Hyacinth also had other titles like Marquess of Saluzzo, Count of Aosta, Moriana, and Nice, and he claimed to be the King of Jerusalem. He was called the "Flower of Paradise" because he was so young and beautiful.

Since he was only 5, Francis Hyacinth didn't really rule the country. He died from a fever at the Castle of Valentino on October 4, 1638. His brother, Charles Emmanuel II, became the Duke after Francis Hyacinth died. Francis Hyacinth was buried at the Sacra di San Michele in Turin.

Francis Hyacinth's family tree

adult_non_technical.text:
Francis Hyacinth was the Duke of Savoy from 1637 to 1638, and he was helped by his mother, Christine Marie, who was in charge of the kingdom. He was born in 1632 in Turin, the oldest surviving son of Victor Amadeus I, Duke of Savoy, and his wife, Christine Marie of France. Since he was the next in line to become the Duke, he was called the Prince of Piedmont. His parents had another son who died in 1628, so Francis Hyacinth was the first choice to inherit the throne.

When his father died in 1637, Francis Hyacinth became the Duke, and his mother took control of the kingdom. She was known as the regent. As the Duke, Francis Hyacinth also held other titles like Marquess of Saluzzo, Count of Aosta, Moriana, and Nice. He was also known as the "King of Jerusalem" because he claimed to be the ruler of that land. Francis Hyacinth was nicknamed the "Flower of Paradise" because he was so young and beautiful.

Even though he was the Duke, Francis Hyacinth didn't rule the kingdom because he was only 5 years old. He died from a fever at the Castle of Valentino, and his brother, Charles Emmanuel II, took over as Duke. Francis Hyacinth was buried at the Sacra di San Michele in Turin.

adult_technical.text:
Francis Hyacinth, Duke of Savoy (14 September 1632 – 4 October 1638), was the eldest surviving son of Victor Amadeus I, Duke of Savoy, and his wife, Christine Marie of France. Born at the Castle of Valentino in Turin, he was styled as the Prince of Piedmont, the heir to the Savoyard throne. His parents had another son who had died in 1628, making Francis Hyacinth the eldest surviving son.

Upon the death of his father in October 1637, the throne passed to Francis Hyacinth, and his mother, Christine Marie, assumed the regency. As Duke of Savoy, he also held the subsidiary titles of Marquess of Saluzzo, Count of Aosta, Moriana, and Nice, and was a claimant King of Jerusalem. He was known by the nickname "Flower of Paradise" (French: Fleur de Paradis).

Despite his young age, Francis Hyacinth did not rule de facto, as he was only five years old. He died from a fever at the Castle of Valentino and was succeeded by his brother, Charles Emmanuel II. Francis Hyacinth was buried at the Sacra di San Michele monastic complex in Turin.

samples.title: Abel-mizraim
samples.original_text:
Abel-mizraim (, ’Āḇêl-Mitsrayim,; the "meadow of Egypt", or "mourning of Egypt") is a place "beyond," or east, of the Jordan river, at the "threshing-floor of Atad." Here Joseph and his 11 brothers (representing the future 12 tribes of Israel) and the Egyptians mourned seven days for Jacob (Genesis ). Its exact site is unknown.

The name Abel-mizraim is only mentioned once in the Hebrew Bible.

Notes

Attribution

Torah places

easy_general.text:
There's a place called Abel-mizraim, which means "meadow of Egypt" or "mourning of Egypt." It's located east the Jordan river, at a place called the "threshing-floor of Atad." Joseph and his 11 brothers, who represent the future 12 tribes of Israel, and the Egyptians mourned seven days for Jacob there. The exact location of Abel-mizraim is not known.

The name Abel-mizraim is only mentioned once in the Hebrew Bible.

The name Abel-mizraim is only mentioned once in the Hebrew Bible.

adult_technical.text: Abel-mizraim, also known as the "meadow of Egypt" or "mourning of Egypt," is a site located east of the Jordan River, specifically at the threshing-floor of Atad. At this location, Joseph and his 11 brothers, representing the future 12 tribes of Israel, and the Egyptians mourned seven days for Jacob. The exact site of Abel-mizraim remains unknown, and its name is only mentioned once in the Hebrew Bible.

samples.title: Chicago school
samples.original_text:
Chicago school may refer to:
 Chicago school (architecture)
 Chicago school (economics)
 Chicago school (literary criticism)
 Chicago school (mathematical analysis)
 Chicago school (sociology)
 Chicago School of Professional Psychology

easy_general.text:
The term "Chicago school" can refer to several different things:

1. In architecture, it's a style of building design that started in Chicago. Think of it as a unique way of building houses that became popular in the city.
2. In economics, it's a way of thinking about money and markets that started in Chicago. It's like a set of ideas about how economies work.
3. In literary criticism, it's a way of studying and understanding literature that started in Chicago. It's like a set of rules for analyzing books.
4. In mathematical analysis, it's a way of doing math that started in Chicago. It's like a set of methods for solving math problems.
5. In sociology, it's a way of studying society that started in Chicago. It's like a set of ideas about how people interact with each other.
6. The Chicago School of Professional Psychology is a school that teaches people how to become psychologists.

adult_non_technical.text:
The term "Chicago school" can refer to several different things:

1. Chicago School: This is a style of architecture that originated in Chicago. It is characterized by its clean lines, simple designs, and use of modern materials in building skyscrapers and office buildings.

2. Chicago School: This refers to a school of economics that developed in Chicago. It is known for its theoretical and mathematical approach to economics.

3. Chicago School of Literary Criticism: This is a way of analyzing literature that developed in Chicago. It focuses on the context and history of literary works.

4. Chicago School of Mathematical Analysis: This is a branch of mathematics that developed in Chicago. It focuses on analysis and calculus.

5. Chicago School of Sociology: This is a school of sociology that emphasizes the study of groups and communities.

6. Chicago School of Professional Psychology: This is a school of psychology that focuses on clinical and counseling psychology.

adult_technical.text:
The term "Chicago school" can refer to several distinct entities, each with its own unique characteristics and contributions to its respective field. Here are the various interpretations:

1. Chicago School (architecture): This refers to the architectural movement that emerged in the late 19th century, characterized by its innovative use of steel and glass in building design. This style laid the foundation for modern skyscrapers and had a significant impact on the development of urban landscapes.

2. Chicago School (economics): The "Chicago School" in economics refers to a group of economists associated with the University of Chicago, who emphasized the role of market forces in economic systems. This approach is known for its focus on efficiency, competition, and individual freedom.

3. Chicago School (literary criticism): In literary criticism, the "Chicago School" refers to a group of scholars who focused on literary history and the study of literary genres. This approach emphasized the importance of context and history in understanding literary works.

4. Chicago School (mathematical analysis): This refers to a group of mathematicians associated with the University of Chicago, who made significant contributions to the field of mathematical analysis.

5. Chicago School (sociology): In sociology, the "Chicago School" refers to a group of sociologists associated with the University of Chicago, who emphasized the importance of social interaction and group dynamics in shaping human behavior.

6. Chicago School of Professional Psychology: This refers to a group of psychologists associated with the University of Chicago, who made significant contributions to the field of psychology, particularly in the areas of clinical and experimental psychology.

samples.title: John II, Duke of Brabant
samples.original_text:
John II (27 September 1275 – 27 October 1312), also called John the Peaceful, was Duke of Brabant, Lothier and Limburg (1294–1312). He was the son of John I of Brabant and Margaret of Flanders.

John II succeeded his father in 1294 During the reign of John II, Brabant continued supporting a coalition to stop French expansion. He tried to conquer South Holland (district of medieval Holland) from the pro-French Count John II of Holland, but was not successful.

In 1309, the Crusade of the Poor besieged the castle of Genappe in Brabant because it was sheltering Jews. John sent an army that defeated the crusaders, who incurred heavy losses.

John, who suffered from kidney stones and wanted his duchy to be peacefully handed over to his son upon his death, in 1312 signed the famous Charter of Kortenberg. John died in Tervuren in 1312. He was buried in the St. Michael and Gudula Cathedral in Brussels.

Family
On 8 July 1290, John married Margaret of England in Westminster Abbey, London. She was a daughter of King Edward I of England and his first wife, Eleanor of Castile. Only one child was born out of this marriage:
 John III, Duke of Brabant.

John II had several illegitimate children:
 Jan van Corsselaer, was later named Lord of Witthem, Wailwilre, Machelen, la Rochette and Colonster.
 Jan van Wyvliet. Lord of Blaesveld and Kuyc. Married to Margaret Pipenpoy.
 Jan Cordeken: Founder of the House of Glymes. He was legitimized by the emperor Louis IV by charter dated of 27 August 1344, lists John II as the father and Elisabeth Gortygin as his mother.
 Jan Magermann. Married to Adelise d'Elsies.
 Jan II van Dongelberg (- 1383). His mother was Marguerite van Pamel.

References

Sources

16

John II, also known as John the Peaceful, was the Duke of Brabant, Lothier, and Limburg from 1294 to 1312. He was the son of John I of Brabant and Margaret of Flanders.

John II took over from his father in 1294. During his rule, Brabant continued to support a group of countries trying to stop France from expanding its territory. He tried to take over South Holland, a part of medieval Holland, from the pro-French Count John II of Holland, but wasn't successful.

In 1309, a group of people called the Crusade of the Poor attacked a castle in Brabant because it was hiding Jews. John II sent an army to stop them, and they suffered heavy losses.

John II had a problem with kidney stones and wanted to make sure his son could take over the duchy peacefully. In 1312, he signed a special document called the Charter of Kortenberg. He died in Tervuren in 1312 and was buried in the St. Michael and Gudula Cathedral in Brussels.

Family
On July 8, 1290, John II married Margaret of England in Westminster Abbey, London. She was the daughter of King Edward I of England and his first wife, Eleanor of Castile. They had one son:
 John III, Duke of Brabant.

John II also had several children who were not from his official marriage:
 Jan van Corsselaer, who became the Lord of Witthem, Wailwilre, Machelen, la Rochette, and Colonster.
 Jan van Wyvliet, who was the Lord of Blaesveld and Kuyc and married Margaret Pipenpoy.
 Jan Cordeken, who founded the House of Glymes and was legitimized by Emperor Louis IV.

samples.title: Bindarri National Park
samples.original_text:
Bindarri National Park is a national park in New South Wales, Australia, 431 km northeast of Sydney.

It is considered the epicenter of biodiversity, due to the rare and endangered species found here, such as fish bone fern, southern quassia and palm orchid.

One of the natural beauties of this park is the mouth of the river Urumbilum, which, descending through the Great Escarpment, carved through spectacular waterfalls.

See also
 Protected areas of New South Wales

References

External links
 Official Site

National parks of New South Wales
Protected areas established in 1999
1999 establishments in Australia

easy_general.text:
Bindarri National Park is a special place in New South Wales, Australia, about 431 kilometers northeast of Sydney. It's home to a lot of rare and endangered plants and animals, like the fish bone fern, southern quassia, and palm orchid. This makes it a very important place for biodiversity.

One of the amazing things about this park is the mouth of the Urumbilum River, which flows down the Great Escarpment and creates beautiful waterfalls. It's like having a natural wonderland right there!

If you want to learn more about other protected areas in New South Wales, you can check out the list of protected areas in the state. You can also find information about national parks in New South Wales and protected areas that were established in 1999.

adult_non_technical.text: Bindarri National Park is a special place in New South Wales, Australia, about 431 kilometers northeast of Sydney. It's known for having a lot of rare and endangered plants and animals, like the fish bone fern, southern quassia, and palm orchid. One of the most beautiful parts of the park is the mouth of the Urumbilum River, which flows down the Great Escarpment and creates stunning waterfalls.

adult_technical.text:
Bindarri National Park, located in New South Wales, Australia, approximately 431 kilometers northeast of Sydney, is recognized as a significant biodiversity hotspot. The park is home to numerous rare and endangered species, including the fish bone fern, southern quassia, and palm orchid.

One of the park's notable natural features is the mouth of the Urumbilum River, which descends through the Great Escarpment, creating stunning waterfalls.

samples.title: Cubomania
samples.original_text:
Cubomania is a surrealist method of making collages in which a picture or image is cut into squares and the squares are then reassembled without regard for the original image, either automatically "or at random." The word can also mean the collage made using this method, a "rearrangement... suffic[ing] to create an entirely new work."  The technique was invented by the Romanian surrealist Gherasim Luca. It has been described as a "statistical method".  Robert Hirsch has seemed to imply that this process can be done with digital photography. Although seemingly a contradiction in terms, at least one cubomania has been made with triangular shapes, rather than rectangles.

Penelope Rosemont and Joseph Jablonski have suggested that cubomania, with other surrealist methods, can "subvert the enslaving 'message' of advertising and to free images from repressive contexts."

Using cubomania as a method for arranging soundscapes has been suggested.

Other meanings
"Cubomania" can also mean "love of cubes", or, specifically, Rubik's Cube.

See also
Cut-up technique
Surautomatism

References

External links
Bill McKeeman Proposed Glossary

Surrealism

easy_general.text: Cubomania is a way of making collages by cutting a picture into squares and then rearranging them in a new way. This method was invented by a Romanian surrealist named Gherasim Luca. It can also be done with digital photos. Some people have even used cubomania to make music.

adult_non_technical.text: Cubomania is a surrealist art technique that involves cutting a picture or image into squares and then reassembling them in a new way, without considering the original image. This method can create entirely new and unexpected works.

adult_technical.text:
Cubomania is a surrealist method of creating collages by cutting a picture or image into squares and reassembling them without regard for the original image, either automatically or at random. The term can also refer to the collage made using this method, which can create an entirely new work by rearranging the squares. The technique was invented by the Romanian surrealist Gherasim Luca and has been described as a statistical method. Robert Hirsch has suggested that this process can be done with digital photography. Although seemingly a contradiction in terms, at least one cubomania has been made with triangular shapes, rather than rectangles.

Penelope Rosemont and Joseph Jablonski have suggested that cubomania, with other surrealist methods, can subvert the enslaving 'message' of advertising and free images from repressive contexts. Using cubomania as a method for arranging soundscapes has also been suggested.

Other meanings
"Cubomania" can also mean "love of cubes", or, specifically, Rubik's Cube.

samples.title: Endeavour River National Park
samples.original_text:
Endeavour River National Park is a national park in Queensland, Australia, gazetted to protect and preserve some of the natural and cultural resources in and around the mouth of the Endeavour River, immediately north of the small town of Cooktown. The park is located  northwest of Brisbane.

Naturalists Joseph Banks and Daniel Solander collected specimens of local 'Australian' flora in 1770 from this area which were taken back to the Royal Botanic Gardens in England. Sydney Parkinson first illustrated local Australian Aboriginal people encountered nearby, plus flora collected and fauna seen; and kangaroos were first given their modern English name (borrowing from the local Guugu Yimithirr language).

HM Bark Endeavour, under the command of Lieutenant James Cook, had struck reefs and been pulled ashore for repairs along the river locally known within Guugu Yimithirr as Wabalumbaal, possibly near the present site of Cooktown. The river was renamed on James Cook's charts as the Endeavour River, after Endeavour, and the current National Park appears, in turn, to be named after the river.

The present National Park contains coastal dunes, freshwater wetlands, mangrove forests, heathlands, tropical woodlands and the estuary plus parts of the Endeavour River catchment. It is mostly accessible by boat only, and still contains flora and fauna species of the kind collected and illustrated back in 1770.

See also

 Captain Cook mythology: Australia
 Protected areas of Queensland

References

External links
 Map showing area and location of Endeavour River National Park near Cooktown

National parks of Far North Queensland
Protected areas established in 1975
1975 establishments in Australia

easy_general.text:
Endeavour River National Park is a national park in Queensland, Australia. It was set up to protect the natural and cultural things around the Endeavour River, which is near the small town of Cooktown. The park is located far north of Brisbane.

In 1770, two scientists named Joseph Banks and Daniel Solander collected plants from this area and took them back to England. They also drew pictures of the local Aboriginal people, the plants, and the animals they saw. This is when the first English name was given to kangaroos, taken from the local Aboriginal language.

A British ship called the HM Bark Endeavour, led by Lieutenant James Cook, hit some reefs and had to make repairs near the river. The river was originally called Wabalumbaal by the local people, but James Cook renamed it the Endeavour River. Now, the park is named after the river.

The park has different types of land, like coastal dunes, freshwater wetlands, mangrove forests, heathlands, tropical woodlands, and the estuary. You can only visit the park by boat, and it still has the plants and animals that Banks and Solander collected in 1770.

For more information about Captain Cook mythology in Australia and protected areas in Queensland, you can check out the links below.

adult_non_technical.text:
Endeavour River National Park is a protected area in Queensland, Australia, created to preserve the natural and cultural resources around the Endeavour River. The park is located near the small town of Cooktown, which is about northwest of Brisbane.

In the year 1770, naturalists Joseph Banks and Daniel Solander collected samples of Australian plants from this area and brought them back to England. Sydney Parkinson was the first person to draw pictures of the local Aboriginal people, the plants, and the animals they saw. He also gave kangaroos their modern English name, which comes from the local Guugu Yimithirr language.

Lieutenant James Cook's ship, the HM Bark Endeavour, was damaged by reefs and had to be repaired on the river. The river was named the Endeavour River after the ship, and the park is named after the river.

Today, the park includes coastal dunes, freshwater wetlands, mangrove forests, heathlands, tropical woodlands, and the estuary. It is mostly only accessible by boat, and it still has many of the same types of plants and animals that were collected and drawn back in 1770.

For more information, you can read about Captain Cook's mythology in Australia and the protected areas of Queensland. You can also find a map of the park's location and other links about the park and its history.

adult_technical.text:
Endeavour River National Park, situated in Queensland, Australia, is a protected area established to safeguard the natural and cultural resources surrounding the Endeavour River's mouth, immediately north of the town of Cooktown. The park is located northwest of Brisbane.

In 1770, naturalists Joseph Banks and Daniel Solander gathered specimens of local 'Australian' flora from this region, which were subsequently transported to the Royal Botanic Gardens in England. Sydney Parkinson was the first to depict local Australian Aboriginal people, flora, and fauna encountered in the area. Kangaroos were also given their modern English name, derived from the local Guugu Yimithirr language.

HM Bark Endeavour, under the command of Lieutenant James Cook, struck reefs and docked for repairs along the river locally known as Wabalumbaal, possibly near the present site of Cooktown. The river was subsequently renamed on Cook's charts as the Endeavour River, after the vessel. The current National Park appears to have been named after the river.

The present National Park encompasses coastal dunes, freshwater wetlands, mangrove forests, heathlands, tropical woodlands, the estuary, and parts of the Endeavour River catchment. Accessible primarily by boat, the park still contains flora and fauna species similar to those collected and illustrated in 1770.

See also: Captain Cook mythology: Australia, Protected areas of Queensland

References

External links: Map showing the area and location of Endeavour River National Park near Cooktown, National parks of Far North Queensland, Protected areas established in 1975, 1975 establishments in Australia

samples.title: Boardman, North Carolina
samples.original_text:
Boardman is a town in Columbus County, North Carolina, United States. The population was 157 at the 2010 census.

Geography
Boardman is located at  (34.439790, -78.948495).

According to the United States Census Bureau, the town has a total area of , of 
which 3.1 square miles (8.1 km2)  is land and  of it (0.64%) is water.

Demographics

As of the census of 2000, there were 202 people, 79 households, and 54 families residing in the town. The population density was 64.8 people per square mile (25.0/km2). There were 89 housing units at an average density of 28.6 per square mile (11.0/km2). The racial makeup of the town was 54.46% White, 44.55% African American, 0.99% from other races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.99% of the population.

There were 79 households, out of which 22.8% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 39.2% were married couples living together, 24.1% had a female householder with no husband present, and 30.4% were non-families. 29.1% of all households were made up of individuals, and 13.9% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.56 and the average family size was 3.15.

In the town, the population was spread out, with 23.8% under the age of 18, 9.4% from 18 to 24, 28.7% from 25 to 44, 22.3% from 45 to 64, and 15.8% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 38 years. For every 100 females, there were 69.7 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 69.2 males.

The median income for a household in the town was $20,500, and the median income for a family was $28,333. Males had a median income of $25,500 versus $20,417 for females. The per capita income for the town was $10,339. About 19.0% of families and 27.6% of the population were below the poverty line, including 45.5% of those under the age of eighteen and 28.6% of those 65 or over.

References

Towns in North Carolina
Towns in Columbus County, North Carolina

easy_general.text:
Boardman is a small town in Columbus County, North Carolina. As of 2010, there were 157 people living there.

Boardman is located at 34.439790 degrees north latitude and 78.948495 degrees west longitude. It covers an area of about 3.1 square miles (8.1 square kilometers), with a small part of it made up of water.

In 2000, there were 202 people living in Boardman. They lived in 79 households, with 54 families. The town was made up of about 54% white people, 45% African American people, and 1% people from other races. About 1% of the population was Hispanic or Latino.

Of the 79 households, 23% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 39% were married couples living together, 24% had a female householder with no husband present, and 30% were non-families. About 29% of all households were made up of individuals, and 14% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.

The average household size was 2.56 people, and the average family size was 3.15 people.

There were 24% of people under the age of 18, 9% between 18 and 24, 29% between 25 and 44, 22% between 45 and 64, and 16% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 38 years. For every 100 females, there were 70 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 69 males.

The median income for a household in the town was $20,500, and the median income for a family was $28,333. Males had a median income of $25,500, and females had a median income of $20,417. The per capita income for the town was $10,339. About 19% of families and 28% of the population were below the poverty line.

References

Towns in North Carolina

samples.title: Psophometric voltage
samples.original_text:
Psophometric voltage is a circuit noise voltage measured with a psophometer that includes a CCIF-1951 weighting network. 

"Psophometric voltage" should not be confused with "psophometric emf," i.e., the emf in a generator or line with 600 Ω internal resistance. For practical purposes, the psophometric emf is twice the corresponding psophometric voltage. 

Psophometric voltage readings, V, in millivolts, are commonly converted to dBm(psoph) by dBm(psoph) = 20 log10V – 57.78.

References

Electrical parameters
Noise (electronics)
Telecommunications engineering

easy_general.text:
Psophometric voltage is a type of noise voltage measured using a special tool called a psophometer. This tool has a part called a CCIF-1951 weighting network, which helps to measure the voltage accurately.

Psophometric voltage is not the same as psophometric emf, which is the voltage in a generator or line with a special resistance of 600 ohms. For practical purposes, the psophometric emf is twice the psophometric voltage.

To understand the psophometric voltage better, we often convert it to a unit called dBm(psoph). This is done using a simple formula: dBm(psoph) = 20 log10V - 57.78, where V is the voltage in millivolts.

References:
Electrical parameters
Noise (electronics)
Telecommunications engineering

adult_non_technical.text:
Psophometric voltage is a way of measuring noise in a circuit using a special tool called a psophometer. This tool has a part called a CCIF-1951 weighting network, which helps to measure the noise in a specific way.

Now, psophometric voltage is not the same as psophometric emf, which is the voltage produced in a generator or line with a special resistance of 600 ohms. For practical purposes, the psophometric emf is about twice the psophometric voltage.

When we measure psophometric voltage, we usually get a reading in millivolts. To understand this reading in a more useful way, we can convert it to a unit called dBm(psoph). This conversion uses a formula: dBm(psoph) = 20 log10V – 57.78, where V is the reading in millivolts.

References

Electrical parameters
Noise (electronics)
Telecommunications engineering

adult_technical.text:
Psophometric voltage is a circuit noise voltage measured using a psophometer that incorporates a CCIF-1951 weighting network. It is essential to distinguish psophometric voltage from psophometric emf, which refers to the electromotive force in a generator or line with a 600 Ω internal resistance. In practical applications, the psophometric emf is approximately twice the corresponding psophometric voltage.

Psophometric voltage readings, expressed in millivolts, are often converted to dBm(psoph) using the formula: dBm(psoph) = 20 log10V – 57.78.

References

Electrical parameters
Noise (electronics)
Telecommunications engineering

samples.title: Aristodemus
samples.original_text:
In Greek mythology, Aristodemus (Ancient Greek: Ἀριστόδημος) was one of the Heracleidae, son of Aristomachus and brother of Cresphontes and Temenus. He was a great-great-grandson of Heracles and helped lead the fifth and final attack on Mycenae in the Peloponnese.

Aristodemus and his brothers complained to the Oracle that its instructions had proved fatal to those who had followed them (the Oracle had told Hyllas to attack through the narrow passage when the third fruit was ripe). They received the answer that by the "third fruit" the "third generation" was meant, and that the "narrow passage" was not the isthmus of Corinth, but the straits of Rhium. They accordingly built a fleet at Naupactus, but before they set sail, Aristodemus was struck by lightning (or shot by Apollo) and the fleet destroyed, because one of the Heraclidae had slain an Acarnanian soothsayer.

His brothers were later able to conquer the Peloponnese.

By his wife Argia, daughter of King Autesion of Thebes, he was the father of twin Kings Eurysthenes and Procles, the ancestors of the two royal houses of Sparta.

Sources
Diodorus Siculus, iv. 57, 58.
Pausanias, i. 32, 41, ii. 13, 18, iii. I, iv. 3, v. 3.
Euripides, Heraclidae.
Pindar, Pythia, ix. 137.
Herodotus, ix. 27.
Karl Otfried Müller. Dorians, Part I, Chapter 3.
Connop Thirlwall. History of Greece, Chapter VII.
George Grote. History of Greece, Part I, Chapter XVIII.
Georg Busolt. Griechische Geschichte, Part I, Chapter 11, Section 7, where a list of authorities is given.

References

Heracleidae
Ancient Messenians

easy_general.text:
In Greek mythology, Aristodemus was a member of the Heracleidae, a group of people descended from Heracles. He was the son of Aristomachus and the brother of Cresphontes and Temenus. Aristodemus and his brothers led the fifth and final attack on Mycenae, a city in the Peloponnese.

Aristodemus and his brothers complained to the Oracle that its instructions had led to the death of those who had followed them. The Oracle had told Hyllas to attack through a narrow passage when the third fruit was ripe. The Oracle explained that the "third fruit" meant the third generation, and the "narrow passage" was not the isthmus of Corinth, but the straits of Rhium. They built a fleet at Naupactus, but before they could set sail, Aristodemus was struck by lightning or shot by Apollo, and the fleet was destroyed because one of the Heraclidae had killed an Acarnanian soothsayer.

Later, his brothers were able to conquer the Peloponnese.

With his wife Argia, daughter of King Autesion of Thebes, Aristodemus had twin sons, Eurysthenes and Procles, who became the ancestors of the two royal houses of Sparta.

adult_non_technical.text:
In Greek mythology, Aristodemus was a member of the Heracleidae, a group of people who were descended from Heracles. He was the son of Aristomachus and had two brothers, Cresphontes and Temenus. Aristodemus was part of the fifth and final attack on Mycenae, a city in the Peloponnese.

Aristodemus and his brothers complained to the Oracle because the instructions it had given them led to disaster. The Oracle had told Hyllas to attack through a narrow passage when the third fruit was ripe. The Oracle explained that the "third fruit" referred to the third generation, and the "narrow passage" was not the isthmus of Corinth, but the straits of Rhium. They decided to build a fleet at Naupactus, but before they could set sail, Aristodemus was struck by lightning or shot by Apollo, and the fleet was destroyed. This happened because one of the Heracleidae had killed an Acarnanian soothsayer.

His brothers were eventually able to conquer the Peloponnese.

Aristodemus married Argia, the daughter of King Autesion of Thebes, and they had twin sons, Eurysthenes and Procles, who became the ancestors of the two royal houses of Sparta.

Sources:

adult_technical.text:
In Greek mythology, Aristodemus was a member of the Heracleidae, a family descended from Heracles. He was the son of Aristomachus and the brother of Cresphontes and Temenus. Aristodemus played a significant role in the fifth and final attack on Mycenae in the Peloponnese.

Aristodemus and his brothers sought guidance from the Oracle regarding the fatal consequences of following its instructions. The Oracle had previously advised that Hyllas should attack through the narrow passage when the third fruit was ripe. The Oracle clarified that the "third fruit" referred to the third generation, and the "narrow passage" was not the isthmus of Corinth but the straits of Rhium. With this information, they built a fleet at Naupactus. However, before they could set sail, Aristodemus was struck by lightning or shot by Apollo, and the fleet was destroyed due to one of the Heraclidae killing an Acarnanian soothsayer.

Despite this setback, his brothers were eventually able to conquer the Peloponnese.

Through his wife, Argia, daughter of King Autesion of Thebes, Aristodemus became the father of twin kings, Eurysthenes and Procles, who were the ancestors of the two royal houses of Sparta.

Sources:
- Diodorus Siculus, iv. 57, 58.
- Pausanias, i. 32, 41, ii. 13, 18, iii. I, iv. 3, v. 3.
- Euripides, Heraclidae.
- Pindar, Pythia, ix. 137.
- Herodotus, ix. 27.
- Karl Otfried Müller. Dorians, Part I, Chapter 3.
- Connop Thirlwall. History of Greece, Chapter VII.
- George Grote. History of Greece, Part I, Chapter XVIII.
- Georg Busolt. Griechische Geschichte, Part I, Chapter 11, Section 7, where a list of authorities is given.

References:
- Heracleidae
- Ancient Messenians

samples.title: Southern Moreton Bay Islands National Park
samples.original_text:
Southern Moreton Bay Islands is a national park in Queensland, Australia, 44 km southeast of Brisbane.  It forms part of the Moreton Bay and Pumicestone Passage Important Bird Area, so identified by BirdLife International because it supports large numbers of migratory waders, or shorebirds.

See also

 Protected areas of Queensland

References

National parks of South East Queensland
Important Bird Areas of Queensland
Islands of Moreton Bay

easy_general.text:
Southern Moreton Bay Islands is a national park in Queensland, Australia, located 44 kilometers southeast of Brisbane. This park is part of a special area called the Moreton Bay and Pumicestone Passage Important Bird Area. BirdLife International chose this area because it has a lot of birds that migrate, called waders or shorebirds.

Learn more about other national parks in Queensland and islands in Moreton Bay.

adult_non_technical.text:
The Southern Moreton Bay Islands National Park is a special place in Queensland, Australia, about 44 kilometers southeast of Brisbane. It's part of a larger area called the Moreton Bay and Pumicestone Passage Important Bird Area. This area is important because it's home to a lot of birds that travel long distances, known as waders or shorebirds.

You can also learn more about other parks in Queensland and the islands of Moreton Bay.

adult_technical.text:
The Southern Moreton Bay Islands National Park is situated in Queensland, Australia, approximately 44 kilometers southeast of Brisbane. This park is part of the Moreton Bay and Pumicestone Passage Important Bird Area, designated by BirdLife International due to its significant population of migratory waders, also known as shorebirds.

See also:
- Protected areas of Queensland

References:
- National parks of South East Queensland
- Important Bird Areas of Queensland
- Islands of Moreton Bay

samples.title: Transmission level point
samples.original_text:
In telecommunication, a transmission level point (TLP) is a physical test point in an electronic circuit, typically a transmission channel, where a test signal may be inserted or measured.  Typically, various parameters, such as the power of the signal, noise, or test tones inserted are specified or measured at the TLP.

The nominal transmission level at a TLP is a function of system design and is an expression of the design gain or attenuation (loss).

Voice-channel transmission levels at test points are measured in decibel-milliwatts (dBm) at a frequency of ca. 1000 hertz. The dBm is an absolute level with respect to 1 mW. The TLP is thus characterized by the relation:

TLP = dBm — dBm0

When the nominal signal power is 0dBm at the TLP,  the test point is called a zero transmission level point, or zero-dBm TLP. In general, the term TLP is commonly used as if it were a unit, preceded by the nominal level for the test point. For example, the expression 0TLP refers to a .  At a −16TLP, the measured level of 0dBm is +16dBm0.

The level at a TLP where an end instrument, such as a telephone set, is connected is usually specified as 0dBm.

See also
 Alignment level
 Nominal level

References

Telecommunications engineering

easy_general.text:
In telecommunication, a transmission level point (TLP) is a spot in an electronic circuit where we can add or measure test signals. This helps us understand how well the circuit is working. We often measure the power of the signal, noise, or test tones at this point.

The nominal transmission level at a TLP is set by the system's design. It tells us how much the signal is boosted or weakened in the circuit.

We measure voice signal levels in decibel-milliwatts (dBm) at a frequency of 1000 hertz. dBm is a measurement compared to 1 milliwatt of power. To find the TLP, we subtract the nominal dBm level from the measured dBm level.

When the nominal signal power is 0dBm at a TLP, the TLP is called a zero transmission level point or a zero-dBm TLP. We often use the term TLP like a unit, followed by the nominal level. For example, 0TLP means a zero transmission level point. At a -16TLP, the measured level of 0dBm is +16dBm0.

The level at a TLP where a telephone set is connected is usually set to 0dBm.

See also
Alignment level
Nominal level

References
Telecommunications engineering

adult_non_technical.text:
A transmission level point (TLP) is a specific spot in an electronic circuit, like a phone line, where engineers can insert or measure test signals. This helps them understand how well the system is working and identify any issues.

The TLP is used to measure the power of the signal, noise, or test tones that pass through the circuit. It can also measure the design gain or loss of the system, which is important for ensuring everything works correctly.

To measure the power of the signal, engineers use a unit called decibel-milliwatts (dBm). This unit compares the signal to 1 milliwatt, which is a standard amount of power. The TLP is then calculated by subtracting the dBm value from a reference value called dBm0.

When the nominal signal power at the TLP is 0dBm, the point is called a zero-dBm TLP. This means that the signal power is equal to the reference value. Engineers often use the term TLP as if it were a unit, preceded by the nominal level for the test point. For example, 0TLP refers to a zero-dBm TLP.

At a -16TLP, the measured level of 0dBm is +16dBm0. This means that the signal power is 16 times stronger than the reference value.

The level at a TLP where an end instrument, such as a phone, is connected is usually specified as 0dBm. This means that the signal power is equal to the reference value.

See also:
Alignment level
Nominal level

References:
Telecommunications engineering

adult_technical.text:
In telecommunications, a transmission level point (TLP) is a specific location within an electronic circuit, typically a transmission channel, where test signals can be inserted or measured. At the TLP, various parameters such as the power of the signal, noise, or test tones can be specified or measured.

The nominal transmission level at a TLP is determined by the system design and represents the intended gain or attenuation (loss) of the system.

Voice-channel transmission levels at test points are measured in decibel-milliwatts (dBm) at a frequency of approximately 1000 hertz. The dBm is an absolute level with respect to 1 milliwatt. The TLP is characterized by the relation:

TLP = dBm - dBm0

When the nominal signal power is 0dBm at the TLP, the test point is called a zero transmission level point, or zero-dBm TLP. In general, the term TLP is used as a unit, preceded by the nominal level for the test point. For example, 0TLP refers to a zero-dBm TLP. At a -16TLP, the measured level of 0dBm is +16dBm0.

The level at a TLP where an end instrument, such as a telephone set, is connected is usually specified as 0dBm.

See also
Alignment level
Nominal level

References
Telecommunications engineering

samples.title: Treis Volakous
samples.original_text:
Treis Volakous (, "three rocks") are rocks close to the southern coast of Crete in the Libyan Sea. They fall within the administration of the municipality of Sfakia, in Chania regional unit.

See also
List of islands of Greece

Landforms of Chania (regional unit)
Uninhabited islands of Crete
Mediterranean islands
Islands of Greece

easy_general.text: Treis Volakous, which means "three rocks" in Greek, are some big rocks near the southern part of Crete, a big island in the Libyan Sea. These rocks are part of a place called Sfakia, which is in a bigger area called Chania regional unit. If you want to learn more about islands and landforms, you can check out these other topics.

adult_non_technical.text: Imagine you're on the coast of Crete, a beautiful island in the Mediterranean. Just off the southern shore, you'll find a group of rocks called Treis Volakous, which means "three rocks" in Greek. These rocks are part of an area called Sfakia, which is in a region called Chania. If you want to learn more about Crete and other islands, check out the list of islands of Greece.

adult_technical.text:
The Treis Volakous, also known as the "Three Rocks," are a group of rocky formations located near the southern coast of Crete in the Libyan Sea. These rocks are under the administrative jurisdiction of the municipality of Sfakia, situated within the Chania regional unit.

For further information, please refer to the List of Islands of Greece, Landforms of Chania (regional unit), Uninhabited Islands of Crete, Mediterranean Islands, and Islands of Greece.

samples.title: X-dimension of recorded spot
samples.original_text:
In fax systems, the X-dimension of recorded spot is the effective recorded spot dimension measured in the direction of the recorded line. The effective recorded spot dimension" is the largest center-to-center spacing between recorded spots, which gives minimum peak-to-peak variation of density of the recorded line. X-dimension of recorded spot implies that the facsimile equipment response to a constant density in the object (original) is a succession of discrete recorded spots.

References

Fax

easy_general.text: "In fax machines, the X-dimension of recorded spots is the distance between the centers of the spots along the line. This distance is the largest possible space between the spots, which helps to keep the line as even as possible.

adult_non_technical.text: When you send a fax, the X-dimension of recorded spot is like the size of the dark spots on the page, measured along the line of the document. This spot size is the distance between the centers of the spots, which shows the smallest change in the darkness of the line. In other words, the X-dimension of recorded spot shows how the fax machine captures a constant darkness on the original document as a series of small spots.

adult_technical.text:
In fax systems, the X-dimension of recorded spots refers to the effective dimension of the recorded spots measured in the direction of the recorded line. This dimension is determined by the largest center-to-center spacing between recorded spots, which ensures the minimum peak-to-peak variation of density in the recorded line. The X-dimension of recorded spots implies that the facsimile equipment responds to a constant density in the object (original) by creating a succession of discrete recorded spots.

References

Fax

samples.title: Tunneling
samples.original_text:
Tunneling or tunnelling may refer to:

 Digging tunnels (the literal meaning)
Hobby tunneling
 Quantum tunneling, the quantum-mechanical effect where a particle crosses through a classically forbidden potential energy barrier
 Tunneling (fraud), a fraud committed by a company's own management or by major shareholders
 Tunneling protocol, transmitting one computer network protocol that is encapsulated inside another network protocol

See also
 
 
 Tunnel (disambiguation)

easy_general.text: Tunneling or tunnelling can mean different things. It can refer to digging tunnels, like building a subway system or creating a tunnel as a hobby. It can also mean quantum tunneling, which is a cool science thing where particles can pass through barriers even though they shouldn't be able. Tunneling can also be a type of fraud or a way to send computer information.

adult_non_technical.text: When you hear the word "tunneling," you might think of digging a hole in the ground to create a tunnel. But did you know that "tunneling" can also refer to other things? For example, you might think of someone who likes to dig tunnels as a hobby, or a type of fraud that happens within a company.

adult_technical.text:
The term "tunneling" can refer to several distinct concepts:

1. The literal act of digging tunnels, often used in civil engineering and transportation projects.
2. The recreational activity of hobby tunneling, undertaken for personal enjoyment.
3. Quantum tunneling, a quantum-mechanical phenomenon where particles pass through classically forbidden potential energy barriers.
4. Tunneling fraud, a form of corporate fraud committed by company management or major shareholders.
5. Tunneling protocols, a method of transmitting one computer network protocol within another.

For further information, see the disambiguation page on tunnels.

samples.title: Route
samples.original_text:
Route or routes may refer to:
 Route (gridiron football), a path run by a wide receiver
 route (command), a program used to configure the routing table
 Route, County Antrim, an area in Northern Ireland
 The Route, a 2013 Ugandan film
 Routes, Seine-Maritime, a commune in Seine-Maritime, France
 Routes (video game), 2003 video game

See also 
 Acronyms and abbreviations in avionics
 Air route or airway
 GPS route, a series of one or more GPS waypoints
 Path (disambiguation)
 Rout, a disorderly retreat of military units from the field of battle
 Route number or road number
 Router (disambiguation)
 Router (woodworking)
 Routing (disambiguation)
 Routing table
 Scenic route, a thoroughfare designated as scenic based on the scenery through which it passes
 Trade route, a commonly used path for the passage of goods

easy_general.text:
A route is a path or way to get from one place to another. It can be a road, a flight path, or even a play in football. Here are some examples:

- A route in football is the path a wide receiver runs to catch a pass.
- A route command is a program that helps find the best way to send information.
- Route, County Antrim, is a place in Northern Ireland.
- The Route is a movie from 2013.
- Routes, Seine-Maritime, is a town in France.
- Routes, the video game, was made in 2003.

There are also other types of routes:

- An air route or airway is a flight path for airplanes to follow.
- A GPS route is a series of points on a map that show you how to get somewhere.
- A path can be a route or a trail in nature.
- A rout in war is a quick retreat of soldiers.
- A route number or road number is the number given to a road.
- A router can be a device that helps send information over the internet.
- A router in woodworking is a tool used to cut patterns in wood.
- Routing is the process of finding the best way to send information.
- A routing table is a list that helps find the best way to send information.
- A scenic route is a road that is known for its beautiful views.
- A trade route is a path often used to trade goods.

adult_non_technical.text:
A route is a path or course that you can take to get from one place to another. It can be a physical path, like a road or a trail, or it can be a virtual path, like a route on a computer network. Routes can also be used in different contexts, such as in sports, technology, geography, film, and even games.

The term route can refer to many different things. For example, in gridiron football, a route is a path run by a wide receiver. In technology, a route command is a program used to configure the routing table, which helps determine how data travels through a network. In geography, Route, County Antrim, is an area in Northern Ireland. In film, The Route is a 2013 Ugandan film. In France, Routes, Seine-Maritime, is a commune in Seine-Maritime. And in video games, Routes (video game), a 2003 game, is an example of a route in a game.

There are also other types of routes. For example, in aviation, an air route or airway is a designated path for aircraft to follow. GPS devices can also be used to create routes, and a GPS route is a series of one or more GPS waypoints. A scenic route is a thoroughfare designated as scenic based on the scenery through which it passes. And a trade route is a commonly used path for the passage of goods.

adult_technical.text: The term "route" can refer to various concepts, including a specific route in gridiron football, a command used to configure a routing table, a location in Northern Ireland, a 2013 Ugandan film, a commune in France, a video game, and, more broadly, a path or route in different contexts such as avionics, GPS, military operations, woodworking, and more.

samples.title: Joule per mole
samples.original_text:
The joule per mole (symbol: J·mol−1 or J/mol) is an SI derived unit of energy per amount of material. Energy is measured in joules, and the amount of material is measured in moles. For example, Gibbs free energy is quantified as joules per mole. It is also a SI derived unit of molar thermodynamic energy defined as the energy equal to one joule in one mole of substance. 

Since 1 mole = 6.02214076×1023 particles (atoms, molecules, ions etc.), 1 joule per mole is equal to 1 joule divided by 6.02214076×1023 particles, 1.66054×10−24 joule per particle. This very small amount of energy is often expressed in terms of a smaller unit such as the electronvolt (eV, see below).

Physical quantities measured in J·mol−1 usually describe quantities of energy transferred during phase transformations or chemical reactions. Division by the number of moles facilitates comparison between processes involving different quantities of material and between similar processes involving different types of materials.  The precise meaning of such a quantity is dependent on the context (what substances are involved, circumstances, etc.), but the unit of measurement is used specifically to describe certain existing phenomena, such as in thermodynamics it is the unit of measurement that describes molar energy.

For convenience and due to the range of magnitudes involved these quantities are almost always reported in kJ·mol−1 rather than in J·mol−1. For example, heats of fusion and vaporization are usually of the order of 10 kJ·mol−1, bond energies are of the order of 100 kJ·mol−1, and ionization energies of the order of 1000 kJ·mol−1. 

1 kJ·mol−1 is equal to 0.239 kcal·mol−1, 1.04×10−2 eV per particle, or 83.6 cm−1. At room temperature (25 °C, 77 °F, or 298.15 K) 1 kJ·mol−1 is equal to 0.4034 .

References 

SI derived units

easy_general.text:
A joule per mole is a unit of measurement that shows how much energy is in a certain amount of material. Energy is measured in joules, and the amount of material is measured in moles. For example, Gibbs free energy is measured in joules per mole. It is also a unit of measurement for molar thermodynamic energy, which is the energy in one joule of one mole of substance.

One mole is equal to 6.02214076×1023 particles (atoms, molecules, ions, etc.). So, one joule per mole is equal to one joule divided by 6.02214076×1023 particles, or 1.66054×10−24 joule per particle. This is a tiny amount of energy, so it is often expressed in a smaller unit called the electronvolt (eV).

Physical quantities measured in joules per mole usually describe the amount of energy transferred during phase transformations or chemical reactions. Division by the number of moles makes it easier to compare processes involving different amounts of material or different types of materials. The meaning of these quantities depends on the context, but the unit of measurement is used to describe certain phenomena, such as molar energy in thermodynamics.

For convenience, these quantities are usually reported in kilojoules per mole (kJ/mol) instead of joules per mole (J/mol). For example, heats of fusion and vaporization are usually around 10 kJ/mol, bond energies are around 100 kJ/mol, and ionization energies are around 1000 kJ/mol.

1 kJ/mol is equal to 0.239 kcal/mol, 1.04×10−2 eV per particle, or 83.6 cm−1. At room temperature (25°C, 77°F, or 298.15 K), 1 kJ/mol is equal to 0.4034.

References

SI derived units

samples.title: Kumbatine National Park
samples.original_text:
Kumbatine  is a national park located in New South Wales, Australia,  northeast of Sydney.

Geography
Glencoe Creek is located wholly within Kumbatine National Park.

The most prominent and highest mountain in the national park is Mount Kippara with an altitude of 484 meters.

See also
 Protected areas of New South Wales

References

National parks of New South Wales
Protected areas established in 1999
1999 establishments in Australia

easy_general.text: Kumbatine National Park is a beautiful place in New South Wales, Australia. It's northeast of Sydney and has a creek called Glencoe Creek. The highest mountain in the park is Mount Kippara, which is 484 meters tall.

adult_non_technical.text: Kumbatine National Park is a beautiful protected area located in New South Wales, Australia, just a bit northeast of Sydney. The park is home to Glencoe Creek, a small river that flows entirely within the park's boundaries. The highest point in the park is Mount Kippara, which stands at 484 meters above sea level.

adult_technical.text:
Kumbatine National Park is situated in New South Wales, Australia, located northeast of Sydney. The park encompasses Glencoe Creek, which is entirely within its boundaries. The highest peak within the park is Mount Kippara, reaching an altitude of 484 meters.

See also: Protected areas of New South Wales

References: National parks of New South Wales, Protected areas established in 1999, 1999 establishments in Australia

samples.title: Gentlemen, Be Seated!
samples.original_text:
"Gentlemen, Be Seated" is a science fiction short story by American writer Robert A. Heinlein.  It was first published in the May 1948 issue of Argosy magazine.  It was later included in two of Heinlein's collections, The Green Hills of Earth (1951), and The Past Through Tomorrow (1967).

Plot summary

The story tells of a visit to a tunnel on the surface of the Moon which goes awry when a pressure seal fails, trapping three men (a supervisor, a reporter, and a tunnel worker). The title of the story derives from the way they plug an air leak while awaiting rescue: by sitting on it.

The phrase "Gentlemen, Be Seated!" is the opening line of the interlocutor in a traditional minstrel show. It was also, at the time the story was written and while Heinlein attended, the opening line for all classes at the military and naval academies (as well as classes for officers at the various service schools) in the United States.

The story might have been inspired by an episode in "Baron Munchausen": The ship sprung a leak. It was my good fortune to discover it first. I found it a large hole about a foot diameter. ... This noble vessel was preserved, with all its crew, by a most fortunate thought! in short, I sat down over it. ... My situation, while I sat there, was rather cool, but the carpenter's art soon relieved me.

References

External links
 

1948 short stories
Short stories by Robert A. Heinlein
Works originally published in Argosy (magazine)

easy_general.text:
"Gentlemen, Be Seated" is a science fiction story by Robert A. Heinlein. It was first published in May 1948 in a magazine called Argosy. Later, it was included in two collections of Heinlein's stories: The Green Hills of Earth (1951) and The Past Through Tomorrow (1967).

The story is about three men who get trapped in a tunnel on the Moon when a pressure seal breaks. They are a supervisor, a reporter, and a tunnel worker. To stop the air from escaping and save themselves, they decide to sit on the leak until help arrives.

The title "Gentlemen, Be Seated" comes from a phrase used in minstrel shows, which were popular performances in the past. It was also used as the opening line for classes at military and naval academies in the United States.

The story might have been inspired by a scene from a book called Baron Munchausen. In this scene, a ship gets a leak, and the main character, Baron Munchausen, fixes it by sitting down over the hole.

The story might have been inspired by a scene in a book called Baron Munchausen, where a character fixes a leak in a ship by sitting on it.

samples.title: 800 BC
samples.original_text:
Events
End of the reign of Polydectes, king of Sparta from 830 BC.
Beginning of the reign of Eunomus, king of Sparta until 780 BC.
Emergence of the first communities settled in the Chincha Valley (Peru), pertaining to Paracas culture in the south coast of Peru.
End of Period IVB, Hasanlu is completely destroyed by a fire.
The Greek Colonization of the Mediterranean & Black Sea.
Archaic period of Greece ( - 500 BCE).
Homer of Greece writes his Iliad and Odyssey. ( - 700 BCE)
Assyrian army makes a good use of the new technology by which iron can be hardened into steel suitable for weapons.
Earliest surviving sundial is in use in Egypt.
Beginning of Iron Age in Britain (until 43 AD).

Deaths
Xiong Xun, monarch of the state of Chu during the Western Zhou Dynasty of ancient China.
Hasanlu Lovers, pair of human remains found at Teppe Hasanlu, possibly a couple.

References

Gallery

easy_general.text:
"Events
Polydectes, the king of Sparta, stopped ruling in 830 BC.
Eunomus became the new king of Sparta and ruled until 780 BC.
People started living in the Chincha Valley in Peru, part of the Paracas culture.
A big fire destroyed a place called Hasanlu.
The Greeks began to settle in the Mediterranean and Black Sea areas.
Greek started a new period around 500 BC.
A Greek poet named Homer wrote the Iliad and Odyssey.
The Assyrians used a new way to make strong weapons from iron.
People used a sundial in Egypt to tell time.
The Iron Age started in Britain until 43 AD.

Deaths
Xiong Xun, a leader of the state of Chu in ancient China, died.
Two people were found at a place called Hasanlu, they might have been a couple.

References

Gallery"

adult_non_technical.text:
"Events
Polydectes stops ruling Sparta in 830 BC.
Eunomus rules Sparta until 780 BC.
The first communities in the Chincha Valley, Peru, start to settle.
A fire destroys Hasanlu, ending the Period IVB.
The Greeks start settling in the Mediterranean and Black Sea.
The Archaic period of Greece begins.
Homer writes the Iliad and Odyssey.
The Assyrians use a new technology to make steel weapons from iron.
The earliest known sundial is used in Egypt.
The Iron Age in Britain starts.

Deaths

samples.title: Cordelia (moon)
samples.original_text:
Cordelia is the innermost known moon of Uranus. It was discovered from the images taken by Voyager 2 on January 20, 1986, and was given the temporary designation S/1986 U 7. It was not detected again until the Hubble Space Telescope observed it in 1997. Cordelia takes its name from the youngest daughter of Lear in William Shakespeare's King Lear. It is also designated Uranus VI.

Other than its orbit, radius of 20 km and geometric albedo of 0.08 virtually nothing is known about it. In the Voyager 2 images Cordelia appears as an elongated object with its major axis pointing towards Uranus. The ratio of axes of Cordelia's prolate spheroid is 0.7 ± 0.2.

Cordelia acts as the inner shepherd satellite for Uranus' ε ring. Cordelia's orbit is within Uranus' synchronous orbit radius, and is therefore slowly decaying due to tidal deceleration.

Cordelia is very close to a 5:3 orbital resonance with Rosalind.

See also 

 Moons of Uranus

References 

Explanatory notes

Citations

External links 
 Cordelia Profile by NASA's Solar System Exploration
 Uranus' Known Satellites (by Scott S. Sheppard)

Moons of Uranus
19860120

easy_general.text:
Cordelia is the closest moon to Uranus. It was discovered by Voyager 2 on January 20, 1986, and was first called S/1986 U 7. It wasn't seen again until 1997 when the Hubble Space Telescope found it. Cordelia is named after the youngest daughter in William Shakespeare's play King Lear. It's also called Uranus VI.

We don't know much about Cordelia, but we do know it's about 20 kilometers wide and has a very dark surface. In Voyager 2's pictures, it looks like a long, thin object with its longest part pointing towards Uranus.

Cordelia helps keep the ε ring around Uranus in place. It's so close to Uranus that its orbit is slowly getting smaller because of something called tidal deceleration.

Cordelia is very close to another moon called Rosalind in a special relationship called a 5:3 orbital resonance. This means that for every 5 times Cordelia orbits Uranus, Rosalind orbits 3 times.

To learn more about Cordelia and other moons of Uranus, you can check out NASA's Solar System Exploration website or Scott S. Sheppard's list of Uranus' moons.

adult_non_technical.text:
Cordelia is the closest moon to Uranus. It was first seen by Voyager 2 on January 20, 1986, and was given the temporary name S/1986 U 7. It wasn't seen again until 1997 when the Hubble Space Telescope found it. Cordelia is named after the youngest daughter in William Shakespeare's King Lear and is also called Uranus VI.

We don't know much about Cordelia, but we do know it's about 20 kilometers wide and has a very dark surface. In Voyager 2's pictures, it looks like a stretched-out shape with its long end pointing towards Uranus.

Cordelia helps keep the ε ring around Uranus in place. It's so close to Uranus that its orbit is slowly getting smaller due to the planet's gravity. Cordelia is also close to having a special orbital relationship with another moon called Rosalind.

For more information, check out the moons of Uranus.

adult_technical.text:
Cordelia is the innermost known moon of Uranus. It was discovered from the images taken by Voyager 2 on January 20, 1986, and was given the temporary designation S/1986 U 7. It was not detected again until the Hubble Space Telescope observed it in 1997. Cordelia takes its name from the youngest daughter of Lear in William Shakespeare's King Lear. It is also designated Uranus VI.

Other than its orbit, radius of 20 km and geometric albedo of 0.08 virtually nothing is known about it. In the Voyager 2 images Cordelia appears as an elongated object with its major axis pointing towards Uranus. The ratio of axes of Cordelia's prolate spheroid is 0.7 ± 0.2.

Cordelia acts as the inner shepherd satellite for Uranus' ε ring. Cordelia's orbit is within Uranus' synchronous orbit radius, and is therefore slowly decaying due to tidal deceleration.

Cordelia is very close to a 5:3 orbital resonance with Rosalind.

samples.title: Svenska Akademiens ordbok
samples.original_text:
Svenska Akademiens ordbok (), abbreviated SAOB, is a dictionary published by the Swedish Academy, with the official title Ordbok över svenska språket utgiven av Svenska Akademien. This dictionary is the Swedish counterpart of the Oxford English Dictionary (OED) or the Deutsches Wörterbuch (DWB). 

Work on the dictionary started in 1787 and the first volume was published in 1898 and as of 2021, when the latest volume appeared, work has progressed to the letter Å inclusively. The dictionary has approximately 450,000 main entries. The searchable web version has been available since 1997.

See also
Svenska Akademiens ordlista

External links 
Svenska Akademiens ordbok
The Swedish Academy – Official site (in English)

Swedish non-fiction literature
Swedish Academy
Publications established in 1898
Swedish dictionaries
Online dictionaries
1898 establishments in Sweden

easy_general.text: The Swedish Academy made a dictionary called the Svenska Akademiens ordbok, or SAOB for short. This dictionary is a big book that lists all the words in the Swedish language. It was started in 1787 and the first part was published in 1898. Now, it has been completed up to the letter Å. The dictionary has about 450,000 words. You can use the online version of the dictionary to look up words since 1997.

adult_non_technical.text: The Swedish Academy, a group of experts in Sweden, has created a big dictionary for the Swedish language. This dictionary is called the Svenska Akademiens ordbok, or SAOB for short. It has about 450,000 words and has been in the works since 1787. You can even search it online.

adult_technical.text:
The Svenska Akademiens ordbok, or SAOB, is a comprehensive Swedish dictionary published by the Swedish Academy. Officially titled Ordbok över svenska språket utgiven av Svenska Akademien, it serves as the Swedish equivalent of the Oxford English Dictionary (OED) or the Deutsches Wörterbuch (DWB).

Work on the dictionary commenced in 1787, with the first volume published in 1898. As of the 2021 edition, the dictionary has covered up to the letter Å inclusively, containing approximately 450,000 main entries. A searchable web version of the dictionary has been available since 1997.
