samples.title: Pommern (disambiguation)
samples.original_text:
Pommern is the German language name for Pomerania, a historical region divided between Germany and Poland.

Pommern may also refer to:

 Pommern (horse), a racehorse which won the English Triple Crown in 1915
 Pommern (ship), former German Flying P-Liner sailing ship, docked in Finland as museum ship
 Pommern, Rhineland-Palatinate, a municipality in the district of Cochem-Zell
 Mecklenburg-Vorpommern or Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania, a German state, partially covering Western Pomerania
 SMS Pommern, German World War I battleship
 Swedish Pomerania, a Dominion under the Swedish Crown from 1630 to 1815, situated on what is now the Baltic coast of Germany and Poland

See also
 Pomeranian (dog)

easy_general.text: Pommern is the German name for Pomerania, a place that used to be in Germany and Poland. But Pommern can also mean other things, like a famous racehorse, a museum ship, a town in Germany, a part of Germany, a big ship from World War I, and a place that was part of Sweden.

adult_non_technical.text:
Pommern is the German name for Pomerania, a region that's now split between Germany and Poland. But Pommern can also refer to other things:

There's a racehorse named Pommern that won the English Triple Crown in 1915. There's also a ship called Pommern that used to be a German Flying P-Liner sailing ship and now serves as a museum ship in Finland. There's a town called Pommern in Rhineland-Palatinate, Germany, and a German state called Mecklenburg-Vorpommern. SMS Pommern was a German battleship from World War I, and Swedish Pomerania was a part of the Swedish Crown from 1630 to 1815, located on what's now the Baltic coast of Germany and Poland.

Also, there's a type of dog called a Pomeranian.

samples.title: Mill Creek Township, Mercer County, Pennsylvania
samples.original_text:
Mill Creek Township is a township in Mercer County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 721 at the 2010 census.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 19.3 square miles (50.1 km2), of which, 18.9 square miles (49.0 km2) of it is land and 0.4 square miles (1.1 km2) of it (2.12%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 639 people, 243 households, and 185 families residing in the township.  The population density was 33.7 people per square mile (13.0/km2).  There were 265 housing units at an average density of 14.0/sq mi (5.4/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 98.75% White, 0.63% African American, 0.16% from other races, and 0.47% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.16% of the population.

There were 243 households, out of which 34.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 65.8% were married couples living together, 7.8% had a female householder with no husband present, and 23.5% were non-families. 20.2% of all households were made up of individuals, and 8.6% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.59 and the average family size was 2.97.

In the township the population was spread out, with 25.2% under the age of 18, 7.2% from 18 to 24, 27.4% from 25 to 44, 26.4% from 45 to 64, and 13.8% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 38 years. For every 100 females there were 100.9 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 99.2 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $39,219, and the median income for a family was $41,023. Males had a median income of $30,903 versus $23,125 for females. The per capita income for the township was $16,928.  About 5.0% of families and 7.7% of the population were below the poverty line, including 9.0% of those under age 18 and 2.2% of those age 65 or over.

References

Townships in Mercer County, Pennsylvania

Of the 243 households, 34.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 65.8% were married couples living together, 7.8% had a female householder with no husband present, and 23.5% were non-families. 20.2% of households were made up of individuals and 8.6% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.59 and the average family size was 2.97.

The population in the township was spread out, with 25.2% under the age of 18, 7.2% from 18 to 24, 27.4% from 25 to 44, 26.4% from 45 to 64, and 13.8% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 38 years old.

The median income for a household was $39,219, and the median income for a family was $41,023. The per capita income for the township was $16,928. About 5.0% of families and 7.7% of the population were below the poverty line.

samples.title: 138 BC
samples.original_text:
Year 138 BC was a year of the pre-Julian Roman calendar. At the time it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Serapio and Callaicus (or, less frequently, year 616 Ab urbe condita) and the Third Year of Jianyuan. The denomination 138 BC for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events 
 By place 
Roman Empire
 Tautalus surrenders to the Romans.
 Valencia in Spain is founded as a Roman colony.

Asia Minor
 Attalus III succeeds Attalus II as Attalid king of Pergamon
Egypt
 Galaestes revolts.

Syria
 Antiochus VII expels Diodotus Tryphon.
 Tryphon sacks Beirut

 Parthia 
 Phraates II becomes emperor of Parthia.

 China
 Grand Empress Dowager Dou, the grandmother of Emperor Wu of Han, purges the high administration of officials to consolidate her power. Among those dismissed are Prime Minister Dou Yong and her own half-brother, the General-in-Chief Tian Fen. Two of the young emperor's closest advisors, Zhao Wan and Wang Zang, are arrested and commit suicide.

 By topic 
 Arts and sciences 
 Hymn to Apollo is written and inscribed on stone in Delphi; it is the earliest surviving notated music, in a substantial and legible fragment, in the western world.

Births 
 Lucius Cornelius Sulla, Roman general and statesman (d. 78 BC)
 Phaedrus the Epicurean, Greek scholar and philosopher

Deaths 
 Attalus II Philadelphus, king of Pergamon (b. 220 BC)
 Diodotus Tryphon, king of the Seleucid Empire
 Mithridates I, king of Parthia (b. c. 195 BC)

References

easy_general.text:
In the year 138 BC, a lot of interesting things happened around the world. Here are some of the most important events:

In the Roman Empire:
- A leader named Tautalus gave up to the Romans.
- A new city called Valencia was started in Spain as a Roman colony.

In Asia Minor:
- A new king named Attalus III took over as king of Pergamon.

In Egypt:
- A group of people called Galaestes rebelled.

In Syria:
- A king named Antiochus VII kicked out another king named Diodotus Tryphon.
- Diodotus Tryphon attacked a city called Beirut.

In Parthia:
- A new king named Phraates II took over as emperor.

In China:
- A powerful woman named Grand Empress Dowager Dou got rid of some important people to gain control.

In Arts and Sciences:
- A song called hymn to Apollo was written on a stone in Delphi, a new way to remember music.

People were born:
- Lucius Cornelius Sulla, a famous Roman general and leader.
- Phaedrus the Epicurean, a Greek scholar and thinker.

People died:
- Attalus II Philadelphus, the king of Pergamon.
- Diodotus Tryphon, the king of the Seleucid Empire.
- Mithridates I, the king of Parthia.

adult_non_technical.text:
In the year 138 BC, a lot of interesting things happened around the world. Here's a summary of some of the most important events:

In the Roman Empire, a leader named Tautalus gave up to the Romans. Also, a city called Valencia in Spain was established as a Roman colony.

In Asia Minor, a king named Attalus III took over from his father, Attalus II, as the ruler of a place called Pergamon. In Egypt, a leader named Galaestes started a rebellion.

In Syria, a king named Antiochus VII kicked out another leader named Diodotus Tryphon. After that, Tryphon attacked a city called Beirut.

In Parthia, a king named Phraates II became the ruler of the country.

In China, a powerful woman named Grand Empress Dowager Dou removed some important officials to strengthen her position.

In the arts and sciences, a famous song in a city called Delphi was written and carved into stone. This song is one of the oldest examples of written music in the Western world.

Important people were born like Lucius Cornelius Sulla, a Roman general and statesman, and Phaedrus the Epicurean, a Greek scholar and philosopher.

Some important people passed away, such as Attalus II Philadelphus, the king of Pergamon, Diodotus Tryphon, the king of the Seleucid Empire, and Mithridates I, the king of Parthia.

adult_technical.text:
The year 138 BC was a pivotal year in the pre-Julian Roman calendar, known as the Year of the Consulship of Serapio and Callaicus, or less frequently, year 616 Ab urbe condita, and the Third Year of Jianyuan in China. The denomination 138 BC has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

By place:
- Roman Empire: Tautalus surrenders to the Romans, and Valencia in Spain is founded as a Roman colony.
- Asia Minor: Attalus III succeeds Attalus II as Attalid king of Pergamon.
- Egypt: Galaestes revolts.
- Syria: Antiochus VII expels Diodotus Tryphon, and Tryphon sacks Beirut.
- Parthia: Phraates II becomes emperor of Parthia.
- China: Grand Empress Dowager Dou purges the high administration of officials to consolidate her power. Among those dismissed are Prime Minister Dou Yong and her own half-brother, the General-in-Chief Tian Fen. Two of the young emperor's closest advisors, Zhao Wan and Wang Zang, are arrested and commit suicide.

By topic:
- Arts and sciences: The Hymn to Apollo is written and inscribed on stone in Delphi, marking the earliest surviving notated music in a substantial and legible fragment in the western world.
- Births: Lucius Cornelius Sulla, a Roman general and statesman (d. 78 BC), and Phaedrus the Epicurean, a Greek scholar and philosopher.
- Deaths: Attalus II Philadelphus, king of Pergamon (b. 220 BC), Diodotus Tryphon, king of the Seleucid Empire, and Mithridates I, king of Parthia (b. c. 195 BC).

References

samples.title: Cherry Grove Township, Warren County, Pennsylvania
samples.original_text:
Cherry Grove Township is a township in Warren County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population at the 2000 census was 228.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , all of it land.

Demographics

As of the census of 2000, there were 228 people, 92 households, and 72 families residing in the township.  The population density was 4.9 people per square mile (1.9/km2).  There were 368 housing units at an average density of 7.8/sq mi (3.0/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 100.00% White.

There were 92 households, out of which 23.9% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 66.3% were married couples living together, 7.6% had a female householder with no husband present, and 21.7% were non-families. 21.7% of all households were made up of individuals, and 5.4% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.48 and the average family size was 2.82.

In the township the population was spread out, with 20.6% under the age of 18, 5.7% from 18 to 24, 25.9% from 25 to 44, 30.7% from 45 to 64, and 17.1% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 42 years. For every 100 females, there were 115.1 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 108.0 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $35,625, and the median income for a family was $40,313. Males had a median income of $35,625 versus $18,125 for females. The per capita income for the township was $15,628.  About 7.8% of families and 5.8% of the population were below the poverty line, including 4.5% of those under the age of eighteen and none of those 65 or over.

References

Townships in Warren County, Pennsylvania
Townships in Pennsylvania

samples.title: Adaptive communications
samples.original_text:
Adaptive communications can mean any communications system, or portion thereof, that automatically uses feedback information obtained from the system itself or from the signals carried by the system to modify dynamically one or more of the system operational parameters to improve system performance or to resist degradation.  
The modification of a system parameter may be discrete, as in hard-switched diversity reception, or may be continuous, as in a 
predetection combining algorithm.

See also
Automatic Link Establishment
Channel use
CALM M5

Telecommunications techniques

easy_general.text: Adaptive communications is like a phone system that can adjust itself to work better in different situations. It uses information from the system or the signals it carries to make changes and improve performance. This can be done in different ways, like using different channels or adjusting the signal strength.

adult_non_technical.text: Adaptive communications is a way for communication systems to adjust themselves based on their surroundings. It's like a car that can change its speed depending on the traffic. These systems use feedback information to make changes that improve performance or prevent problems. These changes can be sudden or gradual, depending on the situation.

adult_technical.text:
Adaptive communications refers to any communication system or its components that utilize feedback information derived from the system itself or the signals it carries to dynamically adjust one or more operational parameters to enhance system performance or mitigate degradation. The modification of these parameters can occur in discrete steps, such as in the case of diversity reception with hard-switching, or in a continuous manner, as seen in predetection combining algorithms.

Relevant topics include Automatic Link Establishment, Channel Use, CALM M5, and Telecommunications Techniques.

adult_non_technical.text:
Worcester is a name that can refer to many different things around the world. Here are some examples:

In the United Kingdom, Worcester, England, is a city in Worcestershire. There's also a UK Parliament constituency called Worcester, and a place in London called Worcester Park. Worcestershire is a county in England.

In the United States, Worcester, Massachusetts, is the largest city with the name. There's also Worcester County in Massachusetts, Worcester, Missouri, Worcester, New York, a town, Worcester Township in Pennsylvania, Worcester, a town, in Vermont, Worcester, a town, in Wisconsin, Worcester, an unincorporated community in Wisconsin, Worcester County in Maryland, Barry, Illinois, formerly known as Worcester, and Marquette, Michigan, formerly known as New Worcester.

Other places with the name include Worcester, Limpopo, South Africa, Worcester, Western Cape, South Africa, and Worcester Summit, Antarctica.

In transportation, Worcester can refer to a type of train called the GWR 3031 Class locomotive, which was used on the Great Western Railway between 1891 and 1915. It can also refer to a train station in Worcester, Massachusetts, called Union Station by the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority. There are also several ships called HMS Worcester in the British Royal Navy and USS Worcester in the United States Navy.

In people, Worcester can refer to a monk and chronicler named John of Worcester, a bishop named Roger of Worcester, another bishop Sylvester of Worcester, and a surname called Worcester.

In food, Worcester can refer to a type of apple called the Worcester Pearmain, and to Worcestershire sauce, a spicy condiment created in Worcester, England, in the 19th century.

Other uses of the name Worcester include Worcester Academy, a British domestic heating company called Worcester, Bosch Group, Worcester College, and Royal Worcester, an English bone china and porcelain manufacturer.

You can also read about Worcester v. Georgia, an 1832 U.S. Supreme Court Case, and Wooster, which can refer to different things.

The list is further divided into male and female biathletes, with each discipline having its own medal table. For male biathletes, the disciplines include the individual event, sprint event, pursuit event, mass start, and relay event, as well as the mixed relay event. Similarly, female biathletes compete in the individual event, sprint event, pursuit event, mass start, and relay event, and again, the mixed relay event. The women's relay event has been contested over three different distances: the 3×7.5 km relay in 1992, the 4×7.5 km relay from 1994 to 2002, and the 4×6 km relay from 2006 to 2018.

The medal table includes the 1924 military patrol medalists. Bold text denotes biathletes who have won gold medals in corresponding disciplines more than once, while bold numbers indicate the record number of victories in certain disciplines. Additionally, the document lists the top biathletes in terms of total medals won, with boldface indicating active biathletes and the highest medal count among all biathletes, including biathletes not listed in the tables. The document also lists the top biathletes in terms of gold medals won at the Winter Olympics, with boldface indicating active biathletes and the highest medal count among all biathletes, including biathletes not listed in the tables. The document denotes the Olympics in which mentioned biathletes took part, with boldface indicating the latest Olympics.

The document also tracks the number of medals won per year, with bolded numbers indicating the highest medal count at that year's Olympic Games. For further reading, the document provides links to additional resources, including the Biathlon World Championships, Biathlon World Cup, the list of IOC country codes, and the military patrol at the 1924 Winter Olympics. The document also includes references to the International Olympic Committee results database and the biathlon medalists list.

samples.title: Gross world product
samples.original_text:
The gross world product (GWP) is the combined gross national income of all the countries in the world. Because imports and exports balance exactly when considering the whole world, this also equals the total global gross domestic product (GDP). According to the World Bank, the 2013 nominal GWP was approximately US$75.59 trillion. In 2017, according to the CIA's World Factbook, the GWP was around US $80.27 trillion in nominal terms and totaled approximately 127.8 trillion international dollars in terms of purchasing power parity (PPP). The per capita PPP GWP in 2017 was approximately Int$17,500 according to the World Factbook.  According to the World Bank, the 2020 GWP in current US$ was approximately US$ 84.705 trillion.

Recent growth
The table below gives recent percentage values for overall GWP growth from 2006 through 2020, as well as an estimate for 2021, according to the International Monetary Fund (IMF)'s World Economic Outlook database. Data is given in terms of constant year-on-year prices.

Historical and prehistorical estimates

In 1998, economic historian J. Bradford DeLong estimated the total GWP in 1990 U.S. dollars for the main years between one million years BCE and 2000 CE (shown in the table below). 

Nominal GWP estimates from 2005 onwards are also shown in contemporary U.S. dollars, according to estimates from the CIA World Factbook and the World Bank. "Billion" in the table below refers to the short scale usage of the term, where 1 billion = 1,000 million = 109.

samples.title: College Park
samples.original_text:
College Park may refer to:

Australia
College Park, South Australia, a suburb of Adelaide

Canada
 College Park (Toronto), a shopping mall, residential and office complex in Toronto
 College Park, Saskatoon, a neighbourhood
 College Park East, Saskatoon, a neighbourhood

Republic of Ireland
 College Park, Dublin

United Kingdom
 College Park, London

United States
College Park (Charleston), a historic baseball stadium in Charleston, South Carolina
College Park, California (disambiguation)
College Park, Delaware, an unincorporated community
College Park, Orlando, a neighborhood of Orlando, Florida
College Park, Georgia, a suburb of Atlanta
College Park, Maryland, a suburb of Washington, DC
University of Maryland, College Park, the flagship state university of Maryland
College Park Airport in Prince George's County, Maryland
College Park High School (Pleasant Hill, California)
College Park (Virginia Beach), a neighborhood in the Kempsville section of Virginia Beach, Virginia, USA
The Woodlands College Park High School, in The Woodlands, Texas

College Park Station (disambiguation)
University Park (disambiguation)

easy_general.text:
"College Park is a name that can refer to different places around the world. For example, in Australia, it's a part of the city of Adelaide. In Canada, it's a shopping mall, residential, and office complex in Toronto, and also a neighborhood in Saskatoon. There's another neighborhood in Saskatoon called College Park East. It's also a place in the Republic of Ireland, in Dublin, and in the United Kingdom, in London.

In the United States, College Park is a historic baseball stadium in Charleston, South Carolina. It's also a place in California, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, and Maryland. In Maryland, it's a suburb of Washington, DC, and there's a university there called the University of Maryland, College Park. There's an airport called College Park Airport in Prince George's County, Maryland, and a high school called College Park High School in Pleasant Hill, California. In Virginia Beach, Virginia, it's a neighborhood in the Kempsville section. In Texas, there's a high school called The Woodlands College Park High School.

You can also read about College Park Station and University Park for more information."

adult_non_technical.text:

Australia

- College Park, Saskatoon, a neighborhood
- College Park East, Saskatoon, another neighborhood

Republic of Ireland
- College Park, Dublin

United Kingdom
- College Park, London

United States
- College Park (Charleston), a historic baseball stadium in Charleston, South Carolina
- College Park, California, a place with multiple meanings
- College Park, Delaware, a small community
- College Park, Orlando, a neighborhood in Orlando, Florida
- College Park, Georgia, a part of Atlanta
- College Park, Maryland, a part of Washington, DC
- University of Maryland, College Park, the main state university in Maryland
- College Park Airport in Prince George's County, Maryland
- College Park High School in Pleasant Hill, California
- College Park (Virginia Beach), a neighborhood in Virginia Beach, Virginia
- The Woodlands College Park High School in The Woodlands, Texas

See also:
- College Park Station
- University Park"

adult_technical.text:
The term "College Park" can refer to various locations and entities across different countries. Here are some examples:

In Australia, College Park is a suburb of Adelaide, South Australia.

In Canada, College Park refers to a shopping mall, residential, and office complex in Toronto, as well as neighbourhoods in Saskatoon, known as College Park and College Park East.

In the Republic of Ireland, College Park is a location in Dublin.

In the United Kingdom, College Park is a location in London.

In the United States, College Park can refer to a historic baseball stadium in Charleston, South Carolina, a shopping mall in California, an unincorporated community in Delaware, a neighborhood in Orlando, Florida, a suburb of Atlanta, Georgia, a suburb of Washington, DC, Maryland, the flagship state university of Maryland, the University of Maryland, College Park, an airport in Prince George's County, Maryland, a high school in Pleasant Hill, California, and a neighborhood in Kempsville, Virginia Beach, Virginia. Additionally, The Woodlands College Park High School is located in The Woodlands, Texas.

See also: College Park Station (disambiguation) and University Park (disambiguation).

samples.title: Sour mix
samples.original_text:
Sour mix (also known as sweet and sour mix) is a mixer that is yellow-green in color and is used in many cocktails. It is made from approximately equal parts lemon and/or lime juice and simple syrup and shaken vigorously with ice. This produces a pearly-white liquid with a pronounced flavor.

Optionally, egg whites may be added to make the liquid slightly foamy.

Sour mix can be mixed with liquor(s) to make a sour drink; most common are vodka sour (vodka) and whiskey sour (whiskey).

Pre-mixed versions are available, and are in use in many bars.  These typically consist of a powder which must be rehydrated by adding water prior to use.

See also
List of cocktails

Drink mixers

easy_general.text:
Sour mix is a yellow-green mixer used in many cocktails. It's made by shaking equal parts of lemon and/or lime juice and simple syrup with ice. This creates a pearly-white liquid with a strong flavor. Sometimes, egg whites are added to make it slightly foamy.

Sour mix can be mixed with liquor to make sour drinks. The most common ones are vodka sour and whiskey sour.

Pre-mixed versions of sour mix are used in bars. These are usually powders that need to be mixed with water before use.

For more information, check out the list of cocktails and drink mixers.

This creates a pearly-white liquid with a strong flavor. Sometimes, egg whites are added to make the liquid foamy.

Sour mix can be mixed with liquor to make sour drinks. The most common ones are vodka sour and whiskey sour. Pre-mixed versions are also available, which are often used in bars. These come in a powder form and need to be mixed with water before use.

For more information, check out the list of cocktails and drink mixers.

adult_technical.text:
Sour mix, also known as sweet and sour mix, is a yellow-green mixer commonly used in various cocktails. It is typically prepared by shaking equal parts of lemon and/or lime juice and simple syrup with ice, resulting in a pearly-white liquid with a distinct flavor. Optionally, egg whites can be added to create a foamy texture.

Sour mix can be combined with various liquors to create sour drinks, the most popular being the vodka sour and whiskey sour. Pre-mixed versions are also available, usually consisting of a powder that must be rehydrated with water before use.

samples.title: Lucerne Mines, Pennsylvania
samples.original_text:
Lucernemines, usually written as Lucerne Mines, is a census-designated place (CDP) in Indiana County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 937 at the 2010 census.

Geography
Lucerne Mines is located at  (40.554447, -79.155584).

According to the United States Census Bureau, the CDP has a total area of , all of it land.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 951 people, 407 households, and 293 families residing in the CDP. The population density was 1,105.8 people per square mile (427.0/km2). There were 427 housing units at an average density of 496.5/sq mi (191.7/km2). The racial makeup of the CDP was 98.63% White, 1.05% African American, 0.11% Asian, and 0.21% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.84% of the population.

There were 407 households, out of which 23.1% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 57.2% were married couples living together, 10.8% had a female householder with no husband present, and 27.8% were non-families. 25.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and 15.5% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.33 and the average family size was 2.76.

In the CDP the population was spread out, with 19.1% under the age of 18, 6.1% from 18 to 24, 27.8% from 25 to 44, 23.4% from 45 to 64, and 23.6% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 43 years. For every 100 females there were 94.9 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 93.2 males.

The median income for a household in the CDP was $28,427, and the median income for a family was $33,580. Males had a median income of $26,719 versus $18,036 for females. The per capita income for the CDP was $13,976. About 10.4% of families and 10.4% of the population were below the poverty line, including 14.5% of those under age 18 and 4.1% of those age 65 or over.

References

Census-designated places in Indiana County, Pennsylvania

samples.title: Worth Township, Mercer County, Pennsylvania
samples.original_text:
Worth Township is a township in Mercer County, Pennsylvania, United States.  The population was 899 at the 2010 census.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 25.0 square miles (64.8 km2), of which, 24.8 square miles (64.2 km2) of it is land and 0.2 square miles (0.6 km2) of it (0.96%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 830 people, 319 households, and 238 families residing in the township.  The population density was 33.5 people per square mile (12.9/km2).  There were 329 housing units at an average density of 13.3/sq mi (5.1/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 99.28% White, 0.12% Asian, 0.24% Pacific Islander, and 0.36% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.24% of the population.

There were 319 households, out of which 34.8% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 65.5% were married couples living together, 5.6% had a female householder with no husband present, and 25.1% were non-families. 20.7% of all households were made up of individuals, and 9.7% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.60 and the average family size was 3.04.

In the township the population was spread out, with 25.2% under the age of 18, 5.7% from 18 to 24, 29.2% from 25 to 44, 24.1% from 45 to 64, and 15.9% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 40 years. For every 100 females there were 100.0 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 106.3 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $41,328, and the median income for a family was $46,719. Males had a median income of $30,573 versus $21,818 for females. The per capita income for the township was $18,434.  About 5.3% of families and 8.4% of the population were below the poverty line, including 13.6% of those under age 18 and 4.2% of those age 65 or over.

References

Townships in Mercer County, Pennsylvania

samples.title: Kiho
samples.original_text:
Kiho may refer to:

 Kiho-tumu, the supreme god in the mythology of the Tuamotu archipelago
 Kihō, Mie, a town in Japan
 In the Legend of the Five Rings Collectible Card Game, kiho cards are played as actions, but generate spell effects.  Kiho nearly always require a shugenja or monk (sometimes specifically one or the other) to bow as part of the cost of playing the card
 In the Legend of the Five Rings Role-Playing Game, kiho are complex martial arts techniques learned by monks and sometimes shugenja that have some extraordinary or supernatural effect

People with the given name
, Japanese women's basketball player

Japanese feminine given names

easy_general.text:
"Kiho can refer to different things:

- Kiho-tumu, which is the supreme god in the mythology of the Tuamotu archipelago
- Kihō, Mie, a town in Japan
- In the Legend of the Five Rings Collectible Card Game, kiho cards are played as actions but generate spell effects. They usually require a shugenja or monk to bow before playing the card.
- In the Legend of the Five Rings Role-Playing Game, kiho are complex martial arts techniques learned by monks and sometimes shugenja that have extraordinary or supernatural effects.
- People with the given name Kiho, a Japanese women's basketball player
- Japanese feminine given names"

adult_non_technical.text:
"Kiho is a term that can refer to different things. Here's a breakdown of its various meanings:

1. In the mythology of the Tuamotu archipelago, Kiho-tumu is the supreme god.
2. Kihō, Mie is a town located in Japan.
3. In the game Legend of the Five Rings Collectible Card Game, kiho cards are played as actions, but they have the effects of a spell. They often require a shugenja or a monk to bow as part of the cost of playing the card. A kiho can be played by a shugenja or a monk, and sometimes it's required that one or the other is involved in the action.
4. In the Legend of the Five Rings Role-Playing Game, kiho is a complex martial arts technique learned by monks and sometimes shugenja. These techniques can have extraordinary or supernatural effects.

Additionally, Kiho is also the name of a Japanese women's basketball player and a feminine given name in Japan."

adult_technical.text: The term "kiho" can be found in various contexts, including mythology, geography, and gaming. In mythology, "Kiho-tumu" refers to the supreme deity in the belief system of the Tuamotu archipelago. In geography, "Kihō, Mie" is a town located in Japan. In the Legend of the Five Rings Collectible Card Game, "kiho" cards are played as actions but generate spell-like effects. They often require a shugenja or monk to bow as part of the activation cost. In the Legend of the Five Rings Role-Playing Game, "kiho" are complex martial arts techniques learned by monks and sometimes shugenja, which can have extraordinary or supernatural effects. Additionally, "kiho" can also refer to people with the given name, such as a Japanese women's basketball player, and Japanese feminine given names.

samples.original_text:
SS7 or SS-7 may refer to:

 Signalling System No. 7, a set of telephone signaling protocols
 SS-7 Saddler, the NATO reporting name of R-16 missile

 Super Socket 7, a chip socket introduced by AMD

easy_general.text:
SS7 or SS-7 can refer to different things:

1. Signaling System No. 7: This is a set of rules that help phone systems work together.
2. SS-7 Saddler: This is the name given to a missile called R-16.
3. China Railways SS7: This is a type of electric train used in China.

adult_non_technical.text: SS7 or SS-7 can refer to several different things. It's a set of rules for how phones communicate with each other, a type of missile, and a model of electric train in China. It's also a type of chip socket used in computers.

adult_technical.text:
SS7 or SS-7 can refer to several distinct entities:

1. Signalling System No. 7 (SS7): This is a comprehensive set of telephone signaling protocols that facilitate the exchange of information between different telecommunications networks. SS7 is responsible for managing call setup, routing, and other functions in telecommunication systems.

2. SS-7 Saddler: This is the NATO reporting name for the R-16 missile, a type of surface-to-air missile developed by the Soviet Union. It is designed to engage aircraft and other aerial targets.

3. China Railways SS7: This refers to an electric locomotive model developed by China Railways. The SS7 locomotive is known for its advanced technological features, such as energy efficiency and high performance.

4. Super Socket 7 (SS7): This is a chip socket introduced by AMD, a leading manufacturer of computer processors.

samples.title: Muslim brotherhoods of Senegal
samples.original_text:
This is a list of Sufi orders (Tariqas) in Senegal (and also the Gambia).  They are active Muslim organizations that can also be found in many other parts of Africa and the Islamic world. Their members are mainly Wolofs, Fulas and Tocouleurs.

List
The four largest Muslim brotherhoods in Senegal are:

 The Xaadir (Qādiriyya), the oldest, founded in Baghdad by the Sufi mystic Abdul Qādir al-Jilānī in the 12th century, now pan-Islamic, spread to Senegal in the 18th Century.
 The Tijaniyyah, the largest in membership, founded in Fez, Morocco by the Algerian born Cheikh Sīdī 'Aḥmad at-Tijānī. The order is centered in the city of Tivaouane.
 The Mourides, the richest and most active, founded by the Islamic leader Cheikh Amadou Bamba (1850–1927) of French West Africa, now Senegal. The order is centered in the city of Touba.
 The Layene are a smaller Sufi order, centered at Yoff north of Dakar.

External links
 Review of Sufism and Religious Brotherhoods in Senegal
 BBC:Senegal's Mourides: Islam's mystical entrepreneurs

Senegal
Islam in Senegal
Lists of Muslims
Sufi orders

easy_general.text:
In Senegal and the Gambia, there are special Muslim groups called Sufi orders. These groups are like clubs where people come together to talk about their faith and help each other. The members of these groups are mainly from Wolof, Fulani, and Tocouleur communities.

Here are the four biggest Muslim groups in Senegal:

1. Xaadir (Qādiriyya): This is the oldest group. It was started in Baghdad by a wise man named Abdul Qādir al-Jilānī in the 12th century. Over time, it spread to Senegal in the 18th century.

2. Tijaniyyah: This group has the most members. It was started in Fez, Morocco, by a man named Cheikh Sīdī 'Aḥmad at-Tijānī, who was born in Algeria. The group is based in the city of Tivaouane.

3. Mourides: This group is the richest and most active. It was started by a leader named Cheikh Amadou Bamba, who lived from 1850 to 1927. The group is based in the city of Touba.

4. Layene: This is a smaller group. It is in a place called Yoff, which is north of Dakar.

To learn more, you can read about Sufism and other religious groups in Senegal. You can also find stories about Senegal's Mourides on the BBC website.

adult_non_technical.text:
In Senegal and the Gambia, there are several Muslim groups called Sufi orders. These groups are active and can be found in many other parts of Africa and the Islamic world. The members of these groups are mainly from Wolof, Fulani, and Tukulor communities.

Here are the four largest Muslim groups in Senegal:

1. The Xaadir (Qādiriyya), the oldest group, was founded in Baghdad by Abdul Qādir al-Jilānī in the 12th century. This group spread to Senegal in the 18th century and is now found throughout the Islamic world.
2. The Tijaniyyah, the largest group in membership, was founded in Fez, Morocco, by Cheikh Sīdī 'Aḥmad at-Tijānī, an Algerian. This group is centered in the city of Tivaouane.
3. The Mourides, the richest and most active group, was founded by Cheikh Amadou Bamba (1850-1927) in French West Africa, now Senegal. This group is centered in the city of Touba.
4. The Layene, a smaller group, is centered in Yoff, north of Dakar.

For more information, check out the links below.

samples.title: Stormarn (district)
samples.original_text:
Stormarn () is a district in Schleswig-Holstein, Germany. It is bounded by (from the north and clockwise) the districts of Segeberg and Ostholstein, the city of Lübeck, the district of Lauenburg, and the city-state of Hamburg.

History

In medieval times the name Stormarn was applied to a larger area, of which the present-day district is only the eastern half. It was the home of the Saxon tribe the Sturmarii.

Stormarn became a part of Holstein in the 12th century.  When Schleswig-Holstein became a province of Prussia in 1867, the Prussian administration established the district of Stormarn, with Wandsbek as its capital. In 1937 the southwestern part of the district was incorporated into Hamburg, and the district lost half of its population. Since Wandsbek was now a borough of Hamburg, the capital was moved to Bad Oldesloe after the war. In 1970 Stormarn again lost a substantial portion of its territory, when the city of Norderstedt was founded in order to become a part of the Segeberg district.

Geography

The river Trave runs through the district before entering the city of Lübeck. In the southernmost portion of Stormarn there are the eastern suburbs of the Hamburg metropolitan area.

Coat of arms
The coat of arms displays a white swan, with a crown around its neck, on red ground. The swan has been the heraldic animal of Stormarn since the Middle Ages.

Towns and municipalities

References

External links
Official website (German)

Regions of Schleswig-Holstein

After the 2004 European elections, the group reformed and became Independence/Democracy (IND/DEM).

There were several parties involved in the EDD:

- The June Movement from Denmark had 3 seats.
- The People's Movement against the EU from Denmark had 1 seat.
- The Hunting, Fishing, Nature, Tradition party from France had 6 seats.
- The ChristianUnion – Reformed Political Party from the Netherlands had 3 seats.
- The UK Independence Party from the United Kingdom had 3 seats.
- The Combats Souverainistes party from France had 1 MEP who switched from the Rally for France/UEN group in March 2001.
- The League of Polish Families from Poland joined the group after Poland became a part of the EU in May 2004.

To learn more about this group, you can look at the European Parliament's Annual Accounts of Political Groups, Europe Politique, the European Parliament profile of Jens-Peter Bonde, and the Konrad-Adenauer-Stiftung website.

The term "punt" can refer to various entities across different domains, including boats, places, sports, and other uses. Here is a comprehensive overview of these entities:

### Boats
- **Punt (boat):** A flat-bottomed boat with a square-cut bow, originally developed on the River Thames.
- **Falmouth Quay Punt:** A small sailing vessel hired by ships anchored in Falmouth harbour.
- **Norfolk Punt:** A type of racing dinghy developed in Norfolk.

### Places
- **Land of Punt:** A trading partner of Ancient Egypt, possibly located in the Horn of Africa region.
- **Puntland:** A region in north-eastern Somalia, centered on Garowe in the Nugaal province.

### Sports and Recreation
- **Punt (gridiron football):** A method of kicking a ball in the American or Canadian varieties of football.
- **Punt (Australian football):** A method of kicking a ball in the Australian variety of football.
- **Goal kick in association football:** A type of goal kick in association football.

### Other Uses
- **Punt (surname):** A surname.
- **The Punt or Punt Éireannach:** Also known as the Irish pound, which was the currency of Ireland prior to its changeover to the Euro.
- **El Punt:** A Catalan newspaper.
- **Punt gun:** A type of extremely large shotgun, mounted directly on punt boats.
- **Punt or punty:** A tool used in glassblowing.
- **Punt mark or pontil mark:** A mark left by the glassblowing tool.
- **Punt (wine bottle):** The indented bottom of a wine bottle.
- **Punt:** A colloquial term in British English for bet or wager in gambling.
- **PUNT:** The Spanish acronym of the United National Workers' Party, a former political party in Equatorial Guinea.

### See Also
- **Punter (disambiguation):** A term that may refer to various entities across different domains.
- **Pundt:** A term that may refer to various entities across different domains.

This comprehensive overview highlights the diverse uses of the term "punt" across various domains, providing a clear and concise reference for readers with a technical background in the topic.

samples.title: Start signal
samples.original_text:
In telecommunication, a start signal is a signal that prepares a device to receive data or to perform a function. 

In asynchronous serial communication, start signals are used at the beginning of a character that prepares the receiving device for the reception of the code elements. 

A start signal is limited to one signal element usually having the duration of a unit interval.

References

Telecommunications engineering

easy_general.text:
In telecommunication, a start signal is like a message that tells a device to get ready to receive information or do something. 

When we use asynchronous serial communication, we send a start signal at the beginning of a message to let the receiving device know that it's time to receive the information. 

A start signal is usually very short, lasting only the length of a unit interval.

References

Telecommunications engineering

adult_non_technical.text:
In telecommunication, a start signal is like a signal that gets a device ready to receive information or do something. 

In asynchronous serial communication, these start signals come at the beginning of a character and help the receiving device get ready for the information. 

A start signal is usually just one signal element and lasts as long as a unit interval.

References

Telecommunications engineering

samples.title: Sibley Township, Sibley County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Sibley Township is a township in Sibley County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 353 at the 2000 census.

Sibley Township was organized in 1864.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 35.7 square miles (92.3 km), of which 35.6 square miles (92.2 km)  is land and 0.1 square mile (0.1 km)  (0.14%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 353 people, 115 households, and 90 families residing in the township.  The population density was 9.9 people per square mile (3.8/km).  There were 127 housing units at an average density of 3.6/sq mi (1.4/km).  The racial makeup of the township was 99.43% White, 0.28% African American and 0.28% Asian.

There were 115 households, out of which 43.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 74.8% were married couples living together, 1.7% had a female householder with no husband present, and 21.7% were non-families. 18.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and 3.5% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 3.07 and the average family size was 3.52.

In the township the population was spread out, with 30.9% under the age of 18, 10.5% from 18 to 24, 28.9% from 25 to 44, 21.0% from 45 to 64, and 8.8% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 36 years. For every 100 females, there were 122.0 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 130.2 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $39,125, and the median income for a family was $40,000. Males had a median income of $27,750 versus $20,833 for females. The per capita income for the township was $14,814.  About 8.3% of families and 11.1% of the population were below the poverty line, including 10.8% of those under age 18 and 10.0% of those age 65 or over.

References

Townships in Sibley County, Minnesota
Townships in Minnesota

easy_general.text:

Sibley Township was started in 1864.

The area of Sibley Township is about 36 square miles (92.3 km). Most of it is land, with a tiny bit of water.

In 2000, there were 353 people, 115 families, and 127 homes in Sibley Township. Most people were white (99.43%), with a few African Americans (0.28%) and Asians (0.28%).

Of the 115 families, 43.5% had children under 18 living with them, 74.8% were married couples living together, and 21.7% were single parents. 18.3% of the families were made up of individuals, and 3.5% had someone over 65 living alone.

The population had a mix of ages, with 31% under 18, 11% between 18 and 24, 29% between 25 and 44, 21% between 45 and 64, 8% over 65, and 10% over 65. The average age was 36 years. For every 100 women, there were 122 men.

The average household size was 3.07 people, and the average family size was 3.52 people.

The average household income was $39,125, and the average family income was $40,000. About 8.3% of families and 11.1% of the population lived below the poverty line.

samples.title: Huerfano, New Mexico
samples.original_text:
Huerfano () is a census-designated place (CDP) in San Juan County, New Mexico, United States. The population was 104 at the 2000 census. It is part of the Farmington Metropolitan Statistical Area. Huerfano is named after El Huerfano Mountain, located a mile to the northeast.

Geography
Huerfano is located at  (36.526359, -108.031135).

According to the United States Census Bureau, the CDP has a total area of , all land.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 104 people, 28 households, and 22 families residing in the CDP. The population density was 3.9 people per square mile (1.5/km2). There were 36 housing units at an average density of 1.3 per square mile (0.5/km2). The racial makeup of the CDP was 99.04% Native American and 0.96% White.

There were 28 households, out of which 39.3% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 57.1% were married couples living together, 17.9% had a female householder with no husband present, and 21.4% were non-families. 14.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and none had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 3.71 and the average family size was 4.32.

In the CDP, the population was spread out, with 38.5% under the age of 18, 7.7% from 18 to 24, 25.0% from 25 to 44, 20.2% from 45 to 64, and 8.7% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 30 years. For every 100 females, there were 85.7 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 82.9 males.

The median income for a household in the CDP was $24,583, and the median income for a family was $24,583. Males had a median income of $18,750 versus $13,750 for females. The per capita income for the CDP was $7,333. None of the population is below the poverty line.

Education
The community of Huerfano is part of the Bloomfield School District.

References

Census-designated places in San Juan County, New Mexico
Census-designated places in New Mexico

samples.title: FTS2000
samples.original_text:
Federal Telecommunications System 2000 (FTS2000) is a long distance telecommunications service for the United States federal government, including services such as switched voice service for voice or data up to 4.8 kbit/s, switched data at 56 kbit/s and 64 kbit/s, switched digital integrated service for voice, data, image, and video up to 1.544 Mbit/s, packet switched service for data in packet form, video transmission for both compressed and wideband video, and dedicated point-to-point private line for voice and data. 

Note 1:  Use of FTS2000 contract services is mandatory for use by U.S. Government agencies for all acquisitions subject to 40 U.S.C. 759. 

Note 2:  No U.S. Government information processing equipment or customer premises equipment other than that which are required to provide an FTS2000 service are furnished. 

Note 3:  The FTS2000 contractors will be required to provide service directly to an agency's terminal equipment interface. For example, the FTS2000 contractor might provide a terminal adapter to an agency location in order to connect FTS2000 ISDN services to the agency's terminal equipment. 

Note 4:  GSA awarded two 10-year, fixed-price contracts covering FTS2000 services on December 7, 1988. 

Note 5:  The Warner Amendment excludes the mandatory use of FTS2000 in instances related to maximum security.
FTS2000 was completed in 2000, then replaced by FTS2001, and thereafter, in 2008, by Networx.

References
FTS2000 was completed in 2000, and was replaced by FTS2001.

Telecommunication services
Telecommunications in the United States

easy_general.text:
The Federal Telecommunications System 2000 (FTS2000) is a long-distance phone service for the U.S. federal government. It offers different types of services, including:

- A voice or data service that can handle up to 4.8 kbit/s
- A data service that can handle 56 kbit/s and 64 kbit/s
- A service that combines voice, data, image, and video up to 1.544 Mbit/s
- A service that sends data in packets
- A service that can send compressed and wideband video
- A private line for voice and data

FTS2000 is mandatory for U.S. Government agencies to use for all acquisitions subject to 40 U.S.C. 759. This means that government agencies have to use FTS2000 when they buy things for their work.

FTS2000 does not provide any government equipment except what is needed for the FTS2000 service.

FTS2000 contractors need to connect their services directly to the agency's equipment. For example, they might provide a terminal adapter to connect the agency's equipment to the FTS2000 service.

GSA awarded two 10-year contracts for FTS2000 services on December 7, 1988.

The Warner Amendment excludes the mandatory use of FTS2000 in high security situations.

FTS2000 was completed in 2000 and replaced by FTS2001. In 2008, FTS2001 was replaced by Networx.

References:
FTS2000 was completed in 2000 and replaced by FTS2001.
Telecommunication services
Telecommunications in the United States

adult_non_technical.text:
The Federal Telecommunications System 2000 (FTS2000) is a long-distance phone service used by the U.S. federal government. It offers different types of services, like phone calls for voice or data up to 4.8 kbit/s, data transmission at 56 kbit/s and 64 kbit/s, and digital integrated services for voice, data, images, and video up to 1.544 Mbit/s. It also provides services for sending data in packets, video transmission for both compressed and wideband video, and dedicated point-to-point private lines for voice and data communication.

Using FTS2000 is mandatory for all U.S. government agencies for certain acquisitions related to 40 U.S.C. 759. This means that these agencies have to use FTS2000 for specific types of purchases.

FTS2000 does not provide any U.S. government information processing equipment or customer premises equipment other than what is needed to provide the FTS2000 service.

The FTS2000 contractors have to connect their services directly to the agency's equipment. For example, they might provide a device called a "terminal adapter" to an agency location to help connect the FTS2000 ISDN services to the agency's equipment.

The General Services Administration (GSA) awarded two 10-year, fixed-price contracts for FTS2000 services on December 7, 1988.

The Warner Amendment excludes the mandatory use of FTS2000 in cases where maximum security is required.

FTS2000 was completed in 2000 and replaced by FTS2001. In 2008, FTS2001 was replaced by Networx.

References:
FTS2000 was completed in 2000 and replaced by FTS2001.

Telecommunication services
Telecommunications in the United States

adult_technical.text:
The Federal Telecommunications System 2000 (FTS2000) is a comprehensive long-distance telecommunications service designed for the United States federal government. It offers a range of services, including switched voice and data transmission up to 4.8 kbit/s, switched data services at 56 kbit/s and 64 kbit/s, switched digital integrated services for voice, data, image, and video up to 1.544 Mbit/s, packet switched services for data transmission, video transmission for both compressed and wideband video, and dedicated point-to-point private lines for voice and data.

FTS2000 is a mandatory service for U.S. Government agencies for all acquisitions subject to 40 U.S.C. 759. This means that agencies must use FTS2000 services for their telecommunications needs. Additionally, no U.S. Government information processing equipment or customer premises equipment other than that which is required to provide an FTS2000 service are furnished.

FTS2000 contractors are required to provide service directly to an agency's terminal equipment interface. For example, an FTS2000 contractor might provide a terminal adapter to an agency location to connect FTS2000 ISDN services to the agency's terminal equipment.

GSA awarded two 10-year, fixed-price contracts covering FTS2000 services on December 7, 1988. The Warner Amendment excludes the mandatory use of FTS2000 in instances related to maximum security.

FTS2000 was completed in 2000 and replaced by FTS2001. In 2008, FTS2001 was replaced by Networx.

References
FTS2000 was completed in 2000, and was replaced by FTS2001.

Telecommunication services
Telecommunications in the United States

samples.title: Battle of Grotniki
samples.original_text:
The Battle of Grotniki took place on 4 May 1439 in the vicinity of Grotniki Duże, a village near Nowy Korczyn, currently in Świętokrzyskie Voivodeship. 

The battle was fought between the Hussite confederates under Spytko III of Melsztyn against the royal forces of King Władysław III of Poland under Hińcza of Rogów and  de facto regent bishop Zbigniew Oleśnicki. The defeat of the non-Catholic forces marked the end of militant Hussite movement in Poland and the beginning of a complete consolidation of power in the Polish Kingdom, led by bishop Zbigniew.

Bibliography
Jan Długosz, Annales seu Cronicae incliti regni Poloniae, opera venerabili domini Ioanni Dlugossi, liber XI i XII, Warsaw 2001, page 202 - 206.
Secondary sources
Anna Sochacka "Konfederacja Spytka z Melsztyna z 1439r. Rozgrywka polityczna, czy ruch ideologiczny? "  Rocznik Lubelski, vol XVI, Lublin 1973.

Grotniki

easy_general.text:
On May 4, 1439, a big fight took place near a village called Grotniki Duże, which is close to a town called Nowy Korczyn. The fight was between two groups of people: one group was led by a man named Spytko III of Melsztyn, and the other group was led by King Władysław III of Poland. The group following Spytko III was called the Hussite confederates, and they were fighting because they disagreed with the Catholic Church.

After the fight, the Hussite confederates lost, and this defeat marked the end of their movement in Poland. The king's group, led by Bishop Zbigniew Oleśnicki, then gained complete power in Poland.

adult_non_technical.text: On May 4, 1439, a big fight took place near a village called Grotniki Duże, which is close to a town called Nowy Korczyn. The fight was between two groups of people. One group was led by a man named Spytko III of Melsztyn, and they were part of the Hussite movement. The other group was led by King Władysław III of Poland and a bishop named Zbigniew Oleśnicki. The fight was important because it marked the end of the Hussite movement in Poland and the beginning of a time when the Polish Kingdom became more powerful.

The conflict was fought between the Hussite confederates, led by Spytko III of Melsztyn, and the royal forces of King Władysław III of Poland, commanded by Hińcza of Rogów and the de facto regent bishop Zbigniew Oleśnicki. The defeat of the non-Catholic forces marked the end of the militant Hussite movement in Poland and the beginning of a complete consolidation of power in the Polish Kingdom, led by Bishop Zbigniew.

samples.title: Dea Tacita
samples.original_text:
In Roman mythology, Dea Tacita ("the silent goddess") was a goddess of the dead. Ovid's Fasti includes a passage describing a rite propitiating Dea Tacita in order to "seal up hostile mouths / and unfriendly tongue" at Feralia on 21 February. In later times, she was equated with the naiad Larunda.  In this guise, Dea Tacita was worshipped at a festival called Larentalia on 23 December. Goddesses Mutae Tacitae were invoked to destroy a hated person: in an inscription from Cambodunum in Raetia, someone asks "ut mutus sit Quartus" and "erret fugiens ut mus". These silent goddesses are the personification of terror of obscurity. Plutarch, who describes Tacita as a Muse, states that Numa Pompilius credited Tacita for his oracular insight and taught the Romans to worship her.

References

Roman goddesses
Death goddesses

easy_general.text: In Roman mythology, Dea Tacita, the silent goddess, was a goddess of the dead. Ovid wrote about a special ritual to make people stop saying mean things to each other during a festival called Feralia, held on the 21 February. In later times, Dea Tacita was also associated with a water spirit called Larunda. People would worship her at another festival called Larentalia on the 23 December. There were also goddesses called Mutae Tacitae who were asked to make a person they didn't like stop talking. These goddesses were thought to be the personification of being unknown. Plutarch, a famous writer, said that Numa Pompilius, a Roman king, credited Dea Tacita for his wisdom and taught the Romans to worship her.

adult_non_technical.text:
In Roman mythology, there was a goddess named Dea Tacita, which means "the silent goddess." She was a goddess of the dead, and the Romans believed she had the power to make people stop talking if they were being mean or unfriendly. On a special day called Feralia, which was on February 21, the Romans would perform a ritual to ask Dea Tacita to "seal up hostile and unfriendly mouths."

Later on, Dea Tacita was also associated with a naiad, which is a water-related spirit. In this form, she was worshipped on December 23 as a part of a festival called Larentalia. The Romans also invoked other goddesses called Mutae Tacitae, who were believed to be able to silence someone they didn't like. In an inscription from a place called Cambodunum in Raetia, someone asked these goddesses to make a person named Quartus stop talking and to run away like a mouse.

These silent goddesses were thought to represent the fear of being unknown or forgotten. Plutarch, a Roman historian, described Tacita as a Muse, which is a goddess associated with art and inspiration. He said that Numa Pompilius, a Roman king, believed that Tacita gave him special wisdom and taught the Romans how to worship her.

References:
Roman goddesses
Death goddesses

adult_technical.text:
In Roman mythology, Dea Tacita, or "the silent goddess," was a deity associated with the dead. Ovid's Fasti contains a passage detailing a ritual to appease Dea Tacita in order to "silence hostile and unfriendly voices" during the Feralia on February 21. In later periods, Dea Tacita was identified with the naiad Larunda, and in this form was worshipped at the Larentalia festival on December 23. The silent goddesses Mutae Tacitae were invoked to silence a person, as seen in an inscription found in Cambodunum, Raetia, where someone requests "that Quartus be silent" and "that a mouse run away." These goddesses embody the fear of obscurity. Plutarch, who describes Tacita as a Muse, states that Numa Pompilius credited Tacita for his oracular insight and taught the Romans to worship her.

References

Roman goddesses
Death goddesses

samples.title: IBM 3720
samples.original_text:
The IBM 3720 was a communications controller (front-end processor) made by IBM, suitable for use with IBM System/390. The 3720, introduced in 1986, was capable of supporting up to 60 communications lines, and was a smaller version of the 3725.  Official service support was withdrawn in 1999 in favour of the IBM 3745.

The IBM 3720 is unrelated to the similarly-numbered IBM 3270 display terminal system.

It was a smaller version of another device called the 3725. IBM stopped supporting this device in 1999 and started using a newer one called the 3745 instead. The IBM 3720 is not related to another IBM device called the 3270.

samples.title: PhpWiki
samples.original_text:
PhpWiki is a web-based wiki software application.
It began as a clone of WikiWikiWeb and was the first wiki written in PHP.
PhpWiki has been used to edit and format paper books for publication.

History
The first version, by Steve Wainstead, was released in December 1999. It was the first Wiki written in PHP to be publicly released. This version required PHP 3.x and only supported DBM files. 
It was a feature-for-feature reimplementation of the original WikiWikiWeb at c2.com.

In early 2000 Arno Hollosi added a second database library to allow running PhpWiki on MySQL.
From then on more features were added and contributions to the software increased, adding features such as a templating system, color diffs, rewrites of the rendering engine and much more. Arno was interested in running a wiki for the game Go.

Jeff Dairiki was the next major contributor, and soon headed the project for the next few years, followed up by Reini Urban up to 1.4, and then Marc-Etienne Vargenau since 1.5.

Releases 

With version 1.4.0 Wikicreole 1.0 including additions and MediaWiki markup syntax are supported. In version 1.5.0 PHP 4 support was deprecated.

Versions 1.5.x are compatible with PHP 5.3, 5.4 et 5.5. Code is generated in HTML5 and CSS3.

Version 1.6.0 is compatible from PHP 5.3.3 to PHP 8.0. Code is generated in HTML5 and CSS3 with
ARIA roles.

Version 1.6.1 adds compatibility with PHP 8.1.

See also

 List of wiki software
 Comparison of wiki software

References

External links
 
 Release Notes

Cross-platform free software
Free wiki software
Free software programmed in PHP
Software clones

easy_general.text:
PhpWiki is a web-based software that helps people create and edit websites. It started as a copy of another popular software called WikiWikiWeb and was the first one written in PHP. PhpWiki has been used to edit and format books for publication.

The first version of PhpWiki was created by Steve Wainstead and released in December 1999. It was the first software written in PHP to be publicly available. This version needed PHP 3.x and only worked with something called DBM files. It had all the features of the original WikiWikiWeb at c2.com.

In early 2000, Arno Hollosi added a new feature called a second database library, which allowed PhpWiki to work with something called MySQL. From then on, more features were added and more people contributed to the software. They added things like a system for creating templates, color differences, and changes to the way the software displays the pages.

Jeff Dairiki was the next major contributor and took over the project for a few years. He was followed by Reini Urban up to version 1.4, and then Marc-Etienne Vargenau since version 1.5.

In version 1.4.0, a new feature called Wikicreole 1.0 was added, along with another feature called MediaWiki markup syntax. In version 1.5.0, support for PHP 4 was removed.

Versions 1.5.x are compatible with PHP 5.3, 5.4, and 5.5 and generate code in HTML5 and CSS3. Version 1.6.0 is compatible with PHP 5.3.3 to PHP 8.0 and generates code in HTML5 and CSS3 with something called ARIA roles.

Version 1.6.1 adds compatibility with PHP 8.1.

You can learn more about other wiki software in a list of wiki software and a comparison of wiki software.

References and external links are available for more information.

PhpWiki is a cross-platform free software, a free wiki software, a free software programmed in PHP, and a software clone.

adult_non_technical.text:
PhpWiki is a web-based software that allows users to create and edit web pages. It started as a copy of another popular software called WikiWikiWeb and was the first one written in a language called PHP. PhpWiki has been used to edit and format paper books for publication.

The first version of PhpWiki was created by Steve Wainstead and released in December 1999. It was the first wiki written in PHP to be publicly available. This version required PHP 3.x and only supported a format called DBM files. It had all the features of the original WikiWikiWeb software at c2.com.

In early 2000, Arno Hollosi added a new database library called MySQL, which allowed PhpWiki to run on a different database. From then on, more features were added and more people contributed to the software. These features included a system for creating templates, color differences, and changes to the rendering engine. Arno was interested in creating a wiki for the game Go.

Jeff Dairiki was the next major contributor and took over the project for a few years. He was followed by Reini Urban up to version 1.4, and then Marc-Etienne Vargenau since version 1.5.

In version 1.4.0, PhpWiki added support for a new feature called Wikicreole 1.0, which included additional features and a format called MediaWiki markup syntax. In version 1.5.0, support for PHP 4 was removed.

Versions 1.5.x are compatible with PHP 5.3, 5.4, and 5.5 and generate code in HTML5 and CSS3. Version 1.6.0 is compatible with PHP 5.3.3 to PHP 8.0 and generates code in HTML5 and CSS3 with a feature called ARIA roles. Version 1.6.1 adds compatibility with PHP 8.1.

adult_technical.text:
PhpWiki is a web-based wiki software application that originated as a clone of the original WikiWikiWeb. It was the first wiki written in PHP and has been utilized for editing and formatting paper books for publication.

History
The first version of PhpWiki, developed by Steve Wainstead, was released in December 1999. It was the first wiki written in PHP to be publicly released. This version required PHP 3.x and only supported DBM files. It was a feature-for-feature reimplementation of the original WikiWikiWeb at c2.com.

In early 2000, Arno Hollosi added a second database library to enable running PhpWiki on MySQL. From then on, more features were added and contributions to the software increased, including a templating system, color diffs, rewrites of the rendering engine, and much more. Arno was interested in running a wiki for the game Go.

Jeff Dairiki was the next major contributor, and soon headed the project for the next few years, followed up by Reini Urban up to 1.4, and then Marc-Etienne Vargenau since 1.5.

Releases
Starting with version 1.4.0, Wikicreole 1.0 and MediaWiki markup syntax were supported. In version 1.5.0, PHP 4 support was deprecated.

Versions 1.5.x are compatible with PHP 5.3, 5.4, and 5.5. Code is generated in HTML5 and CSS3.

Version 1.6.0 is compatible from PHP 5.3.3 to PHP 8.0. Code is generated in HTML5 and CSS3 with ARIA roles.

Version 1.6.1 adds compatibility with PHP 8.1.

samples.title: Wohpe
samples.original_text:
In Lakota mythology, Wóȟpe (less correctly spelled "Wohpe") is a spirit of peace, the daughter of Wi and the Moon, Haŋhépi-Wi. She is the wife of the south wind. When she visited the Earth, she gave the Lakota people a pipe as a symbol of peace. Later, Wóȟpe became conflated with White Buffalo Calf Woman. An alternative name for Wóȟpe is Ptehíŋčalasaŋwiŋ. 

As a symbol of Wophe's coming to earth she is often associated with falling stars.

See also
Dignity (statue)

Lakota spirit beings
Peace goddesses
Lakota culture

When she visited the Earth, she gave the Lakota people a pipe as a symbol of peace. Later, Wóȟpe became known as White Buffalo Calf Woman. Another name for Wóȟpe is Ptehíŋčalasaŋwiŋ.

Wóȟpe is often shown with falling stars as a symbol of her coming to Earth.

samples.title: Tangotango
samples.original_text:
In Māori mythology, Tangotango (sometimes called Hāpai) was a celestial woman who fell in love with the great hero Tāwhaki and came to earth to become his wife.  After bearing him a daughter, Arahuta, they quarreled and she returned to heaven.  Tāwhaki and his brother set out on a great adventure to find her.

Tāwhaki and his brother went on a big adventure to find her.

samples.title: Arthur J. Stone
samples.original_text:
Arthur J. Stone (1847–1938), a leading American silversmith, was born, trained and worked in Sheffield, England, and Edinburgh, Scotland, before travelling to the United States in 1884. He was one of the last silversmiths in America to train apprentices to carry out designs in hand-wrought silver. In 1901, Stone set up a workshop in Gardner, Massachusetts which operated under his name until its sale in 1937 to Henry Heywood. Heywood was a Gardner businessman, who renamed it The Stone Silver Shop, and later, Stone Associates. Heywood died in 1945. His sons Henry, Jr. and Jerome ran Stone Associates until 1957.

One of the silversmiths in Arthur Stone's shop was George Porter Blanchard, father of silversmith Porter Blanchard.

easy_general.text: Arthur J. Stone was a famous American silversmith who was born in 1847 and lived until 1938. He grew up in England and Scotland before moving to the United States in 1884. Stone was one of the last silversmiths in America to teach apprentices how to make beautiful silver designs with their hands. In 1901, he opened a workshop in Gardner, Massachusetts, where he worked until 1937. After that, his friend, Henry Heywood, bought the workshop and renamed it The Stone Silver Shop. Heywood's sons continued to run the shop until 1957.

samples.title: South Manheim Township, Schuylkill County, Pennsylvania
samples.original_text:
South Manheim Township is a township in Schuylkill County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 2,191 at the 2000 census. It was created in 1845 by dividing Manheim Township into South Manheim and North Manheim Townships.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 21.0 square miles (54.3 km), of which, 20.6 square miles (53.3 km) of it is land and 0.4 square miles (1.0 km) of it (1.77%) is water.

Demographics

At the 2000 census there were 2,191 people, 796 households, and 643 families living in the township.  The population density was 106.4 people per square mile (41.1/km).  There were 966 housing units at an average density of 46.9/sq mi (18.1/km).  The racial makeup of the township was 98.31% White, 0.46% African American, 0.23% Asian, 0.37% from other races, and 0.64% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.68%.

Of the 796 households 35.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 74.0% were married couples living together, 5.0% had a female householder with no husband present, and 19.2% were non-families. 14.9% of households were one person and 6.3% were one person aged 65 or older.  The average household size was 2.75 and the average family size was 3.07.

The age distribution was 25.9% under the age of 18, 5.3% from 18 to 24, 29.8% from 25 to 44, 25.8% from 45 to 64, and 13.1% 65 or older.  The median age was 39 years. For every 100 females, there were 97.6 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 97.9 males.

The median household income was $46,786 and the median family income  was $49,757. Males had a median income of $37,629 versus $26,375 for females. The per capita income for the township was $19,638.  About 2.0% of families and 3.0% of the population were below the poverty line, including 2.2% of those under age 18 and 4.5% of those age 65 or over.

References

Townships in Schuylkill County, Pennsylvania
Townships in Pennsylvania

samples.title: 690s BC
samples.original_text:
This article concerns the period 699 BC – 690 BC.

Events and trends
 699 BC—Khallushu succeeds Shuttir-Nakhkhunte as king of the Elamite Empire.
 697 BC—Birth of Duke Wen of Jin in China.
 697 BC—Death of King Huan of Zhou in China.
 697 BC—Hezekiah succeeded by Manasseh as king of Judah.
 696 BC—King Zhuang of Zhou begins his reign in China.
 696 BC—The Cimmerians ravage Phrygia, possible migration of the Armenians.
 696 BC—Pantacles of Athens wins the stadion race at the 21st Olympic Games.
 692 BC—Karib'il Watar of Saba' is recorded as having given "gifts" (tribute) to King Sennacherib of Assyria.
 692 BC—Pantacles wins the stadion race for a second time and the diaulos at the 22nd Olympic Games.
 691 BC—King Sennacherib of Assyria defeats king Humban-nimena of Elam in the Battle of Halule.
 690 BC—Taharqa, a king of the Twenty-fifth Dynasty, ascends the throne of Egypt (approximate date)
  690 BC-664 BC—Sphinx of Taharqa, from Temple T, Kawa, Nubia, is made. Twenty-fifth Dynasty of Egypt. It is now kept at The British Museum, London.
 c. 690 BC—Death of Manava, author of the Indian geometric text of Sulba Sutras.
 690s BC—W'rn Hywt of D'mt in Ethiopia appears in the inscriptional record and mentions the king of Saba', Karib'il Watar.

Significant people

References

samples.title: Essunga Municipality
samples.original_text:
Essunga Municipality (Essunga kommun) is a municipality in Västra Götaland County in western Sweden. Its seat is located in the town of Nossebro.

The 1952 municipal reform in Sweden saw the creation of Essunga Municipality out of eight original entities. In 1974 it was dissolved and part of Vara Municipality until 1983, when it was reestablished within the boundaries of 1952. The village of Essunga is a minor settlement just east of Nossebro.

References

Skaraborg

easy_general.text:

In 1952, Essunga Municipality was created by combining eight smaller areas. In 1974, it was changed and became part of another place called Vara. But in 1983, Essunga became its own place once again. The village of Essunga is a small area just east of Nossebro.

adult_non_technical.text: Essunga Municipality is a small area in Västra Götaland County, located in western Sweden. The main town is called Nossebro. This area was created in 1952 by combining eight smaller areas. In 1974, it became part of another area called Vara, but it was made separate in 1983. There is a small village called Essunga just east of Nossebro.

adult_technical.text:
Essunga Municipality, officially known as Essunga kommun, is a municipality located in Västra Götaland County in western Sweden. The administrative center of Essunga is the town of Nossebro.

In 1952, a significant municipal reform took place in Sweden, resulting in the creation of Essunga Municipality from eight original entities. However, in 1974, Essunga was dissolved and became part of Vara Municipality. This situation lasted until 1983, when Essunga was reestablished within its original boundaries from 1952. The village of Essunga is a minor settlement situated just east of Nossebro.
