samples.title: Thematic role
samples.original_text:
Thematic role is a linguistic notion, which may refer to:

 Theta role (in syntax or at the syntax-semantics interface), the formal device for representing syntactic argument structure—the number and type of noun phrases—required syntactically by a particular verb
 Thematic relation (in semantics), a term to express the role that a noun phrase plays with respect to the action or state described by a governing verb

easy_general.text: In language, thematic role refers to the part a word plays in a sentence. For example, in the sentence "The boy threw the ball," "boy" is the doer of the action, and "ball" is the receiver of the action. These roles help us understand the meaning of the sentence.

adult_non_technical.text: In language, we use the term "thematic role" to describe the part a word plays in a sentence.

adult_technical.text:
Thematic role is a fundamental concept in linguistics, encompassing two distinct but related ideas: theta role and thematic relation within the realms of syntax and semantics respectively.

A theta role is a formal device used to represent the syntactic argument structure - the number and type of noun phrases required by a particular verb. This concept is crucial in understanding the structural organization of sentences.

In contrast, thematic relation is a semantic term that expresses the role a noun phrase plays in relation to the action or state described by a governing verb. It helps clarify the relationship between the verb and the noun phrases associated with it.

samples.title: Windsor Township, Traverse County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Windsor Township is a township in Traverse County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 54 at the 2000 census.

History
Windsor Township was organized in 1881.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 21.8 square miles (56.4 km), of which 15.7 square miles (40.6 km) is land and 6.1 square miles (15.8 km) (28.04%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 54 people, 23 households, and 18 families residing in the township. The population density was 3.4 people per square mile (1.3/km). There were 147 housing units at an average density of 9.4/sq mi (3.6/km). The racial makeup of the township was 100.00% White.

There were 23 households, out of which 30.4% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 73.9% were married couples living together, and 21.7% were non-families. 21.7% of all households were made up of individuals, and none had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.35 and the average family size was 2.72.

In the township the population was spread out, with 24.1% under the age of 18, 1.9% from 18 to 24, 24.1% from 25 to 44, 29.6% from 45 to 64, and 20.4% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 45 years. For every 100 females, there were 125.0 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 127.8 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $26,250, and the median income for a family was $26,250. Males had a median income of $26,250 versus $6,250 for females. The per capita income for the township was $15,582. samples.title: L'inglesou
samples.original_text:
L'inglesou is a Vodou loa who lives in the wild areas of Haiti and kills anyone who offends him.

Portrayal
He executes judgment on those who can't keep their word, including houngans and mamboes who can't keep the secrets of voodoo from the uninitiated. L'inglesou is feared and respected by all. He almost never comes in possession, but when he does, he must be served correctly; otherwise the houngan or mambo will be cruelly punished.

When L'inglesou comes in possession, he only eats glasses and razor blades and drinks warm bull blood. His color is red. He is syncretized with the Sacred Heart of Jesus. He likes sharp objects such as knives, scissors, barbed wire, razor blades, and, in general, anything that will rip or tear flesh.

References

Haitian Vodou gods

easy_general.text:
L'inglesou is a Vodou spirit who lives in the wild areas of Haiti. He is feared and respected by everyone, and he kills anyone who offends him. L'inglesou is a judge who punishes people who can't keep their promises, including houngans and mamboes who can't keep the secrets of Vodou from those who don't know about it. L'inglesou is not often seen, but when he is, he must be treated correctly, or the houngan or mambo will be punished.

When L'inglesou is present, he only eats glasses and razor blades and drinks warm bull blood. His color is red, and he is associated with the Sacred Heart of Jesus. He likes sharp objects like knives, scissors, barbed wire, razor blades, and anything else that can cut or tear flesh.

References

Haitian Vodou gods

adult_non_technical.text:
L'inglesou is a powerful spirit in Haitian Vodou, who lives in the wild areas of Haiti. He is very serious and will punish anyone who breaks their word or reveals the secrets of Vodou to those who are not supposed to know. L'inglesou is feared and respected by all, and he rarely comes to possess someone, but when he does, he must be treated with respect, or the houngan or mambo will be severely punished.

When L'inglesou comes to possess someone, he only eats sharp objects like glasses and razor blades, and drinks warm bull blood. His favorite color is red, and he is associated with the Sacred Heart of Jesus. He likes sharp objects like knives, scissors, barbed wire, razor blades, and anything else that can cut or tear flesh.

References

Haitian Vodou gods

adult_technical.text:
L'inglesou is a Vodou loa who resides in the wild areas of Haiti and is known to punish those who offend him. L'inglesou's primary role is to execute judgment on individuals who fail to keep their word, such as houngans and mamboes who struggle to maintain the secrecy of Vodou practices from the uninitiated. L'inglesou is both feared and respected by the Vodou community. He rarely appears in possession, but when he does, he must be properly served to avoid severe punishment for the houngan or mambo.

During possession, L'inglesou consumes only glasses and razor blades, and drinks warm bull blood. His color is red, and he is syncretized with the Sacred Heart of Jesus. He is drawn to sharp objects such as knives, scissors, barbed wire, razor blades, and other items that can rip or tear flesh.

References:
Haitian Vodou gods

The term "Fairlight" can refer to various entities across different domains, including geographical locations, educational institutions, and technological products. Here is a comprehensive overview of the various uses of "Fairlight":

In places:
1. Fairlight, East Sussex: A village situated east of Hastings in southern England, United Kingdom.
2. Fairlight Primary and Nursery School: A primary school located in Brighton, England.
3. Fairlight, New South Wales: A suburb of Sydney, Australia.
4. Fairlight, Saskatchewan: A community in Canada.

In other uses:
1. Fairlight (company): An Australian technology company that produced synthesizers and digital audio tools.
2. Fairlight CMI: The first digital sampling synthesizer, a groundbreaking innovation in the field of music technology.
3. Fairlight (group): A Commodore 64, Amiga, and PC demo group, as well as a warez group.
4. Fairlight (video game): A computer game developed by Bo Jangeborg and published by The Edge.
5. Fairlight (ferry): A Sydney to Manly ferry that operated between 1878 and 1914.

1. Fairlight Cove: A small village on the East Sussex coast.
2. Fairlight Glen: A nudist beach on the East Sussex coast.

easy_general.text:
Dornier is a name that can refer to different things:

2. Dornier Flugzeugwerke: This is a German company that makes airplanes. It was started by Claudius Dornier in 1914.

3. Dornier Consulting: This is a company that helps businesses with their projects and plans.

4. Fairchild-Dornier: In 1996, a company called Fairchild bought Dornier's assets and used this name. Fairchild also made airplanes.

5. Lindauer Dornier: This is a German company that makes machines for making clothes.

6. Dornier Wines: This is a winery in South Africa where they make wine.

If you want to learn about the airplanes made by Dornier, you can look at the list of military airplanes made by German companies.

samples.title: Carroll Township, Washington County, Pennsylvania
samples.original_text:
Carroll Township is a township in Washington County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 5,640 at the 2010 census.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , of which,  of it is land and  of it (1.96%) is water.

Demographics
At the 2000 census there were 5,677 people, 2,265 households, and 1,701 families living in the township.  The population density was 420.4 people per square mile (162.4/km2).  There were 2,344 housing units at an average density of 173.6/sq mi (67.0/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 98.26% White, 1.09% African American, 0.05% Native American, 0.11% Asian, 0.05% Pacific Islander, 0.21% from other races, and 0.23% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.74%.

Of the 2,265 households 26.0% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 63.4% were married couples living together, 7.8% had a female householder with no husband present, and 24.9% were non-families. 22.3% of households were one person and 13.2% were one person aged 65 or older.  The average household size was 2.45 and the average family size was 2.85.

The age distribution was 19.6% under the age of 18, 4.9% from 18 to 24, 24.1% from 25 to 44, 26.8% from 45 to 64, and 24.7% 65 or older.  The median age was 46 years. For every 100 females, there were 93.0 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 90.7 males.

The median household income was $43,347 and the median family income  was $52,526. Males had a median income of $40,970 versus $24,698 for females. The per capita income for the township was $20,380.  About 4.8% of families and 6.4% of the population were below the poverty line, including 6.8% of those under age 18 and 8.9% of those age 65 or over.

In the city the population was spread out, with 17.3% under the age of 18, 5.8% from 18 to 24, 28.8% from 25 to 44, 25.0% from 45 to 64, and 23.1% who were 65 years of age or older. samples.title: Skarsterlân
samples.original_text:
Skarsterlân (;  ) is a former municipality in the province of Friesland in the Netherlands. The municipality was created 1 January 1984 by merging the municipalities of Doniawerstal and Haskerland, the part of Utingeradeel consisting of the villages Akmarijp and Terkaple and the village Nieuwebrug that used to belong to Heerenveen. City hall was located in Joure. On 1 January 2014 it merged with the municipalities of Lemsterland and Gaasterlân-Sleat to form the new municipality De Fryske Marren.

At first, the Dutch name Scharsterland was chosen, but as of 1 March 1985, the West Frisian name Skarsterlân was adopted and the Dutch name became obsolete.

Population centres 

Akmarijp, Boornzwaag, Broek, Dijken, Doniaga, Goingarijp, Haskerdijken, Haskerhorne, Idskenhuizen, Joure, Langweer, Legemeer, Nieuwebrug, Nijehaske, Oldeouwer, Oudehaske, Ouwster-Nijega, Ouwsterhaule, Rohel, Rotstergast, Rotsterhaule, Rottum, Scharsterbrug, Sint Nicolaasga, Sintjohannesga, Snikzwaag, Terkaple, Teroele, Tjerkgaast and Vegelinsoord.

References

easy_general.text: Skarsterlân was a town in the Netherlands, located in the province of Friesland. It was formed in 1984 when several smaller towns joined together. The town was first called Scharsterland, but later changed its name to Skarsterlân. In 2014, the town merged with other towns to form a new town called De Fryske Marren.

adult_non_technical.text:
Skarsterlân was a town in the province of Friesland in the Netherlands. It was formed on 1 January 1984 by combining the towns of Doniawerstal and Haskerland, a part of Utingeradeel with the villages of Akmarijp and Terkaple, and the village of Nieuwebrug, which previously belonged to Heerenveen. The town office was located in Joure. On 1 January 2014, it merged with the towns of Lemsterland and Gaasterlân-Sleat to form a new town called De Fryske Marren.

At first, the town was called Scharsterland in Dutch, but on 1 March 1985, it was changed to the West Frisian name Skarsterlân. The Dutch name was no longer used.

The main places in Skarsterlân were: Akmarijp, Boornzwaag, Broek, Dijken, Doniaga, Goingarijp, Haskerdijken, Haskerhorne, Idskenhuizen, Joure, Langweer, Legemeer, Nieuwebrug, Nijehaske, Oldeouwer, Oudehaske, Ouwster-Nijega, Ouwsterhaule, Rohel, Rotstergast, Rotsterhaule, Rottum, Scharsterbrug, Sint Nicolaasga, Sintjohannesga, Snikzwaag, Terkaple, Teroele, Tjerkgaast, and Vegelinsoord.

adult_technical.text:
Skarsterlân, a former municipality in the province of Friesland in the Netherlands, was established on January 1, 1984, through the merger of the municipalities of Doniawerstal and Haskerland, the part of Utingeradeel comprising the villages of Akmarijp and Terkaple, and the village of Nieuwebrug, which previously belonged to Heerenveen. The administrative center of the municipality was located in Joure. On January 1, 2014, Skarsterlân merged with the municipalities of Lemsterland and Gaasterlân-Sleat to form the new municipality De Fryske Marren.

Initially, the Dutch name Scharsterland was chosen, but on March 1, 1985, the West Frisian name Skarsterlân was adopted, rendering the Dutch name obsolete.

Population centers within Skarsterlân included Akmarijp, Boornzwaag, Broek, Dijken, Doniaga, Goingarijp, Haskerdijken, Haskerhorne, Idskenhuizen, Joure, Langweer, Legemeer, Nieuwebrug, Nijehaske, Oldeouwer, Oudehaske, Ouwster-Nijega, Ouwsterhaule, Rohel, Rotstergast, Rotsterhaule, Rottum, Scharsterbrug, Sint Nicolaasga, Sintjohannesga, Snikzwaag, Terkaple, Teroele, Tjerkgaast, and Vegelinsoord.

samples.title: Iao
samples.original_text:
Iao may refer to:
 IAO (album), an album by avant jazz musician John Zorn
 Iao (Gnosticism), an archon corresponding to Jupiter
 Iao Theater, a theater in Wailuku, Hawaii
 Iao Valley, a tourist attraction in Maui, Hawaii
 Sayak Airport (IATA code: IAO), also known as Siargao Airport, in Surigao del Norte, Philippines
 , an early Greek form of the tetragrammaton, or name of God

IAO may stand for:

 Incorporated Association Of Organists
 Indian Astronomical Observatory, home of the highest telescope in the world
 Information Awareness Office, a branch of the U.S. Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA)
 Interests, Activities, and Opinions - IAO or psychographic variables
 International Accreditation Organization (Houston, TX)
 International Academy of Osteopathy, an international school offering academic training in osteopathy
 International Astronomy Olympiad, an astronomy competition for high-school students
 Interparliamentary Assembly on Orthodoxy, an organization of parliamentarians of the Eastern Orthodox Church
 Institut d'Asie Orientale (Lyons Institute of East Asian Studies), a centre for research in human and social sciences at Université Lumière-Lyon 2 and Institut d'études politiques de Lyon
 Institute for Art and Olfaction, a non-profit organization
 Istituto agronomico per l'oltremare (Overseas Agronomic Institute), a technical and scientific body of the Italian Ministry of Foreign Affairs

See also
 Yao (disambiguation)

easy_general.text: Iao can mean many different things. It can be the name of an album by the jazz musician John Zorn. It can also be a character in Gnosticism, a set of beliefs, that represents the planet Jupiter. Iao is the name of a theater in Wailuku, Hawaii, and a tourist attraction in Maui, Hawaii. It is the name of an airport in the Philippines, and it is also a name for God.

adult_non_technical.text:
The term "Iao" can refer to several different things. It could be an album by a jazz musician named John Zorn, a character from Gnosticism, a theater in Hawaii, a valley in Maui, an airport in the Philippines, or an old Greek name for God.

Additionally, "IAO" can stand for various organizations, such as a group of organists, an astronomical observatory in India, or a part of the U.S. military. It can also refer to a group that studies interests, activities, and opinions, a school for osteopathy, or an astronomy competition for high school students.

adult_technical.text:
The term "Iao" can refer to various entities, including the IAO album by avant-garde jazz virtuoso John Zorn, the Gnostic archon Iao associated with Jupiter, the Iao Theater in Wailuku, Hawaii, the scenic Iao Valley in Maui, Hawaii, the Sayak Airport (IATA code: IAO) in Surigao del Norte, Philippines, and an early Greek form of the tetragrammaton, the sacred name of God.

The acronym "IAO" can also symbolize several organizations and institutions: the Incorporated Association of Organists, the Indian Astronomical Observatory, the Information Awareness Office within the U.S. Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA), the Interests, Activities, and Opinions (IAO) psychographic variables, the International Accreditation Organization based in Houston, Texas, the International Academy of Osteopathy which offers academic training in osteopathy, the International Astronomy Olympiad, the Interparliamentary Assembly on Orthodoxy, the Institut d'Asie Orientale (Lyons Institute of East Asian Studies), and the Institute for Art and Olfaction. Additionally, the Istituto agronomico per l'oltremare (Overseas Agronomic Institute) is a technical and scientific body under the Italian Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

For further information, please see Yao (disambiguation).

samples.title: 499 BC
samples.original_text:
Year 499 BC was a year of the pre-Julian Roman calendar. In the Roman Empire it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Aebutius and Cicurinus (or, less frequently, year 255 Ab urbe condita). The denomination 499 BC for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events 
 By place 

 Greece 
 After a failed attack on the rebellious island of Naxos in  501 BC (on behalf of the Persians), Aristagoras, tyrant of Miletus, to save himself from the wrath of Persia, plans a revolt with the Milesians and the other Ionians. With the encouragement of Histiaeus (his father-in-law and former tyrant of Miletus), Aristagoras induces the Ionian cities of Asia Minor to revolt against Persia, thus instigating the Ionian Revolt and beginning the Greco-Persian Wars between Greece and Persia. The pro-Persian tyrant of Mytilene is stoned to death.
 Miltiades the Younger, the ruler of the Thracian Chersonese, which has been under Persian suzerainty since approximately 514 BC, joins the Ionian revolt. He seizes the islands of Lemnos and Imbros from the Persians.
 Aristagoras seeks help with the revolt against the Persians from Cleomenes I, king of Sparta, but the Spartans are unwilling to respond.

References

easy_general.text: In the year 499 BC, some important things happened in Greece. A man named Aristagoras, who was in charge of a city called Miletus, decided to fight against the Persians. He convinced other people to join him, and they started a big fight called the Ionian Revolt. This fight was part of a bigger war called the Greco-Persian Wars, which was a fight between Greece and Persia. Aristagoras also tried to get some help from the king of Sparta, Cleomenes I, but the Spartans didn't want to help.

adult_non_technical.text:
In the year 499 BC, some important events happened in Greece. Aristagoras, a leader from Miletus, decided to start a rebellion against the Persians after he failed in an attempt to take over the island of Naxos in 501 BC. Aristagoras got help from the Milesians and other Ionians, who were also unhappy with the Persians. With the support of his father-in-law, Histiaeus, Aristagoras convinced the Ionian cities in Asia Minor to join the rebellion. This event, known as the Ionian Revolt, marked the beginning of the Greco-Persian Wars between Greece and Persia.

During this time, a leader from Mytilene who supported the Persians was killed by his own people. Miltiades the Younger, who ruled a region called the Thracian Chersonese and had been under Persian control since 514 BC, also joined the rebellion. He took control of the islands of Lemnos and Imbros from the Persians.

Aristagoras sought help from Sparta, but the Spartans refused to assist.

adult_technical.text:
In 499 BC, a pivotal year in the pre-Julian Roman calendar, which was known in the Roman Empire as the Year of the Consulship of Aebutius and Cicurinus or 255 Ab urbe condita, several significant events unfolded that shaped the course of ancient history, particularly in the regions of Greece and Asia Minor.

In Greece, following the failure of a Persian attack on the rebellious island of Naxos in 501 BC, Aristagoras, the tyrant of Miletus, sought to protect himself from Persian retribution by orchestrating a rebellion with the Milesians and other Ionian cities. With the support of his father-in-law, Histiaeus, the former tyrant of Miletus, Aristagoras successfully incited the Ionian cities in the region of Asia Minor to rise against Persian rule. This event, known as the Ionian Revolt, marked the beginning of the Greco-Persian Wars, a series of conflicts between Greece and Persia that would have profound implications for the development of ancient civilizations.

In the midst of this rebellion, the pro-Persian tyrant of Mytilene was executed by stoning, reflecting the violent nature of the conflict. Miltiades the Younger, the ruler of the Thracian Chersonese, which had been under Persian suzerainty since approximately 514 BC, joined the Ionian cause and seized the islands of Lemnos and Imbros from the Persians. This action demonstrated the scope of the rebellion and the determination of the Ionian cities to assert their independence from Persian control.

Despite the efforts of Aristagoras to secure assistance from Cleomenes I, the king of Sparta, the Spartans were unwilling to intervene. This decision highlights the complex political dynamics of the time, where Sparta, a powerful Greek city-state, chose not to engage in the conflict, further influencing the trajectory of the Greco-Persian Wars.

The events of 499 BC were a turning point in the history of ancient Greece and Persia, setting the stage for a series of conflicts that shaped the course of ancient history. The Ionian Revolt and the subsequent Greco-Persian Wars would have a lasting impact on the development of ancient civilizations, influencing the course of world history and the evolution of the ancient world.

samples.title: Mary Township, Norman County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Mary Township is a township in Norman County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 102 at the 2000 census.

Mary Township was organized circa 1880, and named for Mary Thomas, the wife of a pioneer.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 35.4 square miles (91.8 km2), all land.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 102 people, 39 households, and 29 families residing in the township. The population density was 2.9 people per square mile (1.1/km2). There were 42 housing units at an average density of 1.2/sq mi (0.5/km2). The racial makeup of the township was 94.12% White, 5.88% from other races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 5.88% of the population.

There were 39 households, out of which 38.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 76.9% were married couples living together, and 23.1% were non-families. 23.1% of all households were made up of individuals, and 10.3% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.62 and the average family size was 3.10.

In the township the population was spread out, with 28.4% under the age of 18, 3.9% from 18 to 24, 33.3% from 25 to 44, 19.6% from 45 to 64, and 14.7% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 36 years. For every 100 females, there were 104.0 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 121.2 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $43,214, and the median income for a family was $44,000. Males had a median income of $38,750 versus $21,125 for females. The per capita income for the township was $16,836. There were 5.3% of families and 9.9% of the population living below the poverty line, including 14.3% of under eighteens and 9.5% of those over 64.

References

Townships in Minnesota

Most people in Mary Township are white, with 94.12% of the population being white. The remaining 5.88% are from other races. About 5.88% of the population is Hispanic or Latino.

There are 39 households in Mary Township, and 29 of them are families. About 38.5% of the households have children under the age of 18, with 76.9% being married couples living together. The rest of the population is spread out, with 3.9% being between 18 and 24, 33.3% between 25 and 44, 19.6% between 45 and 64, and 14.7% being 65 or older. The median age is 36 years old. For every 100 women, there are 104 men, and for every 100 women aged 18 and older, there are 121 men.

The average household size is 2.62 people, and the average family size is 3.10 people. The median income for a household in Mary Township is $43,214, and the median income for a family is $44,000. Males have a median income of $38,750, while females have a median income of $21,125. The per capita income for the township is $16,836.

About 5.3% of families and 9.9% of the population live below the poverty line, including 14.3% of under 18s and 9.5% of those over 64.

samples.title: 650s BC
samples.original_text:
This article concerns the period 659 BC – 650 BC.

Events and trends
Occupation begins at Maya site of Piedras Negras, Guatemala.
First evidence of written Olmec language from the New World.  Pyramid building continues.
657 BC—Cypselus becomes the first tyrant of Corinth.
657 BC—The Li Ji Unrest is a series of events from 657BC to 651BC that takes place during the Spring and Autumn Period, caused by Li Ji, the concubine of Duke Xian of Jin, in order to put his son Xiqi onto the throne of Jin.
656 BC—Psamtik I extends his control over all of Egypt. End of Twenty-fifth Dynasty.
653 BC—Atta-Khumma-In-Shushinak and Khumbanigash II succeed Shilhak-In-Shushinak and Tempti-Khumma-In-Shushinak as kings of the Elamite Empire.
652 BC—Babylonia rises in revolt under Shamash-shum-ukin against the Assyrians.
652 BC—Guan Zhong urges the Duke of Qi to maintain the respect of the other states by refusing the offer of the son of a recently defeated state's ruler to ally himself with Qi if Qi would help him depose his father.
651 BC—Zhou xiang wang becomes King of the Zhou Dynasty of China.
650 BC—The town of Abdera in Thrace is founded by colonists from Clazomenae.
 First evidence of writing in the New World, among the Olmec Winters, C.A. (1984a). Blacks in ancient America. Colorlines, 3(2), 27–28.
650 BC—A climate change affects all the Bronze Age cultures in Europe with colder and wetter climate, and tribes from the Scandinavian Nordic Bronze Age cultures are pushed downwards into the European continent.
650 BC–625 BC—Wine pitcher (oinochoe), from Rhodes, is made. It is now at Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.

Significant people
 653 BC—Death of Tantamani, last king of the Twenty-fifth Dynasty of Egypt
 652 BC—Death of Zhou hui wang, king of the Zhou Dynasty of China
 652 BC—First recorded mention of King Kuras of Parsumas, possibly the same as King Cyrus I of Anshan, head of the Achaemenid dynasty

References

easy_general.text:
This article is about the time between 659 BC and 650 BC. During this period, many important things happened.

Events and Trends
The Maya site of Piedras Negras in Guatemala starts to be occupied.
The first evidence of written Olmec language is found in the New World.
Pyramid building continues.
657 BC—Cypselus becomes the first tyrant of Corinth.
657 BC—A series of events called the Li Ji Unrest happens from 657 BC to 651 BC. This unrest was caused by Li Ji, the concubine of Duke Xian of Jin, who wanted her son Xiqi to become the ruler of Jin.
656 BC—Psamtik I takes control of all of Egypt, ending the Twenty-fifth Dynasty.
653 BC—Two new kings, Atta-Khumma-In-Shushinak and Khumbanigash II, take over the Elamite Empire.
652 BC—Babylonia rebels against the Assyrians under Shamash-shum-ukin.
652 BC—Guan Zhong advises the Duke of Qi to keep the respect of other states by refusing an offer from the son of a recently defeated ruler to ally with Qi if Qi would help him overthrow his father.
651 BC—Zhou xiang wang becomes the king of the Zhou Dynasty of China.
650 BC—The town of Abdera in Thrace is founded by colonists from Clazomenae.
650 BC—A climate change affects the Bronze Age cultures in Europe, making it colder and wetter. Tribes from the Scandinavian Nordic Bronze Age cultures are pushed downwards into the European continent.
650 BC–625 BC—A wine pitcher called an oinochoe is made in Rhodes. It is now at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.

Significant People
653 BC—Tantamani, the last king of the Twenty-fifth Dynasty of Egypt, dies.
652 BC—Zhou hui wang, the king of the Zhou Dynasty of China, dies.
652 BC—The first mention of King Kuras of Parsumas is recorded. He might have been King Cyrus I of Anshan, the head of the Achaemenid dynasty.

References

adult_non_technical.text:
This article covers the period from 659 BC to 650 BC. During this time, people started living in a Maya city, called Piedras Negras, in Guatemala. We also see the first evidence of written language from the Olmec civilization in the New World. They also continued building pyramids.

In 657 BC, a man named Cypselus became the first ruler of Corinth, a city in ancient Greece. This was also a time of unrest in China, known as the Li Ji Unrest. It started with a woman named Li Ji who had a son she wanted to bring to the throne of the Jin state.

In 656 BC, a king named Psamtik I took control of all of Egypt, ending the Twenty-fifth Dynasty. In 653 BC, two new kings took over the Elamite Empire.

In 652 BC, Babylonia rebelled against the Assyrians under a leader named Shamash-shum-ukin. In 651 BC, a man named Zhou xiang wang became the king of the Zhou Dynasty in China.

In 650 BC, a new town called Abdera was founded in Thrace by people from Clazomenae. This was also the first time we see evidence of writing in the New World, among the Olmec civilization.

In 650 BC, the climate in Europe became colder and wetter, and people from Scandinavian were pushed down into the European continent. Between 650 BC and 625 BC, a wine pitcher called an oinochoe was made in Rhodes, which is now in the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.

In 653 BC, a king named Tantamani died, ending the Twenty-fifth Dynasty of Egypt. In 652 BC, a king named Zhou hui wang died, ending the Zhou Dynasty in China. This was also the first time we hear about a King Kuras of Parsumas, who might be the same as King Cyrus I of Anshan, the head of the Achaemenid dynasty.

References:

samples.title: Visualization
samples.original_text:
Visualization or visualisation may refer to:
Visualization (graphics), the physical or imagining creation of images, diagrams, or animations to communicate a message
 Data visualization, the graphic representation of data
 Information visualization, the study of visual representations of abstract data 
 Music visualization, animated imagery based on a piece of music
Mental image, the experience of images without the relevant external stimuli
 "Visualization", a song by Blank Banshee on the 2012 album Blank Banshee 0

See also
 Creative visualization (disambiguation)
 Visualizer (disambiguation)
 
 
 
 Graphics
 List of graphical methods, various forms of visualization
 Guided imagery, a mind-body intervention by a trained practitioner 
 Illustration, a decoration, interpretation or visual explanation of a text, concept or process
 Image, an artifact that depicts visual perception, such as a photograph or other picture
 Infographics

easy_general.text:
"Visualization can refer to different things:

1. Visualization (graphics): This is when people create images, diagrams, or animations to show a message.
2. Data visualization: This is when people use pictures to show information.
3. Information visualization: This is the study of how to use pictures to show complex information.
4. Music visualization: This is when people create moving pictures to go with music.
5. Mental image: This is when you see a picture in your mind, like a memory or a dream, without actually seeing it.
6. "Visualization": This is a song by a band called Blank Banshee on their 2012 album.

Other things related to visualization:
- Creative visualization: This is when people use their imagination to create pictures.
- Visualizer: This is a tool that helps people create pictures.
- Graphics: These are pictures or diagrams that show information.
- Guided imagery: This is when someone helps you imagine pictures to relax or heal.
- Illustration: This is using pictures to explain a story.
- Infographics: These are pictures that show information quickly."

adult_non_technical.text: "Visualization is the process of creating images, diagrams, or animations to communicate a message. It can be used to represent data, information, or even music. Visualization can also refer to the experience of seeing images in your mind without any external stimuli."

adult_technical.text:
Visualization is a broad term that encompasses various methods of representing data, information, or concepts in a visual format. Here are some key aspects of visualization:

1. Visualization (graphics): This refers to the creation of images, diagrams, or animations, either physically or mentally, to convey a message.
2. Data visualization: This involves the graphical representation of data to facilitate understanding and analysis.
3. Information visualization: This is the study of creating visual representations of abstract data.
4. Music visualization: This involves creating animated imagery based on a piece of music.
5. Mental image: This refers to the experience of images without the relevant external stimuli.
6. "Visualization" (song): This is a song by Blank Banshee on their 2012 album, Blank Banshee 0.

See also: Creative visualization (disambiguation), Visualizer (disambiguation), Graphics, List of graphical methods, Guided imagery, Illustration, Image, Infographics.
